projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TRANSACTIONS OF THE High Court of CHANCERY, Both by Practice and Pre≈øident, With the Fees thereunto belonging, And all ≈øpeciall Orders in Extraordinary Ca≈øes, which are to be found in the Regi≈øters Office as they are quoated by Tearmes Yeares & Bookes.
Collected by that famous Lawyer WILLIAM TOTHILL E≈øq late one of the 6 Clearks. And ≈øince Reveiwed by Sir RO: HOLBORNE, Bencher of Lincoln:-Inne.
London Printed by T.W. for R. BEST and I. PLACE, and are to be ≈øold at Grays. Inne-Gate. 1649.

div.head: The tran≈øactions of the high Court of Chancery, both by Practice and Pre≈øident, &c.
ACTIONS.
div.p:
Actions of tre≈øpas tryed in a forraigne County.
DOmina Chandois contra Chandois, the Court ordered that an Action of Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe ≈øhall bee tried in any forraigne County in July 37. Eliz. Reginae.
Barlow contra Wogan, in 8. Jacdi. A. ≈øo. 186.
The like between Tigh and Tigh, in Hillar.. 15. Jac. Regis.
Page cont' Page, li. A. fo. 74. Eliz. 44. & 45.
Barre≈øton contra li. B. 40. Eliz. fo. 724.
Mulca≈øter cont' Mulca≈øter, Pa≈øch. 44. Eliz.
Greg≈øon contra Everard, in Trin. 21. Jac. Regis.

Comes Bedford contra Ru≈ø≈øell, further
part of the County, in 3. Car. Reg.
Dominus Wind≈øor contra Wright, in Pa≈øch. 2. Car. Regis.
Flood contra Tracie, in Mich. or Hill. 5. Car.
I I≈øley contra Dom. Parham, in 32. Eliz. li. B. fo. 839.
Circuity of action pleaded. Kirkham contra Saunders, Circuity of Action, the Defendant not prohibited to plead ≈øeverall Lea≈øes for defence of his title, in 34. Eliz. li. A.
Ownen contra Lort, an Action of Travers ‚Ä¢ yed in a forraigne County, in 10. Car. Regis.

div.head: Acts of Parliament.
div.p: Act of Parliament. Bowes contra Comitem Northumbrit, concerning the relation of an Act of Parliament.

div.head: Accompt.
div.p: Accompt. A Merchants Accompt perfected whether within the Stat. &c. Lumley contra Garret, when Merchants and Cotraders have made an Accompt, ≈øhall not be compelled here to make a new Accompt, 12. Car.
Sands contra Bladwell, Merchants Accompts. Whether an Accompt perfected ≈øhall be within the compa≈ø≈øe of the Statute of lymitation of Accompt, 13. Car.

div.head: Admi≈ø≈øion.
div.p: Admi≈ø≈øion. A Lord to admit a Tenant. Lunsford contra Popham, a Lord to admit a Tenant, 23 Janu. 14. Jae.
Newby contra Chamberlame, the Court compells a Lord to admit a Tenant, in Mich, or Hillar. 5. Carol.
March cont. Gage eod' to admit a Tenant.

No advaÃÑ tage to be taken, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øtatute of limitation. Gravener contra Rake, the Court compells the Lord to admit a Tenant Copiholder to ≈øue at law, without any forfeiture of his Copihold. in Mich. 31. & 32. Eliz. fo. 21.

div.head: Advantage.
div.p: Comes Pembroke contra Hacket, no advantage to be taken at law, notwith≈øtanding the Statute of limitation, 10. Car.

div.head: Advow≈øon.
div.p: Magi≈øter Coll' Emanuell' contra Ewens, Advow≈øon. concerning an Advow≈øon which pa≈ø≈øed but by generall words, Decreed in Equitie, in Hill. 21. Jac. li. A. fo. 572.

div.head: Affidavit.
div.p: Hill contra Tiller, Affidavit. upon a Certificate from the Major of a Town under the Common Seale, that an Affidavit was made before him for ≈øerving of Proces, an Attachment was awarded, in 19. Eliz. fo. 63. li. A.

div.head: Agreement.
div.p: Agreement made before Commi≈ø≈øioners Decreed.A draught of an Agreement before the Commi≈ø≈øioners Decreed, notwith≈øtanding the Defendant refu≈øed, Inter Pope & Ma≈øon, 11. & 12. Eliz. fo. 301.
Smith contra Gouch, A man that marries the Executrix of one that makes an Agreement, ≈øhall be as farre bound, as hee him≈øelfe that made the Agreement. Trin. 40. Eliz. li. B. fo. 118.

Agreement to convey lands in tayle though imbezilled decreed. Bates contra Heard, there was agreement between the ≈øaid Parties, that lands ≈øhould be conveyed in tayle, that the ≈øame being taken away, was confirmed by Decree to be performed according to the ≈øaid Articles, in Maij 11. Jac. li. A. fo. 864.
Throckmorton contra Dom. Throckmorton, Articles of Agreement decreed by the Judges advice, in Novemb. 7. Jac. li. B. fo. 301.
Wadbroke cont' Cheeke, an Agreement for ≈øurrendring of a Copihold (though made when the party was in Pri≈øon) upon Bonds for performance thereof, in 3. Car.
Fo≈øter cont' Eltonhead, an Agreement decreed, & Beuther cont' Denton. 25. Eliz.
Kinner≈øley contra Waller, concerning examination of ≈øome parties to a Joynt ≈øtock, after an Agreement made by ≈øome other parties, 3. Car.
Erby cont' Evans, concerning a promi≈øe or bare Agreement in Mich. or Hillar. 5. Car.

Penni≈øton cont' Com' Downe, concerning Articles of agreement, and would avoyd an
E≈øtate upon pretence of no delivery, Decreed in Mich. or Hillar. 5. Car.
Pollington cont' Pollington, about 6. Car.

Owen cont' Deane, the Defendant got an a≈ø≈øurance of Lands of one in Remainder of an E≈øtate by Fine, contrary to an Agreement made to him that had the Remainder, and the Plaintiffe decreed notwith≈øtanding that the Defendant ≈øhould rea≈ø≈øure it to the Plaintife in Nov. 4. Jac.
Agreement for a Cu≈øtome, binds a Purcha≈øer If by threats otherwi≈øe. Spicer cont' Dockwray, an Agreement for a cu≈øtome ≈øhall bind a Purcha≈øer or Heir, 12. Car'.
Plowden cont' Mar≈øham, if Agreement be compelled by threats, it ≈øhall not bind, in Hillar. 3. Car'. look tenth of June 1602. the contrary between Lord and Tenant.
Agreement or promi≈øe to pa≈ø≈øe lands of Inheritance. Moyles Ca≈øe cont' Horne and others, by rea≈øon two hundred pounds was depo≈øited towards payment, decreed.
Wilkin≈øon cont' Deane, Mich. 2. Car. which afterwards pa≈ø≈øed away again≈øt the Buyer, becau≈øe notice of Agreement.
Fithing cont' Portman, 43. Eliz.
Aubery cont' Concerning an agreement made by a Joyntenement, in 6. Car. li. B.
Page cont' Bi≈øhop, concerning an Agreement in 8. Carol.

div.head: Alyen.
div.p: An Alien cannot ≈øue. Proud cont' Proud, a Demurrer becau≈øe an Alyen cannot ≈øue, and becau≈øe a Legacie given one in ventre ≈øa mere, look the Judges Certificate, in 14. Car.

div.head: Allowance.
div.p: Allowance to children where there is none by Will. Bright cont' Chappell, children allowed ≈øeaven or eight pounds per centum for their Education, where there is no allowance by the Will, in 5. Car'.
Fi≈øher cont' Valence, the Defendant to allow damages for profits received, in Mich. 3. Carol.
Dorrington cont' Skinner, in 8. Car.
Charli≈øh cont' I liffe, Eight pounds per centum look whether the Mortgage was before the Statute of 21. or ≈øince, it was for a Portion, Ju. 3. Car. fo. 268.

div.head: Annuities.
div.p: Annuity. Fage cont' Waller, A Lea≈øe devi≈øed to one, out of that, there is by Will Annuities given, one of the Annuities dyed, one other of them claimes that Annuity by Admini≈øtration, ≈øtration, Decreed again≈øt the Executors 20. Octob. 1631.

Annuity devi≈øed out of lands good, &c. Baynham & Newland com' Goche, an Annuity devi≈øed out of lands holden in Capite to charitable u≈øes, holden good notwith≈øtanding the ≈øtatute of 44. Eliz. li. A. fo. 520.
Je≈øus Colledge ca≈øe in court of Wards in 13. Jac.
Gardiani de Eltham in June. 15. Jac.
Ald≈øey cont' Place, a ca≈øe made in Mich. 2. Car.
Major de Reading cont' Lane, gift to poore, becau≈øe no Corporation voyd, yet relieved in 42. Eliz. A. fo. 706.

Annuity intayled thought not good. Pavier cont' Pavier, an Annuity granted, but becau≈øe the lands are not chargeable at law, this Court will not in equitie, but decreed to be paid in 14. Car. fo. 213.
Wiard cont' Mo≈ø≈øe, an Annuity intailed thought not good, in Hill. 15. Car.

div.head: An≈øwers.
div.p: An≈øwers. Toy enforced at the ≈øuit of Kirke, to ≈øet down upon his Oath, whether his Lea≈øe was expired or not, 25. Eliz.
The Defendant not inforced to an≈øwer to his own hurt. Mildmay was not inforced by An≈øwer to the Bill of Cary and Cottington, to di≈øcover a Forfeiture to his own hurt, 32. & 33. Eliz.
The plaintif admitted to proofes, becau≈øe the defendant being in pri≈øon would not an≈øwer. Per≈øons of Corporation charged as private per≈øons, an≈øwered upon Oath.
Warr' cont' Societatem Feltmakers, in 20. or 21. Jac.
Gowen cont' Taylor, 38. & 39. Eliz. The Defendant being in Pri≈øon would not an≈øwer, therefore the Plaintife was admitted to proceed to proofes.

Becket cont' Waller, 28 Novemb. 40. Eliz. The Defendant being in Pri≈øon, and not in the Fleet, would not make a better An≈øwer, though two Subpena's were ≈øerved My Lord Keeper ≈øaid, Let that be depo≈øed, and hee ≈øhould be ≈øhut up clo≈øe Pri≈øoner in what Pri≈øon ≈øoever he was. Butt cont' Ward, the Defendant enforced to an≈øwer without his wife, 28. Eliz.
Elizabeth Breneton cont' Hart, Mich. 1587. the like.
Kirkham cont' Saunder≈øon, Saunder≈øon having two lea≈øes, was allowed to ≈øtand by An≈øwer upon them both, and not re≈øtrained to one at his perill, Hillar. 35. Eliz.

Burgony contra Machell, the Defendant divided his title by a Lea≈øe and A≈ø≈øignment, which was before his knowledge, and therefore pleaded that he heard ≈øay, that ≈øuch a Lea≈øe and A≈ø≈øignment was made; The Ma≈øter of the Rolls was of opinion, becau≈øe it was anothers Act, the Oath is, that hee thinkes it to be true; The Defendant might have pleaded directly, that they were made as he thinketh 37. Eliz.

Rotheram cont' Saunders, the Defendant An≈øwered, that he had no Evidencs belonging to the Plaintife, that An≈øwer was di≈øallowed, becau≈øe the Defendant therein will be his own Judge, whether they belonged
to the Plaintife or not. And therefore hee was ordered to an≈øwer what he had, and to bring them to be viewed to whom they belonged. Pas. 37. Eliz.
A mans own acts mu≈øt be an≈øwered directly upon Oath, in the affirmative or negative, without Traver≈øe. As Ma≈øter Ju≈øtice Beamont held in the Ca≈øe of Williams & Leighton: 38. Eliz.

Stauden cont' Bullock, the Defendant, forced to ≈øet down to whom he a≈ø≈øigned his Lea≈øe, becau≈øe otherwi≈øe the Lea≈ø≈øor would have no action of Wa≈øt, and to ≈øet downe the names of the per≈øons, whom hee had cau≈øed to fell trees, whereby the Lea≈øor might have his action again≈øt them, 38. & 39. Eliz.
Wilcox & Yates cont' Fi≈øher, after Replication, a better An≈øwer ordered, 38. & 39. Eliz.

To An≈øwer directly.Whether a Lycence to a≈ø≈øigne a Lea≈øe were granted or not, being but three yeares pa≈øt, the Defendant ordered by my Lord to an≈øwer directly, and not to his Remembrance. O≈øwald con' Pennant, 38. & 39. Eliz.

Part of the Title omitted out of the An≈øwer, and the Defendant would have put in a ≈øecond An≈øwer with the full title, and my Lord ≈øaid not for all hee is worth. Ward & Colmer. 1597. & 40. Eliz. and Dacres & Stanhop, eod.
Harbert contra Morgan, 1597. the Defendant ordered to ≈øet down his Terme certaine.

The Defendant could not an≈øwer certainly what con≈øideration hee had a Lea≈øe for twenty yeares pa≈øt, and not confe≈ø≈øed it directly, but my Lord ≈øaid it was a crafty An≈øwer, for he ≈øaid directly that it was not upon tru≈øt, and it was of good value. Randall was Plaintiff in 1597.

Willoughby contra Dom. Wharton, ≈øhe appointed to an≈øwer upon Oath, and not upon her honour, and ≈øo they ought to be ≈øworne as witne≈ø≈øes (as my Lord held) or el≈øe no Attaint lyeth, if the Jury do not according to Evidences, 1597.
Michell' cont' Webb, 1. Novemb. 4. Eliz.
The Defendant by An≈øwer accu≈øeth him≈øelfe and fellow Defendant, and is believed again≈øt him≈øelfe, but not again≈øt his Fellow.

Whether a Joyntenant ≈øhould be inforced by law to di≈øclo≈øe a partition in the life of his Fellow. Be≈øt cont'
_____ did, two Orders in 22. or 23. Eliz.
Cromer cont' Penni≈øton, in 39. & 40. Eliz. doubted.

p.hi: Infants to an≈øwer upon Oath, and bound by Decree.

div.p: Warberton contra Fan≈øhaw. Mich. 39. Eliz. li. B. fo. 289.
Infants to An≈øwer by Guardian, Com' Dor≈øet cont' Puckle, in Hillar. li. B. 683. 1361.

We≈øterne contra Talpit, 12. Mai ‚Ä¢
37. Eliz. li. B. fo. 106.
Langley contra Marke, primo Eliz. li. B. fo. 71.
Arch. cont' Collins, 6. Maii primo Eliz. fo. 113.121.
Phillips contra Owen-ap-Howell. 2. Eliz. li. A. fo. 121.
Po≈øthumus Hobbie cont' Smith, 18. Jac. 229.
To an≈øwer upon Oath. Rivell cont' Com' Salop, the Defendant to an≈øwer upon Oath, Mich. 10. Jac.
Comes Pembroke cont' Wainman, an Infant of 12 yeares, but not upon Oath, 5. Jac. li, A. fo. 1051.
To an≈øwer though excommunicated. Tichborne cont' Edmonds, the Defendant to an≈øwer the Bill though excommunicatod 37. Eliz. li. A. fo. 376. Plumpton contra Belloes.
To an≈øwer a Bill of perjurie. Philips cont' Ben≈øon, the Defendant ordered to an≈øwer a Bill of perjurie, 19. Eliz. li. B. fo. 165.
Wolley cont' Long, Pa≈øch. 10. Jac.
An≈øwer voluntarily. Gargrave contra Gargrave, in 1597. the Defendant an≈øwered voluntarily.
Jervace & Baxter, Trin. 22. Eliz.
A Report in 39. Eliz. between Rumney and Wentworth.
Trentham contra Kinner≈øley & Uxor, the Wives an≈øwer admitted without the Hu≈øbands, hee pretending pleading Juri≈ødiction of Court, 4. Jac. li. B. fo. 90.

2. Defendants one an≈øwering and the other refu≈øing ≈øhall be bound by the others an≈øwer. Ordered to an≈øwer though to his prejudice. Criminall cau≈øes to be an≈øwered unto. Mathew contra Mathew, two Defendants, one having an≈øwered, the other refu≈øed, but ≈øhall be bound by the others An≈øwer, if the cau≈øe pa≈ø≈øe again≈øt them, 7. Jac. fo. 702.
Che≈øter contra Hicks, Hill' 1633, to amend an An≈øwer in the mi≈øtaking.
Eland contra Cottington, ordered to An≈øwer, though it bee to his prejudice by Statute lawes, in Trinit. or Mich. 4. Car.

Wakeman contra Smith, although criminall Cau≈øes are not here to be tryed directly for the puni≈øhing of them, yet incidently for ≈øo much as concerneth the Equitie of the cau≈øe, they are to bee an≈øwered.
Sir Mathew Carews Report in 27. Eliz.
Winn contra Swayne, a Commi≈ø≈øioner, to An≈øwer Briberie and Corruption, Trin. 6. Car.
A Bi≈øhop to an≈øwer upon oath. Major Sarum contra Epi≈øc' Sarum, a Bi≈øhop to an≈øwer upon Oath, 8. Car.
Eyre contra Wortley, one Defendants an≈øwer ≈øhall not prejudice the other Defendant, about 3: Car.

An≈øwer not to be amended after i≈ø≈øue joyned. Chettle contra Chettle, a Rejoynder and a Commi≈ø≈øion, the Defendant to amend her An≈øwer, but my Lord ≈øaith not to amend an an≈øwer after i≈ø≈øue joyned, Mich. 9. Car. Quere further what was determined.
Exchequer man to an≈øwer. Ea≈øt contra Betti≈øon, Pa≈øch. 21. Eliz. li. A. fol. 176. an Exchequer man to an≈øwer.
Menell contra Fenton, eod. fo. 231.
Reader contra Ceble, after a Dedimus to an≈øwer, libertie to demurr. 9. Car. li. B. fo. 333.
Pridgeon contra Lambe, or Thornbur≈øt contra Lambe, 7. Car.
Perry contra Gunter, in Pa≈øch. 2. Car. li. A. fo. 546.
A feme covert to an≈øwer. Acton contra Decanum Elye, the Defendant to an≈øwer as a Politique body, 9. Car. Quere whether upon Oath.
Portman contra Popham, a Wife to an≈øwer without her Husband, he being beyond Sea in 11. Car.

div.head: Arrerages.
div.p: Arrerages. Saris contra Strudhay, the Plaintiffe to have Arrerages before Attornment, 25. Eliz.
Drury contra Drury, concerning how far a Joyntenant ≈øhall allow arerages before partition, 6. Car.

div.head: A≈ø≈øignement.
div.p: A≈ø≈øignement before a Comm≈ø≈øion of Bankrupt ≈øued out good. Yardley contra Knight, a Debt' a≈ø≈øigned before a Commi≈ø≈øion of Bankrupt ≈øued out, good, 7. Car.

div.head: A≈ø≈øurance.
div.p: A≈ø≈øurance Kempe cont' Palmer, in 1594. further a≈ø≈øurance not demanded within the time, yet in equitie ordered to make further a≈ø≈øurance afterwards.

The Wife to make an A≈ø≈øurance. Inter Carrington & Uxor quer', & Humphrey Defendant. It is ordered, that the Defendant and his wife, ≈øhall make an ab≈øolute a≈ø≈øurance for the extingui≈øhment of her Right in the lands, in primo Edw. 6. fo. 306. & in li. C. fo. 3019.
Bee≈øton contra Langford, further a≈ø≈øurance compelled 41. Eliz. li. B. fo. 222.

div.head: Attachments.
div.p: Attachment again≈øt Lords. An Attachment again≈øt the Lord Cromwell again≈øt Tavernor about 14. Eliz.
The like again≈øt the Lord Dacres, 32. E. liz. li. A. fo. 65.
An Attachment about June, 37. Eliz. again≈øt the Lord Barkley, at the motion of the Counte≈ø≈øe of Warr'.

Attachment again≈øt the wife without the husband for not an≈øwering. Keies contra Macher, an Attachment again≈øt the Wife alone, and not the Hu≈øband, for that ≈øhee would not an≈øwer the Bill, Mich. 4. Jac.

Farmer contra Fox, becau≈øe the Defendant maketh Oath, that he cannot an≈øwer without ≈øight of Writings in the Country, and then puts in a Demurrer, therefore an Attachment is awarded again≈øt him, Pa≈øch. 21. Eliz.
Attachment again≈øt Infant. Savill contra Slingsby, an Attachment again≈øt an Infant, to make him to choo≈øe a Gardian, Hillar. 7. Car.

Witham contra Robert, an Attachment awarded again≈øt the Plaintiff, for arre≈øting the Defendant, upon an Attachment in the Court of Reque≈øts, again≈øt the Priviledge of this Court, the Defendant being formerly a priviledged man, and an Injunction to ≈øtay proceedings there, 9. Car.

div.head: Attorney.
div.p: Might an Attorney, ≈øued at Law upon an Action of the Ca≈øe, for confe≈ø≈øing an Action without Warrant for one Hargate, for whom he had been an Attorney, wherefore Might ≈øought Reliefe in this Court, and could not have it, in 1595.

div.head: Attornement.
div.p: Attornment ordered. Hui≈øh & Blond & Fowler, 39. Eliz. Trin. & Pa≈øch. 36. Eliz. li. A. fo. 19.
Notwith≈øtanding a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin. Dannet cont' Blackall, an Attornment ordered notwith≈øtanding a Di≈ø≈øei≈øin, and it was for a Lea≈øe 11. Car. vel Jac.
Pie cont' Bevill, the Defendant ordered to ≈øhew Evidences, to direct what Tenants ought to Attorne, and to di≈øcover who is Tenant, 11. Car.
Sands cont' Lewes; an Attornement ordered and arrerages and damages ≈øince Rent became due 11. Car.
Viviun com' Tre≈øayer, notwith≈øtanding no Attornment before Quid juris clamat, ordered to goe to law directing a ≈øpeciall tryall in it, 14. Car.

div.head: Award.
div.p: An Award not to be decreed. D ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ contra Wood, Trinit. 24. Eliz. An Award made, the Defendant recovered money thereby, the Plaintiff would have had it Decreed, could not, becau≈øe it was not made by any Warrant of this Court.
An Award concerning a lea≈øe to be performed. Twyn contra Twinn, the Court ordereth an Award or agreement to be performed concerning a Lea≈øe and other things, 40. Eliz. l. B. fo. 463.
Sands con' Carvil, in 9. Car.
Award voluntary decreed. Car contra Heron, an Award decreed with the advice of the Lord chiefe Ju≈øtice, in 22. & 23. El. li. A. fo. 596.
Hall contra Hocks, in Nov. 38. & 39. Eliz. It is a voluntary Award.
Award decreed no party to the Exchange bound. Godderick contra Swan≈øell, an Award decreed by this Court, and a man bound, though no partie to the Exchange, 9. Jac. li. B. fo. 1456.

Bi≈øhop contra Bi≈øhop, a voluntary Award decreed, but ≈øome part being to bind Tenant in tayle not to alyen, the Court would not decree that, but gives reliefe again≈øt the Award, being to make a perpetuitie, and a man not bound to An≈øwer, as to cau≈øe him to be ≈øubject to the penalty of a Bond, and the Statute of lymitation (as this ca≈øe ≈øtands) is over-ruled, Mich. 15. Car.
Colt contra Smith, an Award made by Cordall and the Bi≈øhop forty yeares ≈øince, decreed again≈øt the ≈øucce≈ø≈øor for the manner of tithing, Mich. 21. Car.

div.head: Baile.
div.p: A Baile in this Court, or in the Civill law, is di≈øcharged upon bringing in the principall, as he may at the Common law.
Archboll contra Barrell, 23. & 24. Eliz.

div.head: Bargaine.
div.p: Bargain for hor≈øes by doubling of Oats. Rogers contra Smith, the ≈øuit is touching two Hor≈øes, for which the Defendant was to pay by doubling an Oate. demurred becau≈øe but an Action of the ca≈øe, over-ruled in 15. Car.

Fage contra Browne, concerning the
For a Lute by the ≈øtrings.buying of a Lute by the ≈øtrings, in 1. or 2. Car.

div.head: Barre≈øter.
div.p: Barre≈øter being free of a Company. Swallow contra Man, a Barre≈øter of the Temple, being free of a Company, and by his Will di≈øpo≈øeth of profits of lands, how far ≈øhall it trench upon the Cu≈øtome, Pa≈øch. 15. Car.

div.head: Bill.
div.p: One which had a Covenant to deliver Evidences, exhibited his Bill, ≈øuppo≈øing certaine Deeds to remaine in the Covenanters hand, the opinion of the Court was, the Defendant needed not to an≈øwer, becau≈øe he ≈øhould thereby di≈øclo≈øe cau≈øe of Forfeiture of the Bond. Wolgrave contra Coe, Mich. 1595.38. Eliz.

A Bill to examine Witne≈ø≈øes in perpetuall memorie touching common not thought fit but a Bill upon the title, and to examine Witne≈ø≈øes and publication thereupon, and then to goe to law. Throckmorton contra Griffin, 38. & 39. Eliz.
The Father complaineth for a Lea≈øe which is in the ≈øonne to the Fathers u≈øe. Pomeroy contra Ford, Pa≈øch 1597.

A Bill upon a penall Statute, clayming one halfe to the Queen, and another to the party, di≈øallowed by my Lords opinion. Coward & We≈øt, Trin, 39. Eliz. though ‚Ä¢
not mentioned in the Order..

Bill taken off the file and new put on. Clifford contra Adams. 11. & 12. Eliz. li. A. fo. 294. the Plantife having put in his Bill being mi≈øconceived, notwith≈øtanding An≈øwers put in, and proceedings had thereupon, was taken off the File and new put in.
Old and new proofes read upon a new bill. Stanley contra Young, Hillar. 1590. The Lord Chancellours opinion was, that the old and new proofes ≈øhould be read upon a new Bill, to prove better matter.

Bill for mony won at dice. Cromer exhibited a Bill again≈øt Champney, to be relieved of a Bond made for money wonne at Dice, the Defendant would have been di≈ømi≈ø≈øed but ordered to an≈øwer it, 22 Maij. 38. Eliz.
And the like ca≈øe between Hubbard, and the Lord Compton, about 44. Eliz.
Bill for Legacie di≈ømi≈ø≈øed. Piggot contra Par≈øon, 44. Eliz. Becau≈øe the ground of the Bill is for a Legacie, thought fit to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.
Pennington contra Cooke, a Bill to prevent Dower, being her Husband was pa≈øt memory at time of Marriage, but it was di≈ømi≈øt to law, 3. Jac. li. B. fo. 6.
Hare cont' Hide, a Bill preferred again≈øt an Infant, and he ordered to An≈øwer, Hill' 3. Jac. & Pa≈øch. Prox'.

Scoble contra Holman, if the Plaintiffs Bill were exhibited before Judgement the
Defendants proceedings to ≈øtay, or el≈øe nor, 38. Eliz. fo. 79.
No Bill of Revivor after Marriage. Vaux contra Dowell. 39. Eliz. lib. B. fo. 132. no Bill of Revivor after Marriage.
Dale contra Dale, the like.
In 25. Eliz. Sloper contra Bacon.
Cre≈øwell contra Luther, 19. & 20. Eliz. li. A. fo. 210. A Bill to find who is Tenant of land whereby to ground an Action.
No Bill of Review admitted upon new matter, Lovegraie contra Webb, 3 Jac. 259. Mudget contra Davies, 15. Jac. li. B.
Bill to be relieved upon an e≈øcape. Carn≈øew contra Coad, a Sheriffe preferred his Bill, to have reliefe upon an E≈øcape of one that was in execution, Mich. 20. Jac. li. B. fo. 306.
Reynell contra Quintin, li. A. 7. Jac. fo. 933. contrary.
Reynell contra Longca≈øtle, Hillar. 19, Jac. Boll & Farrington, 10. Jac. li. B. fo. 178.

A Bill in the nature of an Avowric for Rent. Cae≈øar contra Cater, Pas'. 9. Car. A Bill in the nature of an Avowrie for Rent, and ≈øervice, the Defendant ordered to ≈øet out a place, and ≈øtand upon right, or goe to hearing.

Bill to rever≈øe a Decree at York.
Askwith contra Turnor, Mich'. 1633. A Decree at Yorke, a Bill pre≈øerred in this Court to rever≈øe it, the matter was heard at large, not with≈øtanding any pleading of the Defendant.
Pre≈øton contra Proctar, 2 Car.
Boucher contra Barwicke Pa≈øc. vel Trin. 10. Car.

Bill a ‚Ä¢ yoluntary promi≈øe without preferment di≈ømi≈øt. Alexander contra Cre≈øheld, A generall and voluntary promi≈øe (and no con≈øideration) of the ≈øon, to di≈ø-ingage and pay the Fathers debts, where, no advancement by his Father, di≈ømi≈øt, 28 Octob. 7. Car.

Bill to be tenant by curte≈øie. Cowley contra Ander≈øon, 20 Jac. li. B. fo. 77. the Defendant conveyed land to the u≈øe of his Daughters,the Plaintiff married one, and had children by her who are dead, the plaintiff preferrs his Bill to bee Tenant by curte≈øie, but held not ≈øo, becau≈øe the Daughters had Joynt E≈øtates, and ≈øo goes to the Survivor.

Bill pretending more land pa≈øted then was intended, yet no reliefe again≈øt the Purcha≈øor. Clifford contra Laughton, the Plaintife preferrs a Bill in this Court again≈øt the Defendant, ≈øuppo≈øing that more lands pa≈ø≈øed then was intended, but becau≈øe the Defendant was a Purcha≈øer upon valuable con≈øideration, would give no reliefe, 4 Jac. li. B. fo. 340.
Bill for contribution to a Surety. King ≈ømill contra Etheridge, the Defendant ≈øueth for contribution after Judgement, which was a≈ø≈øigned for that purpo≈øe in June, 20. Jac.
Newman contra Lloyd, a Demurrer overruled about 20. Jac.

Hill Mil'. contra Penty, Wal≈øh & al'.
about 17. Jac. another in the Queens time between Agar and Cur≈øon.
Bill upon e≈øcape not relieved here. H ‚Ä¢ de contra Burges, upon a Bond 3, Car. A Bill preferred to be relieved upon point of e≈øcape, but di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.
Brackin contra Dom. Perpoint, 25. November 21. Jac.
Reynell contra Darling, 6 Octob. 19. Jac.
Reynell contra Whiting, 14. Maij. 19 Jac.
Bill to find a tenant to ground an Action. Dom' Kempe contra Risbie, A Bill to find a Tenant to an E≈øtate whereby to ground an Action of Dower, in Mich. 2 Car.
For an E≈øcape. Lello contra Lamplugh, concerning an E≈øcape, Mich. 5. Car.

Tenant pur auter vie prefers a Bill, or an Executor ≈øues for land. Hemming contra Leigh, Tenant pur auter vie, exhibited a Bill, or an Executor ≈øues for title of land, whether this ≈øhall hold in li. B. Car. 6. about two yeares after referred to Ma≈øter Ju≈øtice Jones.
For Fees di≈ømi≈øt. Harding contra Tedwell, a Bill for Fees was dimi≈ø≈øed, & Moore contra Rowe, 5. Car.
Yelverten contra Rolfe, 6. Car.
To ≈øet out boundaries. Tipping contra Chamberlaine, a ≈øuit to ≈øet out Boundaries, Mich. 2. Car.

2. Bils the fir≈øt in the Court of Reque≈øts, th' other here, the Defendant pleads the proceedings there over-ruled For mony wonne at dice, &c. Samuel contra Samuel. a Bill fir≈øt preferred in the Court of Reque≈øts, and the ≈øame being mi≈øtaken there, prefers another
Bill here, the Defendant pleads the proceeding in that Court, notwith≈øtanding over-ruled, 9. Car.

Sucklyn contra Morley, the Bill being to di≈øcover, what money the Defendant wonne at Dice or play of the Plaintiffe, overruled, and an Injunction, to ≈øtay ≈øuit upon a Bond entred into for the money, 11. Car.
To a≈ø≈øi≈øt a Covenant Dayrell contra Pollard, a Bill to a≈ø≈øi≈øt a Covenant, 11. Car.
In perpetuall memorie. Potts contra Scarborough, the Bill being to examine. Witne≈ø≈øes in perpetuall memorie concerning common reteyned, 11. Car.

di≈ømi≈ø≈øed upon an≈øwer. Walker contra Lip≈øcombe, for that the Plaintiffe ≈øheweth by his Bill, that hee hath no Witne≈ø≈øes to prove the ≈øame, and the Defendant denyed upon Oath, therefore di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, Mich. 12. Car. li. B.
Read contra Gilbert, a Demurrer put into a Bill for Fees for ≈øolliciting to di≈øcharge a Tenure done accordingly yet Demurrer to ≈øtand. 12. Car.
A Bill for a way. Savill contra Timperley, a Bill to bee relieyed for a way which hath been aboli≈øhed, a Commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øet it out in 8. Jac. fo. 855.
Rembolt contra Iames in Mich. 15. Car.

Vpon a promi≈øe to a≈ølure lands of Inheritance di≈ømi≈ø≈øed. Miller contra Blandi≈øt, to bee relieved concerning a promi≈øe to a≈ø≈øure land of Inheritance, but becau≈øe there was no execution thereof, but onely fifty five ≈øhillings paid in hand, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed in 30. Jac. li. B. fo. 234.
Towne contra Traherne, a Bill preferred here to ≈øtay a ≈øuit, brought upon fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, in 10. Jac. lib. A. fo, 477.
Arundell contra Drew, A Bill entred into to procure a Marriage, cancelled. A Ca≈øe between Cov ‚Ä¢ nors and Comes Suff. 10. Jac.
Delabarr contra Cox, the Bill to bee relieved upon Articles of Agreement, but (becau≈øe the bargain at Dice) would not decree it, in Mich. 14. Car.
Price contra Palmer, A ≈øuit to rever≈øe a Decree made again≈øt a Wife, ≈øhee con≈øenting to a Feme Coverts An≈øwer, ≈øhall nor bind, in M ‚Ä¢ ch. 9. Car.
To performe a Will. Hire contra Wardall, the Bill is to have a mans Will performed 9. July, 4. Car.
Aprice contra Aprice, a Bill preferred for a per≈øonall E≈øtate becau≈øe he makes an E≈øtate title or Intere≈øt to him≈øelfe, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed in M ‚Ä¢ ch. 13. Car.

Gerrard contra Deering, becau≈øe a Prohibition to ≈øtay ≈øuit in the Court of Reque≈øts prefers a Bill, and de≈øires Depo≈øitions
in that Court to be u≈øed, Pa≈øch. 1. Car.
To di≈ø≈øolve a Contract of Marriage. Bateman contra Wells, a Bill to di≈ø≈øolve a Contract of Matriage, and to have Bond up, becau≈øe the woman denies to have him, Hillar. 8. Car.

How far a man mu≈øt An≈øwer. Cotton contra Fo≈øter, the Plaintiffe preferrs his Bill to have the Defendant an≈øwer, whether the Contract was to receive more moneys for Intere≈øt then warranted, Demurred unto, but over-ruled, and if found that the Defendant lent it without con≈øideration, then to take the forfeiture in 25. Eliz. fo. 15.

Wal≈øh contra Mar≈øhall, a Bill upon a Recognizance, the Defendant pleads the Statute of U≈øuric, and the ≈øame is in≈øufficient, Ordered to put in ≈øuch a Plea as hee will ≈øtand unto, 25. Eliz. li. B. fo. 28.

Vpon an Action of the ca≈øe after a tryall referred again thither, but re≈øerving equitie. Mallery contra Vintner, a Bill to be relieved upon an Action of the ca≈øe upon an Accompt, after a Verdict, Judgement, and Execution at Law, referred againe to law, becau≈øe a Verdict pa≈ø≈øed upon the Oath of one Vintner, who was thought not to have dealt fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ly at the tryall, and after, the cau≈øe referred to this Court for Equitie, Hill. 15. Car.

Of the nature of conformitie. Muffet contra Crack-place, the Defendant and two more, ordered to conforme them≈øelves to an agreement of other
Creditors. 11. Iac. li. A. fo. 104.
Many Plaintiffs in one Bill for ≈øeverall cau≈øes, and much di≈øliked. Bri≈øtow and Parker in 1590.

div.head: Bonds.
div.p: Bonds antient to be cancelled. Garford contra Humble, Antient Bonds put in ≈øuit, ordered to be cancelled, about Mich. 16. Jac. 169.
Mon≈øon contra Betti≈øon. ≈øimile in 5. Car.
For Tobacco cancelled. Hubber≈øtie contra Dumethalls, Bonds entred into for Tobacco here cancelled, Mich. 11, Jac.

Put in ≈øuit ordered not to proceed. Pearcy cantra Bardolfe, the Defendant ≈øeeks to put a Bond in ≈øuit again≈øt the Plaintiffe, having married ≈øhe that promi≈øed not to marry without the con≈øent of friends. Ordered not to proceed in 32. Eli. li. A. fo. 21 3.

Relea≈øed by the Father taken in the ≈øons names good. Simonds contra Lomley, Bonds relea≈øed by the Father, which he had taken in the names of his ≈øons being Infants, thought good and allowed in Hillar. 20. Jac.
Entred into by menaces, &c cancelled. Watts contra Lock, 4. Car. Bonds cancelled which have been entred into per Menaces threats, and Impri≈øonments.
Othy con' Daniel, point of co≈øenage bonds cancelled & concerning wares, in 5 Ca. li. B.
For re≈øigning a Benefice Wood con' Berry concerning Bonds given for re≈øigning a Benefice Me Lord Keepers di≈øtinction concerning Simony in Trin. Car. 6. li. B. fo. 653.
Snell contra Still, concerning Bonds to pre≈øent to a Benefice, M. 3, Car.

For payment of mony and a relea≈øe made all in one day relieved. Topp cont' Roberts, Mich. 12. Car. li, A. fo. 66. the Defendant would avoyd the payment of money upon a Bond, becau≈øe the Plaintiff made a Relea≈øe the ≈øame day after the Bond entred into, relieved here.
Wynne contra Swayn, & Man con' Ham, Bonds entred into for performance of an Award, upon non-performance ≈øued, yet ≈øtayd by Injunction, 6. Car. li. B.
Lever cont' Ar≈øents, 6. Car. li. B. Bonds entred into for fees, & Lords favors cancelled.

Mi≈øtaken, no advantage. Col≈øton con'Carr. a Mi≈øno≈ømer in a Bond no advantage to be taken, 11. Mai ‚Ä¢
33. Eliz.
A voluntary bond entred into cancelled. Wright cont' Moore, 7. Car. A voluntary Bond of 1000. l entred into for no con≈øideration, cancelled in the pre≈øence of Judges.
Arle≈øton contra Kent, Bonds entred into for procuring a Marriage, cancelled Febr. 17. Jac. For procuring marriages cancelled.
Gotts contra Gib≈øon, Feb. 10. Jac. An Injunction awarded.
Wi≈øeman contra Pa≈øcell, the Bond brought into Court, 3. Car.
For fir≈øt fruits one delivered up. Trobridges ca≈øe, 9. Car. Two bonds for fir≈øt fruits entred into, the fir≈øt mu≈øt be delivered up.

Forfeited, and after the money tendred, no u≈øe from that time allowed. Malton contra Pennell, 12. Car. though a Bond be forfeited and money tendred afterwards
≈øhall be allowed no u≈øe after the tender.

Dom. Cavendi≈øh contra Forth, Bonds entred into in 22. Eliz, becau≈øe it was not inventoried,Antient to be delivered, up and cancelled. and ≈øome money proved to bee paid to the Te≈øtator, it was conceived the money was all paid, and the Bonds decreed to be delivered up.

For performance of Covenants mi≈øtaken, cancelled. Ti≈ødall contra Danvers, a Covenant that a Meadow was haimeable at May day, and a Bond for performance of Covenants, that the Meadow was haimeable at April, the Bond was put in ≈øuite upon that Covenant, decreed to be cancelled, in 10. Jac. li. A. fo. 231.
Without u≈øe by the Father, the Son ≈øhall have none. Archer contra Bartlet, in 10 Car. where the Bond is made without u≈øe by the Father, the ≈øonne ≈øhall be concluded.
Voluntary. Bridges contra Wimbleton, concerning a voluntary Bond entred into, 10. Car.

Entred into to procure a Pardon. Mainwayring contra James, & Moie, concerning Bonds entred into, to procure a pardon, the Bill and An≈øwer expre≈ø≈øeth the Bonds to be without any con≈øideration, and no per≈øonall E≈øtate to ≈øatisfie, and how farr the pardon ≈øhall take away the civill Action of another, and the Lord Keepers Declaration, if a man enters into a Bond for payment of a ≈øumme certain, at a day certaine, the Obligee ≈øhall not be put to prove the Bond in Novemb. 1629.

div.head: Broccage.
div.p: Broccage of Citizens and Gentlemen. Sands contra Gre≈øhall, the great cau≈øe concerning young Gentlemen being brought in by Londoners. Hill 31. or 32. Eliz.

div.head: Cattell Tythable.
div.p: What manner of cattell tithable. Southby contra Meere. 5. or 6. Car. concerning what manner of Cattell are tithable.

div.head: Charitable u≈øes.
div.p: Money given to a charitable u≈øe decreed with damages. Seymor contra Pauperes de Twiford, Money long ≈øince given to a charitable u≈øe, decreed with Intere≈øt, Trin. 1634.
Wolrich contra Inhabitant de Frempton, Charitable u≈øes upon the ≈øtatute of 43. Eliz.
Burford contra Pauperes de Sudbury, Trin. 5. Car.
Slater cont' Phillips, concerning a charitable u≈øe, and the Judges Certificate upon the ≈øtatute of 43. Eliz. 5. Car. & Mich. 2. Car.

Charitable u≈øes when confirmed by Lord Keeper not to be altred, and the Lord Keepers power. Pauperes de Ea≈øt-Green≈øteed contra Howard, My Lord declared, that when he had altered or confirmed the Decree made upon the ≈øtatute of 43. Eliz. the Decree is to bee perpetuall, and then to remain in the Pettibagg, and it is in his power to make a Decree good, which is defective in 8. Car. & 10 how far a Purcha≈øer ≈øhall be bound.

Hungate experte Inhabitant de Shorhorne
3. Car. A debt which is a charitable u≈øe in Action, was given for the erection of a Schoole, and this was a good appointment within this law.

Steward contra Jermyn, 41. Eliz. when a Donor appoints lands or goods to be ≈øold for to maintain a charitable u≈øe, and doth not appoint by whom the ≈øale ≈øhall be made by ≈øuch as the Commi≈ø≈øioers ≈øhall appoint.
Hellams Trin. 5. Car. a devi≈øe to the Company of Leather-≈øellers London, for a charitable u≈øe, was holden a good devi≈øe.
2. Jac. lands in Grates-Inne-lane, given to build a Schoole at Rugby in Com' Warr', the Commi≈ø≈øioners did ≈øit at Rugbie to enquire, and held not good.
Wingfield 4. Car. Mony was given for the good of the Church of Dale, and this was ruled good upon the≈øe generall words.
Ken≈øham 41. Eliz. that a Copihold may be charged with a charitable u≈øe.

Goff contra Webb, 44. Eliz. upon the Will of one Hunt, of the Lea≈øe of the Rectory of Haines in the County of Wilts, it was re≈øolved by Egerton and Popham, that a devi≈øe of money be di≈øtributed to twenty of the poore≈øt of his kindred, ≈øhall be a good devi≈øe, notwith≈øtanding it doth not appeare that he had any poore kindred.

Champion contra Smith, 3. Jacobi, one
Ridley being ≈øei≈øed of Copyhold lands in Barking in E≈ø≈øex, did devi≈øe that the Par≈øon and Church-wardens in Thames-≈øtreet London, and foure hone≈øt men of that Pari≈øh, ≈øhould ≈øell the land, and employ the money for the poore and charitable u≈øes in that Pari≈øh. And it was objected that the devi≈øe was voyd, becau≈øe the Par≈øon and Church-wardens were not a Corporation to take land out of London, nor to ≈øell it for ≈øuch u≈øes, but it was decreed that the devi≈øe was good, and that they had a good Authority to ≈øell the ≈øame.

Stoddard 20. Jacobi, who devi≈øed by paroll a yearly rent of 10. pounds per annum for ever, out of his hou≈øe called the Swanne with two necks, in the old Jury London, for the maintenance of two ≈øchollers in Oxford and Cambridge, and willed that Hugh le Scrivenor ≈øhould put it into writing, which he did accordingly; And this was found by Inqui≈øition, and decreed.

And it was objected, that the Devi≈øe was not good, for that a Rent could not be devi≈øed by a Will Nuncupative, but the Decree was confirmed to be good, for a Rent may be created and granted without Deed in ca≈øe of a Petition, much more for a charitable u≈øe.

Hire contra Cordall, Pa≈øch. 4. Jac. upon
the Will of one Thomp≈øon, who being ≈øeized of lands in London, did devi≈øe that it ≈øhould be ≈øold after the death of his Wife, for Daughters Portions, and made his Wife his Executrix, and it was ruled, that the Executors of his Wife might ≈øell, for land in London devi≈øable by Cu≈øtome before the Statute of Wills, but it was doubted that it had been of lands not devi≈øable by Cu≈øtome.

Major & Burgen≈øis de Reading contra Lane, in 43. Eliz. A devi≈øe to the poore people maintained in the Ho≈øpitall in the Pari≈øh of Saint Laurence in Reading for ever, Exception was taken that the poore were not capable by that name for no Corporation, yet becau≈øe the Plaintiffe was capable to take lands in Mortmaine, and did govern the Ho≈øpitall; It was decreed the Defendant ≈øhould a≈ø≈øure the lands to the Major and Burge≈ø≈øes for the maintenance of the ≈øaid Ho≈øpitall.

Sir Thomas Middleton, Hillar. 15. Jac. The Ma≈øter and Mariners in a voyage to Sea, agreed that a ratable proportion ≈øhould be deducted out of their wages, for reliefe of ≈øuch ≈øeafaring men, as ≈øhould be maymed at Sea, and Sir Thomas Middleton (being Trea≈øurer for the Navy, Anno 1590.) had paid their wages, and deteyned this money
for the maymed ≈øea-faring men, and not paid it, and although no certain particular men could claime it, yet he was adjudged to accompt for it by this Law.

Major Bri≈øtoll contra Whitton, 9. Car. A man devi≈øeth by his Will, moneys to a charitable u≈øe, to be be≈øtowed for poore people, and the re≈øidue of his goods to be employed to ≈øuch u≈øes as his Fecoffecs ≈øhall thinke meet, Devi≈øe is good, though it be devi≈øed to a Corporation, &c. in 8. & 9. Car. Two Judges Certificate afterwards.

Fi≈øher contra Hill, when no u≈øe is mentioned or directed in a Deed, it ≈øhall be decreed to the u≈øe of the poore, and the Feoffement being made to Gentlemen out of the Towne, ≈øought to bee avoyded, becau≈øe it ought to be the Towne≈ømen onely, Decreed in 10. Iac. li. B. fo. 238.
E≈øtcot contra Cooke & Mannington, in Mich. 15. Car.
Allen contra Cooke Mich. 14. Car.

Peacocke contra Thewer, M. 14. Car. If lands be given to a charitable u≈øe, to di≈øpo≈øe an overplus, if the Purcha≈øor had no notice, cannot bind him, but if rent i≈ø≈øue out of land, the Purcha≈øor mu≈øt pay it, but will not charge him to pay arrerages before purcha≈øe, nor lay it upon one, nor excu≈øe the other.
Man≈øell contra Middleton in Mich. 14. Car.
Penniman contra Iennings, Lands given to Church-wardens, voyd in law, decreed hereabout, 2. Car.

Pember contra Inhabitant de Kington, Whether money given to maintain a preaching Mini≈øter bee a charitable u≈øe, the Lord Keeper, and the Judges did decree (notwith≈øtanding it is not warranted by the Statute to be a charitable u≈øe) that the ≈øame ≈øhall be paid by the Executor to ≈øuch maintenance, in Trin. 15. Car.

Pen≈øterd contra Pavier, A. Devi≈øeth 20 pounds per annum, to a preaching Mini≈øter, dyes, leaving lands and A≈ø≈øets, the Defendant will not pay it accordingly, the Court with the Judges chargeth her out of the A≈ø≈øets, to buy lands to perpetuate it in Trin. 15 Car. ≈øhee having but a third part of the lands, and ≈øo ought not to bee chargeable with any more.

Bramble contra, Pauperes de Havering, Feme covert makes a will of 30 ≈øhillings per annum to a charitable u≈øe, out of ≈øome of her own lands and (though an Award) it ≈øhall be paid; and Bonds given to performe the ≈øame, yet the Heiro is not bound to performe the ≈øame in Trin. 15. Car.

Windfor contra Pauperes de Farnham,
whether after appearance upon exceptions, the Decree may be revived in Pa≈øch. 2. Car.

div.head: Cho≈øe in Action.
div.p: Cho≈øe in Action good in this Court. Burrell contra Siday, a Devi≈øe out of a Cho≈øe in Action, good in this Court, in 3. Car. li. B. fo. 792,
Roch contra Guntur, A≈ø≈øignee of Cho≈øe in action, in Mich. 15. Car.

A≈ø≈øigned and di≈øpo≈øition of things by a feme Covert.
Greenvile contra Com' Suff. concerning a≈ø≈øigning of Cho≈øe in Action, and di≈øpo≈øition of things by a Feme Covert, in li. A. fo. 5. Car.
Georges contra Chancey, Mich'. 15. Car. Greenvile contra Cutteford in Hill' 1632.

A≈ø≈øignable by this Court. Seaten contra Ferrers, concerning the a≈ø≈øigning of money decreed in li. B. 22. Jac. and a ≈øecond Purcha≈øer ordered to pay the money, although but cho≈øe in Action, and not privy to the A≈ø≈øignement.

div.head: Colluder.
div.p: One Colluder to bring in another. Forth, to bring in Mary Dick with whom he colluded, The Lord Audley and 32. & 33. Eliz.

div.head: Common.
div.p:
Common. A Commi≈ø≈øion to di≈øtingui≈øh bounds & meats. Magi≈øter & ≈øocietat' Chri≈øt-Church in Cambridge contra Martin, The Bill concerning title of Common, and the Court Awards a Commi≈ø≈øion for the di≈øtingui≈øhing
the Meats and Bounds in 32. Eliz. li. A. fo. 207.
Sands contra. Beale, in Pa≈øch. 20. Jac. fo. 866.
Determined here and ≈øtinting of cattell. Tenants of Do≈øthorpe contra Loveday, point of Common determined here in 33 Eliz. fo. 400. li. B.
Raremeadow contra Beacle, and ≈øtinting of Cattell in Nov. 7. Jac.
French contra Eyer, in 33. Eliz. concerning Comons, Walts, and Cu≈øtomes.
Cockaine contra Dom. Howard, for Apportionment of Common 9. Car.
Goodman contra Wood, This Court determines the liberty of Foldage and Pa≈øture, and what number of ≈øheep ≈øhall bee kept, 21. Jac.
Hartley contra Dively, a Bill here for common of Pa≈øture for him and his Tenants, and comon of Turbary in the wa≈øt grounds in a Mannor allowed here, in 33. Eliz. fo. 192.

After tryall at law a Commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øet forth CoÃÑ mon. Lamott contra Hitch, Whether a common for ≈øheep lyes now in the Pari≈øh of Melborne or Folmer, though ≈øent to Law, yet re≈øerving Equitie, to th'end a Commi≈ø≈øion may be awarded to ≈øet it out in 14. Car.

To be according to the plow land, and Cottages not to be excepted. Sewell contra F ‚Ä¢ nch, findes that the Town hath had alwaies Common, and many Deeds ≈øpeake of u≈øe and tru≈øt, the Court
adjudgeth the Common to be according to the plow-land and Cottages not to be excepted, but to have a proportionable rate in 2. Car.

Pre≈øcription of Common how farre relieved. By lawes for ≈øtinting of Common di≈ømi≈ø≈øed. Tucker contra Copple≈øton, becau≈øe the Plaintiffe could not pre≈øcribe any Title of Commoning in the Wa≈øts, no Reliefe, in Pa≈øch. 15. Car.
Mole contra Mole, An Agreement between Town≈ømen concerning ≈øtinting and re≈øtrayning cattell, and other Orders in the Fields, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed in 15. Car.

div.head: Commi≈ø≈øions.
div.p: Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øpeciall to private per≈øons. Cage contra Elrington, a ≈øpeciall Commi≈ø≈øion to private per≈øons to apprehend one in contempt, and to bring him to the Fleet, Trin. 3. Jac.
Of Rebellion. The parties ≈øhall be bayled if good Sureties be offered, or el≈øe they ≈øhall be ≈øued about 37. & 38. Eliz.
For po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Becau≈øe the Defendant had ≈øet out all Proces of contempt, 1. Ed. 6. fo. 144. or 244.
Another for Law≈øon, 37. H. 8.
Evans crontra Bingham, 30. Eliz.
Brereton contra Young, about 33. Eliz. Commi≈ø≈øion to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and apprehend the contemners.
Brocas contra Savage, To put the Defendant in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

Wildgo≈ø≈øe contra Ragland, 36. Eliz. Becau≈øe the Defendant ≈øtood out all Proces of contempt for not An≈øwering, the Bill was taken pro confe≈ø≈øe, Denton Mill' was Plaintiffe contra Brown in Pa≈øch. 11. Jac. li. A. fo. 736.
Another between Comes Oxon contra Gouch about 13. Jac. fo. 104.
Comes Hertford contra Gerrard, becau≈øe the Defendant would not An≈øwer the Plaintiffes Bill, it was taken pro confe≈ø≈øo, 10. Jac. li. A. fo. 371.
Devoreux contra Stephens, Maij 11. Jac. fo. 632.
To examine wa≈øts. Po≈øhall contra Reresby, A commi≈ø≈øion to examine Wa≈øts in 12. Jac. li. B. fo. 74.

Sacheverell contra Sacheverell, One of the Commi≈ø≈øioners letting the Defendant e≈øcape, being taken upon a Commi≈ø≈øion of Rebellion, was to ≈øtand committed to Pri≈øon, till hee brings in the Defendant in Hillar. 18. Jac.

To prove whether a child be legittimate. A Commi≈ø≈øion out of this court, to prove whether a child be legittimate, Cre≈ø≈øey contra Hull, Pa≈øch. 11. & 12. Eliz. li. A. fo. 130. The contrary in 22. Jac. inter Hobby & Smith.
Townley contra Clench, or Clench contra Townley, about 40. Eliz.

To ≈øet out lands for payment of debts. Mullineux contra Mullineux, the Court orders that a Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øhall goe forth to ≈øet out lands that lye promi≈øcuou≈øly to be lyable for payment of debts, in Feb. or Jan. 14. Jac. li. B. fo. 427.

To ≈øet out Coppyhold land from Freehold lands Peckering contra Kimpton, a Commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øet out Coppyhold land from free land which lye ob≈øcured, if the Commi≈ø≈øioners cannot ≈øever it, then to ≈øet out ≈øo much in lieu thereof, in Mich. or Hill. 5. Car.
Lovelace contra Coffin, whether a Commi≈ø≈øion to An≈øwer and examine Witne≈ø≈øes, may in one be concluded,To prove Cu≈øtomes but parties intere≈ø≈øed not to be examined. 9. Car.
Hopton contra Higgins, a Commi≈ø≈øion awarded to prove cu≈øtomes, but parties intere≈ø≈øed ≈øhall not be examined as Witne≈ø≈øes in 10. Jac. li. B. fo. 309.

After CoÃÑ mi≈ø≈øion an examiner to goe down to examine. Bartley contra Eyre, where a Commi≈ø≈øion is awarded to Commi≈ø≈øioners to examine Witne≈ø≈øes, and they cannot agree, or where there is an undue carriage, or the Commi≈ø≈øioners great, or Witne≈ø≈øes old, the Court awards an Examiner to goe down into the country in 1 Augu≈øti, 41. Eliz.
Maton contra Culpepper, 25 April, 15 Eliz.
Stampe contra Clarke in Iune 32. Eliz.

div.head: Commi≈ø≈øioners.
div.p:
Commi≈ø≈øioners. Nel≈øon contra Yelverton, Commi≈ø≈øioners upon a Commi≈ø≈øion of Rebellion, letting
the partie in contempt goe where hee li≈øted, ordered to be committed till they pay the the debt, in Trin. 18. Jac.
The like between Sacheverell and Sacheverell.
Morgan contra Bowdler, Commi≈ø≈øioners to be examined upon occa≈øion of partialitie and practi≈øe, 9. Car.
Norton contra Hodgetts, Trin. Car. 5.

div.head: Commitment.
div.p: Commitment, one delivered, and after apprehended and committed. Bra≈øier & Cro≈ø≈øe, in 39. & 46. Eliz. Wheatley contra St. John, the Husband and Wife committed in 38. Eliz. li. A. fo. 63.
S ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ ope and Steward, the Defendant ≈øhut up clo≈øe in the Kings Bench, and not to have Habeas Corpus.
Pope contra Newmon, aut aliter, in Mich. 22. Jac. committed to Bridewell.
Husband and Wife committed. Cutler contra Barber, the Defendant to ≈øtand committed, till his wife be examined upon Interrog. 9. Jac. li. A. fo. 787.

Walker contra Arderne, It was Decreed, that if the per≈øonall E≈øtate of the parties would not pay all debts, that a Lea≈øe ≈øhould be ≈øold for the payment thereof, and that the Defendant and his Wife were committed, becau≈øe they refu≈øed, in 13. & 14. Eliz, l. B. fo. 70.

Partridge contra Partridge, a man committed
One committed for terrifying a witne≈ø≈øe.for terrifying a Witne≈ø≈øe, which is to be examined at a Commi≈ø≈øion in. Trin. 15. Car.

div.head: Contribution.
div.p: Contribution of a Bond. Parkhur≈øt contra Bathur≈øt, Contribution of a Bond in Mich. or Hillar. 5. Car.
Peter contra Davis, in Hillar. 5. Car.
Fleetwood contra Charnock, ≈øureties compelled to contribute for payment of debt upon a Joynt Bond in Pa≈øch. 5. Car.
Wilcox contra Dom. Dun≈ømore, A Demurrer put in upon point of Contribution, over-ruled, 12. Car.
Hall contra Offley, how far the Court will re≈øtraine a Lord to di≈øtraine for rent where he plea≈øeth in Mich. 3. Car. But for the pre≈øent thinkes fit, that there ≈øhould be a Contribution.

div.head: Contempt.
div.p: Cotempt.A Defendant at contempt and pardoned, the Plaintiffe was inforced to ≈øerve a new Subpen ‚Ä¢ , to doe that which was fir≈øt ordered. Young contra Chamberlaine, Trin. 37. Eliz.
One Witne≈ø≈øe ≈øufficient to prove a contempt. Sands contra Knighton, one witne≈ø≈øe ≈øufficient to prove a contempt in Mich. or Hillar. 13. Car.

div.head: Conveyance.
div.p:
Conveyance.The Plaintiffe (depending the ≈øuit) conveys over his Intere≈øt but in tru≈øt, and yet
the Court would hold no longer in his name, Hill. Contra Portman 1584.

Lands conveyed away by an Ideot holpen for him in Remainder. Ru≈øhloy contra Mansfield, lands conveyed away by an Ideot, by Fine holpen for him in Remainder, being in Fee again≈øt a Purcha≈øor, and concerning notice al≈øo, Trin. 10. Jac. fo. 119. or 1190. li. B.

A re≈øtraint from making a Conveyance to children by a ≈øecond venter. Ayloff contra Ayloff, the Court re≈øtrains the Defendant from making any conveyance to his children by a ≈øecond Wife, to di≈ø-inherit the Plaintiffe being his Grandchild and Heire, and concerning a promi≈øe, in Trin. 12. Jac. li. B. fo. 1040.

One ≈øeeks to avoyd a Conveyance for want of Livery. Conque≈øt contra Newdigate, the Defendant ≈øeeks to avoyd a conveyance for want of Livery, yet holpen, and Common and Farmes whether parcell of the Mannor, was ≈øought to be avoyded by unitie of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, yet decreed here in Mich. or Hillar. 9. Jac. li. B. fo. 604.
Finches Ca≈øe, in Trin. 41. Eliz.

Conveyance in tru≈øt to Infants being after indebted, inabled to ≈øel the lands to pay debts. Grant contra Edes, the Plaintiffe made a Conveyance to Feoffees in tru≈øt, to the u≈øe of his ≈øons being Infants, with ≈øeverall remainders over, the Plaintiffe being after indebted, the Court inables him to convey and ≈øell tho≈øe lands, in Hillar. 18. Jac. li. B. fo. 758.

Lewis contra Vaughan, the Plaintiffe being ≈øimple, the Defendant got a Conveyance
Of lands was obteyned the Plaintiffe being ≈øimple rea≈ø≈øured.from him, of his lands, and although the land was ≈øold to Purcha≈øors, and a di≈øcent, yet the Plaintiffe had the land rea≈ø≈øured to him in 4. Jac. li. B. fo. 835.
Pla≈øted contra Algood, whether (a Conveyance in tru≈øt) a man may di≈øpo≈øe of the ≈øame by will, or otherwi≈øe, in 4, Car.
Dom. Buck contra Paul, in Mich. 5. Car. This is concerning an Office.
Moreton contra Briggs, a Conveyance ≈øought to be a voyded for want of livery, relieved, Hill. 16. Jac.

To tru≈øtees by the Wife before marriage to u≈øe, who ≈øells the ≈øame, though the hu≈øband joyn ≈øhall not prejudice the wife. Fitz-James contra Hir≈øley, a Widow before Marriage, makes a Conveyance to the u≈øe of her ≈øelfe to friends, becau≈øe her Husband ≈øhall not have benefit, the Tru≈øtees a≈ø≈øigne this Lea≈øe to one for valuable con≈øideration, and though the Husband joyne, ≈øhall not prejudice her, but becau≈øe the A≈ø≈øignee came in upon a valuable con≈øideration, ≈øhall keep it till he receive all disbur≈øments, and the Wife to have benefit of the ≈øame, 32. & 33. Eliz. l. A. fo. 464.
Intru≈øt to u≈øes, needs no livery. Thomas contra Powell, a Conveyance in tru≈øt to u≈øes, needs no livery, and concerning Tenants in Common, in li. B. 6 Car.
Epi≈øcopus Heref. contra Bright & Barkley, A Conveyance made to avoyd a Ward≈øhip, decreed not to be given in Evidence in Mich. 6. Car.

In tru≈øt and after ≈øells the Inheritance. Dominus Roberts contra Lea, the Defendant makes a Conveyance in tru≈øt, and after ≈øells the Inheritance, the tru≈øt ≈øhall go in equitie to the Purcha≈øor, in 8. Car.
Lamplughs ca≈øe.

Defective for want of livery decreed. Paul contra Wilkins, Three Copartners, one for a valuable con≈øideration ≈øells this land but before Deed executed dyes, decreed again≈øt the Defendant, in Mich. 14. Car.
Defective intention ≈øupplyed. Cooke contra Cleere, though a Conveyance be defective, yet becau≈øe there was a full intention to make better a≈ø≈øurance, Decreed in 2. Car.

div.head: Corpus cum Cau≈øa
div.p: Corpus cumcau≈øa. Subpena Compl' quia Def't. pro≈øecutus e≈øt per Billam Midd'. Ward contra Mar≈øton, 36. H. 8. fo. 125.

div.head: Coppihold.
div.p: Coppyhold. Severance from the Mannor hurts not, Gunn contra Buckma≈øter, 21. & 22. Eliz. li. A. fo. 360.
Lands which had gone Fifty years allowed, till recovered by Law, Trin. 27. Eliz. fo. 630. li. A. Ba≈øpoole contra Roberts.
The like 21. Eliz. between Wrayford and Carew, for lands enjoyed 60 yeares as Copihold, li. A. fo. 232.

Lands which had gone but five years as
Coppihold of Inheritance, allowed.

Trin. 26. Eliz. li. B. fo. 757. between Radcliff and Raunce, (though a Mannor) ≈øome Coppiholds were but for life, and ≈øome of Inheritance, and in 22. & 23. Eliz. Fifty yeares po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion allowed, between Freeman and Penny.
A Coppihold granted at a Court kept out of the Mannor, confirmed again≈øt the Lord which made it, Marke contra Sulyard, 25. Eliz.

The Father commits a Forfeiture and dyeth, the ≈øon is admitted as heire by di≈øcent, this purgeth not the forfeiture, becau≈øe the Father dying ≈øei≈øed of no E≈øtate, the ≈øonne cannot be admitted to any, Smith contra
_____ 30. Eliz.

An admi≈ø≈øion by the Lord, di≈øpen≈øeth with a former forfeiture, as it was held between Clerke & Wentworth about 35. Eliz. The Father committed a forfeiture, the lord neverthele≈ø≈øe ≈øeized a Herriot upon his death, and yet would avoyd the heires e≈øtate for that forfeiture, which he could not, becau≈øe the taking of a Herriot, alloweth of a dying ≈øeized. Bacon contra Thurley, Hillar. 1592.

A ≈øuit to compell a Lord to grant a Lycence to let a Coppihold, but becau≈øe the Defendant ≈øaid by this An≈øwer, that the
Coppihold was forfeited, this court would not inforce him to grant a Lycence, till the forfeiture was examined, Bullard contra Agard, about 1592.

Ju≈øtice Clench fuit D'opinion en ca≈øe inter Commin & King≈ømell & ≈øe Copiholder pri≈øt mari≈øme ≈øives lycence &c. ce' imploy ≈øur ≈øon Cu≈øtomary allowei' Dee' releeve in equit ie, payant un competent fine, in 1591.
A Copiholder can have no A≈ø≈øize of Common again≈øt his Lord, but is to be relieved in equitie, The Tenants of Petworth, and the Earle of Northumberland, in 38. & 39. Eliz.
Common for Copiholders and terminors is to be relieved here, Colcot contra Lea. 43. Eliz. & 38. & 39. Eliz.
Rich contra Erth, Judges of opinion, that a Tenant out of the court cannot take a ≈øurrender of a woman Covert, for that ≈øhee is ≈øecretly to be examined by the Steward in 38. Eliz. li. A. fo. 420.

div.head: Co≈øts.
div.p: Co≈øts.No co≈øts for a contempt di≈øcharged by the generall pardon, 27. Eliz. Fulwood contra Fulwood.

The Defendant not being ≈øerved with Proces, found the cau≈øe ≈øet down for hearing, and attended, and was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with co≈øts, becau≈øe the Plaintiffe was not ready,
Clayton contra Leigh, 15. Eliz.
Brothers contra Ringro≈ø≈øe, Pa≈øch. 25. Eliz.
Brown & North contra Grove, in 36. & 37. Eliz.
A matter put to compromi≈øe to be ended by, &c. before the returne of the Subpena, it was not ended, the Defendant got Co≈øts for want of a Bill, and yet not di≈øcharged. Slater contra Finch, 1596.
The Plaintiffe allowed 20 l co≈øts. Creditors ordered to take low rates. Coles contra Champneys, the Plaintiffe is allowed co≈øts in 7. Car.

div.head: Creditors.
div.p: Creditors are ordered to compound with their Debtors, for to take a ≈ømall rate in the hundred. Maldmay contra Wentworth, Mach. 11. Jac. committed for ≈øuing a Surety.
Bret contra Shurley, in Pa≈øch. 2. Car. For good of Creditors.

div.head: Court Rolls.
div.p: Court rolls, to ≈øhew which is Copyhold, and which Freehold. Corbet contra Pe≈øhall, ordered that Court-Rolls ≈øhall be brought and ≈øhewed to coun≈øell, to ≈øhew which is Coppihold, and which is free-hold, in 12. Jac. li. A.

div.head: Covenant.
div.p:
Covenant to levy a Fine. B. Covenants to levy a Fine to P. of lands given in Marriage with his Daughter at a day, by negligence of payment, the Daughter being dead, P. pa≈ø≈øed away the lands to Purcha≈øors, but B. ordered to an
E≈øtate of 100 Marks, Hillar. 15. Jac. li. A.

Relieved in equitie after time expired. Tun≈øtall contra La≈ø≈øells, one Covenants and enters into Bond for di≈øcharging of Incumbrances within a time, none ≈øtirred within that time, untill afterwards, how far ≈øhall bind. A ca≈øe to be made 2. Car.
Ill penned ≈øupplyed. Vanlore contra Bartlet, A Bill to be relieved of a Covenant ill penned, demurred unto, but in regard of ≈øome precedent Agreement, over-ruled to An≈øwer, Mich. 3. Car.

div.head: Councellours Clerke.
div.p: Councellors Clerk. Breame contra Breame, the Councellours Clerke not to be examined in the cau≈øe, 13. & 14. Eliz. fo. 93.
Lee contra Markham, the Councell of the parties cau≈øe, not to be examined in the ≈øame cau≈øe, 11. Eliz. li, A. fo. 17.
Thimblethorpe contra Thimblethorpe, the like in li. B. 6. Car.

div.head: Cu≈øtomes.
div.p: Cu≈øtomes. Cu≈øtomes referred to Law.
A≈øtill cont' Danvers, No, 30. Eliz. fo. 236.
Lort contra Hutchin, Maij 18. Eliz. li. B. fo. 1344.
Maning & al' tenen' de, _____ contra Ep' Worr' ≈øibi & ≈øuis, made an E≈øtate of Inheritance, & contra Fines, 34. Eliz. li. A. fo. 826.
Michelborne contra Fines 27 Junij. 33. Eliz.
Binxie contra Smith, two yeares and a halfe value in Hill' 12 Jac.
Weedon contra Stepney, in 28. Eliz. li. A. fo. 327. if any Tenant ≈øhould goe about to defraud the Lord of the Mannor, then hee to pay a yeare and a halfe more.
Tenants de _____ contra Arm≈øtrong, one yeares value and not above, to be paid in 40. Eliz. li. B. fo. 595.
Corbet contra Tenants de Beanni≈øter in Mich terme, 21. Jac. halfe a years value.
Stafford contra Pa≈øch. in Mich. & Hill' 15. Jac.
Parker cont' Ten' de Eatmi≈øter in Mich. 21. Jac.
Sterling contra Tenants of Burton, a Compo≈øition formerly made between Lords and Tenants ought to bind a Purcha≈øor or an heire, ≈øo decreed in Octob. 40 Eliz. li. A. fo. 434.
Pincheon contra Keeling, whether Fines be Arbitrable or not, determined here, and how to a≈øcertaine them in 9, Car.
Cu≈øtome certaine proved di≈ømi≈ø≈øed. Wingfield contra Bedford, in 38. Eliz. Cu≈øtome proved of 16 pence an Acre for Tythe of Wood, and no Wood in kind, yet the Court would not decree a Cu≈øtome.
The opinion of the Court is of advi≈øe contrary to the cu≈øtome of London.

Nicholas contra Dutton, 32. Eliz. li. A.
fo. 677. the Plaintiffe had two ≈øonnes and two Daughters, if the one Daughter dyed before twentie one, or Marriage, devi≈øed by Will, th'other ≈øhould have her full part, after the Defendant marrying the Survivor, was promi≈øed to have both Portions, and made Joynture accordingly, now the ≈øonnes were preferred in the Fathers life, the Will is voyd in that point, becau≈øe by Cu≈øtome they ≈øhould have a part.
Cu≈øtome in London, and promi≈øe in London wil not hold. A Decree in Bacons ca≈øe of the like.

Hall contra Lumley, a verball promi≈øe in London will not hold, and therefore to an≈øwer here to that in 11. Car. and in Nov. 13. Car. Decreed to bee good here between tho≈øe parties, and concerning a Child preferred in Marriage, ≈øhall come afterwards into the Orphans Court.
Gebo ne contra Dutton; the Cu≈øtome of London whether a child preferred in lifetime of his Father, ≈øhall after decea≈øe goe into hotchpott, an order in it 41. Eliz. li. A.
Knivet contra Freeman, becau≈øe the Bill is for the manner and cu≈øtome of Tything, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, in 10. Jac. li. B. fo. 322.

Carter contra Bateman, Trin. 6. Car. concerning the Cu≈øtome of London, how
farre a Mortgage ≈øhall bee put into the ≈øtate.
Greleeves contra Pope, the que≈øtion is, whether the Lord of a Mannor, can by the Cu≈øtome of a Mannor, grant a Rever≈øion for lives, decreed here upon view of the Court Rolls, 31. Ian. 9. Jac.
Topp contra Topp, Deeds of gift made to defraud the Plaintiffe of her cu≈øtomary E≈øtate of London, adjudged voyd, in 40. Eliz. li. A. fo. 522.
Page contra Page, a Decree concerning the Cu≈øtome of the Province of Yorke, in 13 Car. li. B. fo. 51.
Morris contra Evans, about 5. Car.
Boice contra Wilkin≈øon, and concerning other Cu≈øtomes, in Mich. 10. Car.

Carter contra Maund, a Citizen of London, devi≈øeth 3000 l to his Wife and 3000. l to Orphans, and Legacies to divers others, pre≈øuming his E≈øtate to be greater then it was, Quere who ≈øhall ≈øu≈øtaine the lo≈ø≈øe, either the Legatees, or the Orphans ≈øhall abate, a Certificate in Septemb. 1626.
Hopton contra Simcotts, in Hillar. 14. Car.

div.head: Damages.
div.p:
Damage given for wa≈øt committed. Browne contra Dom' Bridges, Damages given to the Plaintiffe for Wa≈øtes committed by the Defendant, upon the Plaintiffs
woods, as much as hee was damnified, in 32. Eliz. li. B. fo. 838.
Blackenden contra Hidem, 6. Jac. li. A. fo. 915.
The like, Ha≈øtings contra Cooper, in Pa≈ø ‚Ä¢ . 4 Jac. And ordered that no antient Pa≈øture or Meadow ground ≈øhall be plowed, 3. Jac. li. B. fo. 652.

Damages allowed for childrens portions where no allowance by Will. Horton contra Long, where there is no Provi≈øion by a Will for maintenance, becau≈øe the Legacies to be paid after the debts, yet the Defendant allowed maintenance, and to accompt for the profits of the ≈øtate as long as it is in his cu≈øtody, in 2. Iac. li. B. fo. 807.
Barwick contra Barwick, Executors ordered to put in good ≈øecuritie to allow five pounds Per centum, for Education, and to make good their Portions, 44. Eliz. li. A.
Farrington contra Throckmorton, in Trin. 15. Jac. fo. 987. Mich. following, fo. 99. & 144.
Coriton in Mich. 21. Iac. fo. 37.
Birch contra Chambers, in Maij 11. Iac. fo. 686.
Argentie contra Young, in Nov. 37. Eliz.
Rol ‚Ä¢ contra May, 1. Car. not to put in Sureties.
Moul≈øon contra Moul≈øon, Trin. 16. Car.

div.head: Debt.
div.p: Debt upon word ≈øatisfied before others upon ≈øpecialty. Cole contra Ferrand, the Plaintiffe was ≈øatisfied of a debt upon word by order of Court before others upon ≈øpecialty, 3. Jac. li. B. fo. 238. & 241.

Vpon a Recognizance cannot be Attached in London.
Skeggs contra Smith, whether a Debt upon a Recognizance may be Attached in London or whether an Attachment made of a Debt in London, may be pleaded in bar of a Scire facias, upon a Recognizance in this Court, it hath been over-ruled, in law it cannot in 38. Eliz. li. A. fo. 431.

To be paid beyond the ≈øtatute of limitation A Debtor is made Executor, ≈øhall not drown the debt. concerning a mediat debt of Cu≈øtomers and Receivers, &c. Hal≈øted contra Little, Debts though beyond the Statute of limitations, ordered to be paid, becau≈øe directed to be paid by will Hill. 1632.
Askwith contra Chamberlaine, a man makes a Debtor Executor, there ≈øhall be no Extingui≈øhment, but it ≈øhall goe to the E≈øtate, Hill. 15. Car.
Englefield contra Nicholas, Lord Keepers Declaration of the Chancerie and Exchequer concerning the mediate Debt of a Cu≈øtomer, and Receiver to the King, and other matters, in Hill. 15, Car.

div.head: Deeds.
div.p: The court will not order the DefendaÃÑt to ≈øhew the Covenants or contents of his Lea≈øe or Deed. Salton≈øtall contra Wilbore, the Court would not order the Plaintiffe to ≈øee what Covenants, and ending of a Lea≈øe or Deed, Mich. Jac. li. B.
Dominus Darcy contra Allerton, A ≈øecond A≈ø≈øignement made without con≈øideration being in force, Decreed, 31. Iune 1631.

Two voluntary Deeds. Defective for want of Livery. Byden contra Loveden, the Defendant would avoyd an E≈øtate for want of Livery and ≈øeizin, but becau≈øe the Plaintiffe enjoyed twenty five years; It was Decreed he ≈øhould enjoy it quietly, 14. Iune 11. Iac. li. A.
Barrow contra Barrow, Mich. 2. Car. Upon a Deed for want of Livery or Attachment.
Dom. Darcie contra Allerton, two voluntary Deeds, the fir≈øt ≈øhall take place, unle≈ø≈øe the la≈øt be for payment of Debts, Hill. 7. Car.
Dominus Rex ordered that a Deed ≈øhall be inrolled, though it concernes lands in Scotland, or Ireland, 7. Car.

A ≈øleeping Deed of Intaile not favoured. Pountney contra Pilkington, where the Father conceives his land to be Freehold, gives part thereof to a younger ≈øonne, although an old ≈øleeping intaile be ≈øet on foot, ≈øhall not prejudice the younger ≈øonne, 18. Car.
Made in tru≈øt which take place. Singer contra Bennet, concerning two Deeds made in tru≈øt, which ≈øhall take place, in 8. Car.
Row contra Che≈ø≈øick, A Deed for want of Livery, in Mich. 13. Car.

Not inrolled, decreed again≈øt the heire onely. Paul contra Michell, a Deed not inrolled, decreed again≈øt the heire, but if any other E≈øtate challenged by ≈øurvivor≈øhip or other precedent E≈øtate, will not bind, in 14. Car.
Franck contra Reepe, how farre a Defendant ≈øhall be compelled to ≈øhew a Deed of Intaile, and to be examined upon Intergatories where the ≈øame is, Mich. 14. Car.
Pollard contra Hall, in 13. Car. & Morgan contra Morgan.

Vicecomes Rochford contra Lovell, the Plaintiffs Wife had a deed of gift or grant made to her of ≈øheep, and other per≈øonall E≈øtate, but kept the ≈øame ≈øtill in his owne hands, and alters the propertie and dyes, and makes the Defendant Executor, and the Te≈øtators goods which came to his hands farre more then the debt, though the goods were altered by the Te≈øtator, yet the goods which came to the Te≈øtators Plaintiffes hands, ≈øhall bee lyable in 3. Car. li. A. fo. 223.
Barkley contra Barkley, my Lords Declaration of a voluntary Deed, how far to hold or nor, in Hillar. 15. Car.

div.head: Decree.
div.p: Decree.IN the Judgement Roll of 36.37. and 38. H. 8. there is a Decree to be ≈øeen to the ‚Ä¢ o effect hereafter mentioned, where Daniel and the re≈øt of the Inhabitants of Crudworth, in the County of Warwick, exhibibited a Bill again≈øt Thomas Arderne for title of Common, and to have certaine inclo≈øed lands open. It was decreed that Ardern and his heires ≈øhould hold the ≈øame lands ≈øo inclo≈øed, di≈øcharged of the Common, becau≈øe it ≈øeemed that the Inhabitants had Common enough be≈øides, and that the laying open the lands called Martinmas Ley≈øe, would be a great decay of Husbandry,Rotulo Judicial' 3. pars. Rotul' Iudicial' Ed. 6.2. pars, there is a Decree between Dudley and his Wife, pretending to be Executors of one Morgan, who ≈øuppo≈øeth him≈øelfe to be Admini≈øtrator to that Morgan, And becau≈øe the Plaintiffe had not ≈øufficiently proved ≈øuch Will, and for that the Defendant ≈øued forth his Letters of Admini≈øtration, therefore all the goods of the Inte≈øtate were decreed to the Defendant, allowing Debts, Legacies, and Funerall charges.

A Decree betweene Tur ‚Ä¢ on and Cooke Plaintiffs, and Goddard, Defendant, whereby it appeares that the controver≈øie was
touching the Me≈ø≈øuages or Farme hou≈øes, and three hundred Acres of land in Haughton, in the County of Southamton, which the Plaintiffe ≈øuppo≈øed to have been Demi≈øed to Robert Tanner, and which the Defendant claimes as Executor unto Thomas Goddard, and that becau≈øe the Plaintiffs proved not the contents of their Bill, and the Defendant made proofe of his An≈øwer, therefore the premi≈ø≈øes and the Lea≈øe therof made to the Defendants Te≈øtator, were decreed to the Defendant again≈øt the Plaintiffe, and that the Defendant after Mid≈øommer then next, ≈øhould enter and hold the premi≈ø≈øes (without En ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to be made by the Plaintiffe) till hee ≈øhould recover the ≈øame by Action at the common Laws and furthermore it was ordered that the Defendant ≈øhould be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.

The like Decree in the ≈øame Roll between „Äà‚óä„Äâ Plaintiffe and Gittins Defendant, whereby it appears, that the Plaintiffe had purcha≈øed certain lands of the Kings, whereof he ≈øuppo≈øed Iohn Brown Clerk (to whom the Plaintiffe was Executor) had an Abbots Lea≈øe, and the Defendant pretended that the two Me≈ø≈øuages and one Yard land, was letten unto him by Lea≈øe under Covenant and Seale for four≈øcore and one yeares, and traver≈øed the Plaintiffs title and the
Plaintiffe proved not his Bill, and therefore the premi≈øes were decreed to the Defendant according to his Lea≈øe, for all the years then to come therein, and the Plaintiffe adjudged to pay him ≈øixteen ≈øhillings eight pence.
Note that it is decreed to him without any quou≈øq that it ≈øhould be recovered at law and without any liberty, to ≈øhew better matter in this Court.

The like Decree in that Roll, between William Me≈ø≈øinger Quer', and the Major and Burge≈ø≈øes of Glouce≈øter, touching divers Mannors; Fora≈ømuch as upon the hearing of the matter, the Defendant ≈øhewed a Tripartite Feoffement of the premi≈ø≈øes, from John Cooke to the Major and Burge≈ø≈øes, to the u≈øe of a Free-≈øchoole and other purpo≈øes, And becau≈øe the Plaintiffe proved not the matter of his Bill and Replication, therefore the ≈øaid Mannors and lands. &c. were decreed to the Defendants and their Succe≈ø≈øors, to their u≈øes, and that the Plaintiffe ≈øhould by Chri≈øtmas next deliver them all the Evidences concerning the ≈øame.

The like Decree in that Roll between Thomas Stowell and Anthony Capps, reciting, that where the Lord William Pawlet, Lord Pre≈øident of the Councell, and Lord Keeper of the great Seale, 22 Oct. Anno 5. Eliz. 6. becau≈øe the Plaintiffe had not proved
his title to the Mannors, &c. decreed the ≈øaid Mannors to the Defendant and his heires till the Plaintiffe ≈øhould recover the ≈øame at the Common Law, and that the Defendant ≈øhould al≈øo have the Arrerages, and twenty ≈øhillings co≈øts; The Plaintiffe being grieved with that Decree, and exhibiting a new Bill to the Lord Rich, having at the Plaintiffs in≈øtance heard the Cau≈øe, and given divers dayes to the Plaintiffe, to ≈øhew what he could to rever≈øe that Decree, did afterwards, becau≈øe no ju≈øt cau≈øe was ≈øhewed, to fru≈øtrate or alter that Decree, di≈ømi≈ø≈øe the Defendant.

Al≈øo a like Decree in that Roll, between Richard Lewknor, and Dame Elizabeth his Wife Plaintiffes, and Robert Barwick Defendant, becau≈øe the Plaintiffs proved not the matter of their Bill and Replication, and becau≈øe the Defendant proved a Lea≈øe to be made to him ≈øix yeares ≈øince of the Farme of Elle≈øton, by one Sir Roger Lewknor, therefore the Defendant was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed. And it was further by the Authority afore≈øaid decreed, that the Defendant ≈øhould enjoy his Lea≈øe, without interruption of the Plaintiffs, or either of them, and the Plaintiffs ≈øhould pay him forty ≈øhillings Co≈øts.

A Decree between Fotheringall and Ed≈øington Defendant,Rotulo Judicial' E. 6 4. pars. the que≈øtion was touching
certain lands which the Plaintiffe claimed by Lea≈øe, and which the Defendant claimed as Copihold; And fora≈ømuch as he failed in the proofe, and the Defendant ≈øhewed his Copy and antient Court Rolls, proving it to be antient Coppihold, therefore the lands were decreed to the Defendant according to his Copy, again≈øt the Plaintiffe his Executors and A≈ø≈øignes, till the Plaintiffe ≈øhould prove a better title before the Councell at Yorke, and yet if the Plaintiffe did trouble the Defendant or his Wife at Yorke, or any other the Kings Courts, then hee ≈øhould pay five pounds Co≈øts, and the Defendant was then di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with twenty ≈øhillings Co≈øts pre≈øently.
Another Decree in the ≈øame Roll between Gervas and Gawen, to the ≈øame effect afore≈øaid.
The like decree in the ≈øame Roll between We≈øtwood and We≈øtwood.

A Decree between ap-Edward, Rotul' Judicial' Edw. 6.8. pars. and Trevor, whereby it appeares that the Plaintiffe having fir≈øt a Decree by default, did counter feit an ab≈øolute Decree, and put the Lord Chancellours name to it, and therefore it was then ordered that the Defendant and his A≈ø≈øignees ≈øhould enjoy the lands, and take the profits thereof again≈øt the Plaintiffe and his heires, till hee or they ≈øhould
prove a better title in this Court.

Brocas contra Savage, a Decree made for the Defendant, notwith≈øtanding it was alleaged by the Plaintiffe in re≈øpect the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes was in que≈øtion, in 31. Eliz. li. B. fo. 295.

He in rever≈øion comming in by ≈øurrender bound by Decree. A Decree again≈øt the Le≈ø≈øee and all claiming under him, he ≈øurrenders to him in Rever≈øion, and he was adjudged to be bound by the Decree for ≈øo long time as the Lea≈øe ≈øhould have endured.

Chapman contra. Bi≈ø≈øow, 23. & 24. Eliz. The Tenant in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion wa≈øted the hou≈øes becau≈øe di≈øpuni≈øhable, by rea≈øon of a meane E≈øtate for life, yet decreed that he ≈øhould repaire two parts in Judgement Roll, Edw. 6. Vaneerant & Eyre.
Strelley contra Throckmorton, & Foliamb, & Fitzwilliams, Two parts of Judgement Roll, Edw. 6. and Woodley & Read.

Goodman contra Kinnerley, Jennings contra Blunt, Re ‚Ä¢ d contra Rawlins, Nicholas Scot in the ≈øecond part of Judgement Roll, H. 8. and in the ≈øame Roll two Decrees for divor≈øes. Terrell and his Wife, Jeffery and Jenny.

list.item: Moore & Taylor 29. Eliz. After verdicts in Kings Bench.

div.p:
A Decree made for an Heire at the Common
For an heire touching lands conveyed by a Recu≈øant.law again≈øt certain Feoffees, who had lands conveyed unto them to maintaine Schollers, who ≈øhould u≈øe holy Orders, Crofts & Evetts, Mich. 3. Jac. Another 4. Jac. Witering contra Pe≈øhall, 18. Jac.

A Decree made to relieve one which had double taken from him (as a concealer) by vertue of the ≈øtatute of Bankrupts, upon indirect dealing by Commi≈ø≈øioners, in the execution of the Commi≈ø≈øion, Wood contra Hayes. 4. Jac.
Allen con' Edwards, 2. Jac. Et Edwards, Smith & Wood contra _____ in 8. Jac.

The Court decrees that the Husband and Wife ≈øhall make, ≈øeale and deliver, or ≈øuffer livery of a Lea≈øe of the lands to bee made to the Plaintiffe by the ≈øaid Husband and his Wife. Hungerford contra Hutton, 12. Eliz. li. A. fo. 91.

Dom' Culpepper contra Par≈ølow, the Court decrees the thing promi≈øed, and the Hu≈øband is bound by the wives promi≈øe. The que≈øtion is, whether the Wife was married at the time of the promi≈øe made or not, Mich. Jac. li. A. fo. 138.

Decree and Commi≈ø≈øion. Frankland contra Graie, the Plaintiffe bought land of the Defendant, which the Defendant had conveyed before, to the u≈øe of him≈øelfe, his Wife and Son; It was decreed that the Plaintiffe ≈øhould have the
land again≈øt all, in 13. & 14. Eliz. li. B. fo. 81. The Defendant refu≈øed, a Writ of Execution went out, and hee could not be found, ≈øerved upon his Wife who refu≈øed, all Proce≈ø≈øe of contempt went out again≈øt him, in lib. eod. fo. 159.264.350. Whereupon in re≈øpect he could not be found a Commi≈ø≈øion was directed to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid lands, and the Tenants to pay their rents to the Plaintiffe, or el≈øe Attachments to be awarded again≈øt them.
Without a Bill. Bull contra Huddleton, Decree without a Bill in Mich. 9. Jac. li. B. fo. 27. or thereabouts.
