We≈øt contra We≈øt, and a Seque≈øtration, 12. Car.
To re≈øign a Benefice. Harris contra Smith, a Decree re≈øigne a Benefice, in Mich'. 8. Car.
Reyner contra Reyner, in Mich. 22. Jac. Dom. Effingham contra
A Without proofe for quieting of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Decree without proofe for quieting of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
Denis contra Carew, in 16. Jac. An Injunction or Decree here without any proofe to quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion had at law, and to avoyd Multiplicity of ≈øuits, in 3. vel. 4. Jac.
Durham contra Dearing, 4. vel. 5. Jac.
Sawyer contra Pomery, li. B. fo. 786. in libro novo.
Standen contra Bullock, 41. Eliz. li. B. fo. 284.

For a lea≈øe ≈øuppo≈øed to be voyd &c. Manwaring contra Peck, A Decree for e≈øtabli≈øhing of a Lea≈øe which is ≈øuppo≈øed to be voyd, and again≈øt a ≈øtatute law, being Priors land, in 11. Iac. li. A. fo. 342.

Confirmation of a Decree in the Court of Reque≈øts. Francis contra in ‚Ä¢ vace, the Court doth decree and confirme the Decree in the Court of Reque≈øts, without any proofes of the ≈øub≈øtance of the matter, notwith≈øtanding the Prohibition out of the Court of Common Pleas, or Kings Bench, li. B. 9. Iac. fo. 277.

Parcell or no parcell decred here. Decanus Wind≈øor contra Kinner≈øley, the point being parcell or no parcell, Decreed and being uncertain, the lands lying intermixt, ordered to be ≈øet out, notwith≈øtanding the Defendant by generall words in a Bargain and ≈øale, have enjoyed the ≈øame long, yet ordered in Michaelmas 9. Iac. li. A. fo. 321.
Decanus Wind≈øor contra Bouliant, the like in Mich. 8. Jac. li. A. fo. 390.
Sincton contra Greeno, upon point of Reputation, in Nov. 7. Iac. Decreed in Pa≈øch. 9. Car.
Vpon one witne≈ø≈øe. Eland contra Wright, a Decree upon one Witne≈ø≈øe appeareth by a Judges Certificate, in Hillar. 9. Car. vel Iac. or Pa≈øc. following.
Swan contra Atkins, A Decree upon one Witne≈ø≈øe which proves his Pedigree, from whence he claimes, in 16. & 17. Eliz. li. A. fo. 213.
Fawkner contra Winchcombe, in Pa≈øch. 10. Iac. vel Car. li. B. fo. 788.
Vpon a verball promi≈øe. Hunt contra Chee≈øeman, a Decree made upon a verball promi≈øe in Pa≈øoh. 10. Jac. vel Car. li. B. fo. 813.
A Decree pronounced in the Te≈øtators lifetime, not to be pa≈ø≈øed under Seale by the Executor. Ewer contra Frere, Pa≈øch. 1634.
To avoyd a Decree. Dominus Peter contra Elimozinarius de We≈øtm. A Decree to avoyd a Decree made according to the ≈øtatute of 43. Eliz. in Trin. 3. Jac. li. B.

This cau≈øe was, where the lands came into the Kings hand, but not by the Statute of Chantries, and the King being ≈øo ≈øeized de facto & non jure, grants the≈øe lands to a common per≈øon, whether the grant be good yea or no in Equitie.

Noxon contra Browning, in 3. Iac. li. B. fo. 515. and afterwards if there be a Decree made in this Court, upon the Decree of the Commi≈ø≈øioners upon the ≈øtatute, as ≈øhall not be maintainable by the ≈øaid ≈øtatute, fo. 864.
Pauteres de Trinbury contra Chapman, in Mich. or Hillar. 4. or 5. Car.
Ewderby contra Huddle≈øton, examined a Decree in the Court of Reque≈øts in October 9. Jac.

Kit≈øon contra Cropley, May 37. Eliz. A
Decree to prohibit a man from ≈øowing of Ridges which lye in Sheepcour≈øe in May, 37. Eliz.
Iervace contra Bullen, 12. Jac.
To prohibit one from preaching. Villa de Yarmouth contra Decanunt Norwich, a Decree to prohibit a Par≈øon 0118 0683 V 3 from Preaching, and the Town to pay Co≈øts, in Hill. 5. Car.
Holme contra Wild, the Defendant entred into a Bond to leave his Fellow≈øhip, and after takes away his Bond, the Court doth di≈øplace him, and decreed him to leave it, Pa≈øch. 15. Car.
For by lawes. Shipwa ‚Ä¢ e contra Pilkington, concerning the decreeing of By-lawes for the good of a Town, a Decree in 5. Car. and a Decree in 25. Eliz.
Dodford contra Se≈ø≈øions, the contrary in 14. Car.

In the Court of Reque≈øts confirmed. King contra Burrell, a Decree in the Court of Reque≈øts upon a verball promi≈øe, a Prohibition thereupon, this Court confirmes that Decree, becau≈øe the Plaintiffe is antient Tenant, and been at co≈øts in building. Hill. 2. Car.

Rever≈øt though no new matter. Epi≈øcopus Dunelmen' contra Martin, a Decree rever≈øt though no new matter, in Trin. 5. Car. the ca≈øe upon which the Decree was mi≈øtaken, and notwith≈øtanding his tran≈ølation, ≈øues as for the right of the Bi≈øhop of Oxon'.
Comes Devon contra Leake, ≈øome mi≈øtaking in a Decree amended, &c. in Hill. 14 Car.
Irons laid on a man in Fleet for not performing a Decree. South contra Gardiner, Irons to be layd upon a man in the Fleet, becau≈øe he will not performe a Decree in 6. Car. li. B.
Patent of concealement. Barker contra Shepheard. about 3. Car. Swan contra Turborvile, concerning a Patent of Concealment, Decreed, and other Patents, in Car. li. B.
Comes Pembroke contra Zouch, a Legacy decreed in Mich. 7. Car.
Legacie decreed. Again≈øt an Infant. Monke contra Winch, decreed again≈øt an Infant, and one bound in 500 l to performe when he comes to age, Hill' 2. Car.

To confirme a Decree at Yorke.
Portington contra Beamont, a Decree here, to confirme a Decree at Yorke, to prevent Prohibition, Trin. 2. Car.
Almioney. La≈øhbrooke contra Tiler, Almiony decreed here 8. Car.
Gre≈øham contra Dee, & Dee contra Woodhou≈øe in 4. Car. a man may affirme a Decree though not in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
Ma ‚Ä¢ or Norwich contra Decanum Norwich, Decree for Precincts and parcells, 8. Car.
Wright contra Middleton, this Court examines a Decree made at Yorke, 8. Car.

After a Decree in London.
Coventry contra Major London & We≈øt, 6. Car.
For damages. Paine contra Patti≈øon, a Decree for Damages for a Le≈ø≈øee for yeares, in Mich. 7. Car.
Hill contra Michell, Mich. 9. Car.
Richman contra Gi≈ølinhans, looke Ju≈øtice Crookes Certificate, 9. Car.
Askwith contra Turner, the Court will not rever≈øe a Decree made at Yorke, unle≈ø≈øe it was unduly obtained, or Erior therein, 9. Car.

A ≈øuit reteyned here after a Decree in the Court of Reque≈øts. Devi≈øteed contra Engle≈øted, 38. Eliz. li. B. fo. 426. Notwith≈øtanding a Decree in the Court of Reque≈øts, this Court referrs a≈øwell matters decreed there, as here, to Referrces, to ca≈øt up Accompt.
For tithes in kind. Farmour contra Tro≈øt, Tythes in kind decreed, notwith≈øtanding a Decree in Lord Bacons time, 12. Car. and what is a Yardland, and how to ≈øet it out.
Epi≈øcopus Heref. contra Awbrey, Hill'. 14. Car.
Kenrick contra Temple, 15. Car.
Magi≈øter Trin. Coll. contra brooke, 12. Car.
Birch trees, timber trees. Comiti≈ø≈øa Cumbries contra Com' Cumbrie, Birch trees are decreed to be Timbertrees, in 8. Jac. fo. 349.

And ≈øeque≈øtration in Infants hands, or to their u≈øe. Sere & Eland contra Colley, the Plaintiffs being Creditors of Colley preferred their Bill again≈øt the Defendant, being all
Forreyners, but the goods were pa≈ø≈øed over into England, into Merchants hands by Colley, and this Court taking notice in re≈øpect of the different computation of the Realm, Fir≈øt to be paid at the Fea≈øt of the three Kings heads ≈øecondly becau≈øe the Bill was not ≈øealed; Thirdly, becau≈øe the debts grew in France, and he came over hither to keepe his body from Arre≈øts the Court decreed the debts, and cau≈øed a Decree to be drawn up pro Confe≈ø≈øo, becau≈øe the Defendant would not an≈øwer, and Seque≈øtred moneys in other mens hands to pay the debts, although they were pa≈ø≈øed over to others to the u≈øe of an Infant, 8. Jac. li. A. fo. 1184.
Cooke contra Trewman, a Decree upon a verball Agreement, in Trin. 4. Jac.
For tithe Conies & Wood. Shires contra Burgaine, a Decree for Tythe Coneys and Wood, 12. Car.
Holme contra Fletcher, concerning a Legacie, in Mich. 2. Car.
Poole contra Co ‚Ä¢ well, Trin. 4. Car. the Father entred into Articles for land, the ≈øonne no partie, yet having con≈øented decreed.

An intention with a Declaration ≈øupplyed. Redman contra Torrell, for that the Plaintiffes Father did fully intend and re≈øolve, that the Plaintiffe ≈øhould have the Lea≈øe and did give the ≈øame accordingly, and that ≈øhe at divers times declared, that
≈øhee had given him the ≈øaid Lea≈øe, and for that Chri≈øtopher Torrell him≈øelfe prote≈øted, as he was a Chri≈øtian man, did promi≈øe that the Plaintiffe ≈øhould, and for that the ≈øaid Torrell did purpo≈øe to ≈øend to the Plaintiffe for ≈øome agreement, and made offer of 200 pounds for the ≈øaid Lea≈øe, therefore decreed in 28. Eliz. fo. 682.
A highway decreed. Wotton contra Wotton, a high way decreed in 10. Car.
Powell contra Par≈øons, a piece of ground ≈øold, but no re≈øervation of a high way, but decreed that a way ≈øhould be continued as formerly, Mich. 3. Car.
In the Court of Wards over-ruled here. Roberts contra Harccourts, a Decree in the Court of Wards decreed here, notwith≈øtanding the Decree there, Hill. 14. Car.
Attorac. Dom. Regis contra Epi≈øc. Oxon', a Bill here to unite a Par≈øonage to the Bi≈øhops ≈øea about 12. Car.
Dom. Scroope contra Lazenby, a Decree at Yorke being for lands, is adjudged to be coram non judice, Pa≈øch. 2. Car.

div.head: Defendant.
div.p: DefendaÃÑ A Defendant examined touching a contempt, and di≈øcharged thereof, ≈øhall have Co≈øts of Cour≈øe, if a Commi≈ø≈øion bee not pre≈øently taken out to prove it, and if he prove it not, thou increa≈øe of Co≈øts, Atkin≈øon contra Ailoff. 37. Eliz.

div.head: Demurrers.
div.p: Demurrer. A Bill laying a promi≈øe to a≈ø≈øure lands for ten ≈øhillings in hand, and 2100 pounds at daies, demurred and allowed becau≈øe it was but a preparation for Action upon the ca≈øe, William & Nevill, Trin. 38 Eliz.

The generall pardon pleaded to di≈øcharge

A Demurrer, becau≈øe it concernes the Queens title proper for the Exchequer, yet over-ruled, Mich. 33. Eliz. li. A. fo. 33.

div.head: Depo≈øitions.
div.p: Depo≈øition no amendment after publication. Chamberlaine & Pope, 39. & 40, Eliz. After publication, the Court would not amend a Depo≈øition mi≈øtaken.

div.p: Di≈ømi≈ø≈øions. Hayward contra Timber, 4. Jac. li. B. fo. 602. The matter heard there after a Di≈ømi≈ø≈øion in the Exchequer upon hearing, but there appearing no matter to relieve the Plaintiffe, the matter was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, the rather, becau≈øe there was a former di≈ømi≈ø≈øion in the Exchequer.

div.head: Divor≈øe.
div.p:
Divor≈øe.A Divor≈øe cau≈øa frigitatis, the Woman ≈øued for her Marriage portion, yet her Father was alive who gave it, to which exception was taken, yet the Ma≈øter of the Rolls ≈øaid, he would be no Formali≈øt. Barrow

div.p: Dower. Wild contra Wells, Bill to be relieved for Dower, and a Commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øet out the the lands in 25. Eliz. li. B. fo. 112.

div.p: Elegit.PAImer contra Bolls, an Elegit returned and fyled being out, and thereby without remedy renewed by this Court to be executed, 2. Car.

div.p:
Intaile. Baile contra Read, 38. Eliz. li. A. fo. 728. an Entaile cut off contrary to a Provi≈øo, to the intent onely to make a Joynture, and then the I emainders were ≈øettled in taile as
before, wherefore the Forfeiture di≈øpenced within Equitie.

Tatton contra Molineux, Of a Chattle how farr√© good. a Lea≈øe made to Feoffees in tru≈øt to the u≈øe of the Plaintiffe for life, and after to the Heires males of his body, the ≈øaid Plaintiffe hath full power to di≈øpo≈øe of his Lea≈øe, ≈øo long as he hath an heire, and that an Intaile of a Tru≈øt of, or out of a chattle is not good, nor any ≈øuch perpetuitie, Pre≈øidents being produced to that purpo≈øe and the Judges opinion between a remainder of a Chattle and the i≈ø≈øue in taile of a chattell in 7. Jac. li. A. fo. 1183. the lands lye in the Countie Palatine.

div.head: Equitie.
div.p: Lock contra Hunt, 7. Car. no advantage by unitie, di≈øcent, Fine, or di≈øcontinuance.

div.p: E≈øtate. King contra Blundavile, the Defendant having an E≈øtate for life without impeachment of Wa≈øt, was ordered not to do Wa≈øt both upon woods and hou≈øes, 5. Jac. li. A. fo. 327.

div.p: Examination.Examinations of Plaintiffs and Defendants, and Witne≈ø≈øes after a hearing.

div.head: Exceptions.
div.p: If a man except again≈øt an An≈øwer and hath it referred if thereupon it fall out to be good, the Defendant ≈øhall have Co≈øts for that trouble upon motion, Be≈øwick contra Fox, Hillar. 39. Eliz.

div.head: Executors.
div.p: Executor not inforced to put in bond but in certain ca≈øes. Executors not in equitie compelled to put in Bond to per≈øorme the Will or An≈øwer Legacies, unle≈ø≈øe it appeare, they have either broken the tru≈øt in them repo≈øed by the Te≈øtator, or bee decayed ≈øince his death, for at his death it ≈øeemed hee tru≈øted them without Bond, Browne contra Purton, 32. Eliz. li. B. fo. 641.
One Executor may ≈øue another in this Court, though not at law, Allen contra Story in 1585. and Okely & Barnard, 39. Eliz.
Two executors, one of them is made Defendant he ≈øhall be charged no further, then for the goods came to his own hands, Herbage contra Back≈øhaw, 35. Eliz.

Jac. li. A. fo. 638.

Two Executors and Joynt in the Bill,Coexecutors. ≈øhall be ≈øevered upon hearing.

Capell contra Go≈øtow, two Executors, the one tru≈øteth the other to receive all Rents and dyes, the Plaintiffe calls his Executor to an account, being th' executor of a Tru≈øtee, ordered to make ≈øatisfaction, in 12. Jac. li. A. fo. 421.

Terrey contra Fowler, an Executor maketh
doubt, whether he ≈øhall pay debts before a Decree in Chancerie, decreed they ≈øhall be protected.
Dominus Craven & Comes Dor≈øet, Creditors about 6. Car.
Wolver≈øton contra Amher≈øt. 13. Car.
Kemp contra Lamplugh, 14. Car.
Rowe contra Billing, two Executors being decreed to pay Legacies and debts, the one paying it, the other ≈øhall upon a Bill be compelled to pay the moity and Co≈øts, in 10. Car.
Martin contra knowles, concerning two Co-partners Executors, the e≈øtate being not divided before death, 28. Eliz. fo. 257.
Houghton contra Hampden, & e contra, One Executor receives money for Intere≈øt, it ≈øhall be accompted as principall for five per centum, in Mich. 9. Car.
Viceeomes Conway contra Crooke, a Bill preferred again≈øt the Executor of one that committed Wa≈øts, demurred unto, and good in 15. Car.
But an accompt for an E≈øtate which came to the Defendants hands called in que≈øtion, pleaded the Statute of limitation, over-ruled in 15. Car.

div.head: Exemplification.
div.p:
Exemplification. Fi≈øher contra Hawkes & Smith in 1590. the Plaintiffe allowed without ≈øhewing a
Deed inrolled, to plead the Exemplification of it.
If a Demi≈øe of lands, want ≈øufficient words to carry that which was meant to pa≈ø≈øe, it ≈øhall not be holpen in equitie, Kent contra Kent. in 1591.
Fi≈øher contra Smith, the Court orders an Exemplification of a Deed to be pleaded at law, where the Deed cannot be brought, in 33. Eliz. li. A. fo. 26.

div.head: Extent.
div.p: Extent not well layd, anew awarded. Trion contra Michell, the Plaintiffe ≈øued out an Elegit, being not well layd, and the Extent not good, ≈øues here in Equitie for the money, decreed 12. Car.
To accompt for profits upon Extent according to true valuation, and not to the extended value, but not u≈øe for tho≈øe profits, in 5. Car. li. B.

Haughton contra
_____ 4. Car. or thereabouts.
Lands extended at low rate to an≈øwer trua value. Re-extent. Aldred contra Wilkin≈øon, 5. Car.
Dom. Deancourt contra Hamp≈øon, according to the Receipt, and not to the extended rate, in 2. Car.
Chivers contra Bampton, Trin. 5. Car. A Reextent awarded upon a Statute, the lands being not known upon the former extent.

div.head: Evidence.
div.p:
Bourn contra Debe≈øt, Evidence. Shop-bookes read
as an Evidence at the hearing, Mich. 15. Car.
Harri≈øon contra Bludder, the ≈øame terme, and concerning the Statute of Limitation by great advi≈øe.

div.head: Feme Covert.
div.p:
BAcon alias Prior, le feme vend le u≈øe
que le feme ad cer' les Deniers vncorpus le mort le Baron quel clayme le u≈øe mere, & nient remedie in equitie, 7. E. 4. vouch un ea≈øe de Tasborough & Danvers, are in que≈øtion, Hillar. 1590.
The Husband ≈øold lands and debts due to the Wife before Coverture, and tooke Wares for it, hee dying ≈øhe ≈øurviving relea≈øed the debts, and decreed ≈øhe ≈øhould not, 36. H. 6.134. & 142.

Waterhou≈øe Defendant, was Grauntee of a Lea≈øe in tru≈øt, to the u≈øe of the Wife of Witham, ≈øhe dyed, and made Waterhou≈øe Admini≈øtrator, Witham complained, and would have had the Lea≈øe in equitic, the order and opinion of the Court was, hee ≈øhould not, but the Grauntee and Admini≈øtrator ≈øhould, 38. Eliz.

Seekes to avoyd a Lea≈øe. Ireland contra Pavie in Mich. 13. Car. The Plaintiffe held two Tenements of the Husband and Wife, and ≈øurrendred both, in con≈øideration that the Husband and Wife
≈øhould make a Lea≈øe for one of them for three lives, the Husband dyed, the Wife being but Tenant for life, and ≈øo by the Statute would have avoyded the Lea≈øe for three lives, but the Court thought good it ≈øhould be holpen in Equitie. Donnery & We≈øton 36. & 37. Eliz.
Feme ad E≈øtate d√Ø≈øpuni≈øhable del wa≈øt un ‚Ä¢ '. wa≈øt en mea≈øons prohibit & puis en Mare ≈øine auxi, Morgan & Peury, 37. Eliz.

Not bouÃÑd by Decree. Feme covert partie by Articles, and to a Decree, but ≈øhe a≈ø≈øented not, the effect of it was, to forgoe the Joynture for other recompence, after that the Husband dyed, ≈øhe tooke a new Husband, and they left to the law to recover her Joynture. Slater contra Foliambe, 37. Eliz.

Styward contra Jarmy, & Iarmy contra Stayward, Iarmy was enforced to make a≈ø≈øurance, Mich. or thereabouts decreed in 39. & 40. Eliz. li. A. fo. 660. li, B. fo. 41. & 42. Eliz. fo. 220. & 551, and becau≈øe ≈øhee refu≈øed to performe, was committed till ≈øhe did agree.
The like between Twyn & Box, in li. A. fo. 487.22. & 23. Eliz.
Egerton contra Town≈øend, li. B. fo. 954 11. Jac.

Voux & Uxor, contra Gleas & Uxor, 4
& 5. Ed. 6. fo. 35. the Court doth order that the Husband ≈øhall become bound in a Recognizance, that his Wife ≈øhall relea≈øe her Right.
Compelled to levy a Fine. Barty contra Herenden, 2. & 3. Eliz. li. A. fo. 62. the Court compells the Hu≈øband and Wife to levy a Fine.
Wiat contra Wiat, in Mich. 16. Jac. li. B. fo. 476. The Wife being no partie to the Bill.
Hau≈øly contra Hau≈øly, Trin. 17. Jac. & Hillar' prox.

Committed to Newgate for not performing an Order. We≈øtdeane contra Frizell & Uxor', the Defendant and his Wife committed to Pri≈øon for not performing the order in Maii 10. Iac. The Decree and their Commitments in 12.13. & 14. Iac. Regis in 14. Iac. li. B. fo. 14. She was committed to Newgate.
Compelled to levy a Fine and perfect a≈ø≈øurances. Sands contra Tomlin≈øon, Mich. Iac. li. A. fo. 679. a Wife compelled to levy a Fine and perfect a≈ø≈øurances.

Pope contra Moore, the Defendants Wife being priviment en≈øeint at her husbands death, the child could not be provided for by law, but the Court ordered, that the Child ≈øhould have ≈øufficient allowance, li. A. fo. 307.3. Car. vel Iac.
Sueth her Husband and others. Rivet contra Lanca≈øter, the Wife ≈øueth her Husband, in 39. Eliz. li. A. fo. 201.
We≈øt. contra We≈øt, 12. Car.
And feme Covert ≈øueth others, 17. Iac. li. A. fo. 940.
Kiffin contra Kiffin, 17. Iac. li. A.
Dom. Cri≈øpe in Pa≈øch. or Trin. 18. Iac. li. A. fo. 1088.
Comiti≈ø≈øa Dor≈øet contra Comitem Dor≈øet about 7. Iac.

Fle≈øhward contra Iack≈øon, Money given to a Feme Covert for her maintenance, becau≈øe her Husband is an unthrift, the Hu≈øband pretends the money to be his, but the Court ordered that the money ≈øhould be at her di≈øpo≈øing, 21. Iac. li. B. fo. 719.

Ru≈øt contra Whittle & al', Pa≈øch. 8. Iac. li. B. The Court doth decree a Report wherein it was thought fit, that the Defendant ≈øhould compell his Wife, and another mans Wife, being th'other Defendant, to levy a Fine and joyne in a≈ø≈øurance.
Sued others without her Hu≈øband and in her friends name. Dom. St. John contra Englefield, in Mich. 14. Iac. a Bill preferred without the privitie of her Husband, allowed.
Ga≈øcoigne contra Francklyne, a Feme Covert ≈øues others, 42. Eliz. li. A. about fo. 593.
Haynes contra Duncombe, in Trin. 21. Iac.
Milward contra Bradborne 5. or 6. Car.
Examined again≈øt her Hu≈øband. Lake contra Deane, 38. Eliz. li. A. fo. 157. a Wife examined to di≈øcover her Hu≈øbands deceipt.
Chargeth lands with a paroll tru≈øt. Cary contra Ley, in Mich. 21. Iac.
Land charged with a paroll tru≈øt, though made by a Feme Covert.
Sambroke contra Ram≈øey, in Mich. 13. Car.

May di≈øpo≈øe of a Tru≈øt. &c.
Baskervile contra Sinthome, the Plaintiffe conveyed a Lea≈øe to Feoffees in tru≈øt, to the u≈øe of his Daughters, and to his Children lynially, the Daughter married and had i≈ø≈øue, which dyes, marries againe, the Feoffees conveys the Lea≈øe to the Wife and Husband, and di≈øcharges the tru≈øt, the woman gives this tru≈øt to the Husband & dyes, the Heire ≈øues the Husband for this land, but ordered that the land ≈øhould goe to the Husband, notwith≈øtanding the Conveyance, 12. Jac. li. B.
To an≈øwer. Palmer contra Shonck, a feme Covert to An≈øwer Mich. 5. Car.
An Infant bound by Agreement. Stiles contra Stiles, an Agreement binds a Feme and an Infant, in Hillar. 2. Car.
Sankey contra Golding, 21. Eliz. li. fo. a Feme Covert ≈øues without her Hu≈øband.
Sues. Farewell contra Cur≈øon, Feme covert ≈øues in Chancerie ≈øa Baron in vie ou≈øter la Mare, 31. & 32. Eliz. fo. 8.
Baker contra Newbery, about 5. Car. though the Husband relea≈øed.

An Infant compelled to an≈øwer. Moore contra Dom'. Greenvile, will not
An≈øwer becau≈øe a Feme covert and within Age, compelled, 11. Car.
Throckmorton contra Calver, a woman returning her An≈øwer, being married after the Commi≈ø≈øion awarded, ordered, 11. Car.

Bound by Agreement. Randall contra Tynny, a ≈øingle woman did agree to have a moitie of land, and after Marriage, ≈øub≈øcribed her name with her Husband, to a latter Agreement, though Feme covert decreed in 10. Jac. li. B. 25. or 250.
Holman contra Awdley, 10. Jac. li. B. fo. 309. a Wife not to bee examined again≈øt her Husband.
Demurrs ordered to An≈øwer. Court contra Popham, the Wife demurres without her Husband, becau≈øe charged with con≈øpiracie and combination, ordered to An≈øwer upon Oath about June. 6. Car.
Comes Danby contra Peele, a Relea≈øe by the Husband ≈øhall not prejudice the Wife, to ≈øue for her Jewels in 13. Car. and a Wife ≈øues another in a friends name.
Keeling contra Bodley, Mich. 14. Car.
Rowe contra Comitem Newburgh, 14. Car. Looke in it otherwi≈øe, becau≈øe ≈øeparate.
Comes Exon' contra Dom. Morley, how farre it binds an heire more then Common law, for payment of debts, 13. Car.
To an≈øwer. Portman contra Popham, a Wife to an≈øwer without her Husband being beyond the Sea, in 11. Car.

Bat≈øon contra Conney, the Defendant demurres that at the time of the Agreement, the Defendant was an Infant at ≈øixteen years old, and now married, and ≈øo not bound, ordered to an≈øwer in Mich. 14. Car. and in Hill. 15. or 16. Car.

Poole contra Harrington, or econ'. A Wife hath a ≈øtock for her own u≈øe and dies, who is buried by a friend without direction of her Husband, he that buries her mu≈øt bee at the charge, and not the Husband, in Mich. 14. Car.

Roe contra Dom. Newburgh, a Feme covert cannot ≈øue, unle≈ø≈øe there be a ≈øeverance, this ≈øuit is for a promi≈øe in Marriage, after twenty yeares, the matter was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, becau≈øe the Plaintiffe could not find Pre≈øidents ≈øuting this ca≈øe. in Trin. 15. Car.
Georges contra Chancie, a Feme Covert being ≈øeparated, having an Allowance of two hundred pounds ≈øhe improved it, and di≈øpo≈øed of it by her Will, Mich. 15. Car.
Clarke contra We≈øt, how far a man Non compos mentis ≈øhall be concluded by a Feme Coverts di≈øpo≈øing of his E≈øtate, in Mich. 15. Car. a ca≈øe made and referred to Judges.
Simp≈øon contra Simp≈øon, a man cannot ≈øue his Wife, nor a Wife her Husband, in 3. Car fo. 394.

Received 1000 l for her right yet not barred. Dookwray contra Poole, a man having three Daughters, intailes his land upon thom after one of them married, and being a Fems Covert, with the con≈øent of her Husband was contented and agreed, to take one thou≈øand pounds in con≈øideration and extingui≈øhment of her right as Co-heire, the Judges hold it to be no good barr to her, in Trin. 7. Jac. The Judges Certificate.

div.head: Feme ≈øole.
div.p: Feme ≈øole before marriage conveys away her E≈øtate to, &c. avoyded. Povy contra Peart, the Plaintiffs Wife before Marriage, conveyed away her E≈øtate to the Defendant being her Son, and after the Defendant conveyed the ≈øame to his Children being Infants, becau≈øe (as the Court conceived) it was pa≈ø≈øed without any con≈øideration it was decreed for the Plaintiffe again≈øt the Defendant, and the Infants in 32. & 33 Eliz. li. B. fo. 430.454. & 484.

Re≈øerves power when feme revokes that not good A ‚Ä¢ w ‚Ä¢ d contra Stubbs, one Amy Pyms did cau≈øe one Light foot and the Defendant to enter into Covenants, and a Bond for performance to leave one hundred pounds to pay to ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhee ≈øhould appoint and if ≈øhe did nominate none, then the ≈øome hundred pounds was to be paid to two grand children, after ≈øhe cau≈øed the ≈øaid S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bbs and Light foot to cancell the≈øe Covenants and Bond, to make voyd this her intention yet decreed to be made good to
the Plaintiffe, in 10. Jac. or Car. li. B. fo. 442.
Sues to ≈øet forth her Dower. Thomas contra Thomas, ≈øues to ≈øet forth her Dower, 13. & 14. Eliz.

Takes a Commi≈ø≈øian, &c.
Winter contra Dancie, feme ≈øole onely, takes a Commi≈ø≈øion to examine Witne≈ø≈øes, marries before Witne≈ø≈øes be examined and after examined whether the Depo≈øitions ≈øhould ≈øtand, ordered to ≈øtand, 10. Car.

Marries before an Injunction, &c.
Webb contra Wi≈øe, a Marriage before an Injunction, the Court declares that it ≈øhall go and be revived notwith≈øtanding no Bill of Revivor, 10. Car.

Kempe contra Dom' Reresby, or econ'. The Lord Keeper declares that a woman cannot have Dower of a Tru≈øt, in M ‚Ä¢ ch. 2. Car. but compelleth the Defendant to An≈øwer, who is Tenant to the land, to enable her to bring her Writ of Dower.
A Farme with the lands u≈øually ≈øet therewith to be lett, and the Scrivenor put in the Farme with th'appertenance, and then got a Lea≈øe him≈øelfe to avoyd it, Harbin & Straw.

div.head: Fines.
div.p:
Fines. A Fine and Recovery got by circumvention, the party which got it, may bee compelled in equitie to recompence the partie circumvented, As the Ma≈øter of the Rolls was of opinion, at the hearing of the Cau≈øe
between Welby and Welby, primo Mait 1595.
Fines arbitrable for Coppiholders.
Tenant Right.
Middleton contra I ack son, in Hill'. 5. Car. one years moderate value.
Popham contra Larce≈ø≈øe, Trin. 13. Car.
Mon≈øier contra Ducket, Mich. 14. Car. The≈øe after a Decree at York.
Cooper ailas Staynning contra Blunt, A Fine arbitrable rated under value, 29. Eliz. li. B. or li. A. fo. 515.
Stoner contra Smith, a Fine arbitrable rated at two years and a halfe rent, which was the higher, in re≈øpect of the multiplicitie of Plaintiffs, 31. Eliz. li. A. fo 484.
Tenants de Accledon contra Kinne≈øley, 21. & 22. Eliz. li. B. fo. 86.
Gittings contra Browe, 41. Eliz. li. B. fo. 486. Two years rea≈øonable value.
Lake contra Jetherell, Nov. 9. Jac. Two years value.
Atwood & Ap≈øley, 41. Eliz.
Tenants de Gadde≈øden contra Carey, A years value, and book upon change of Tenant, and halfe a years value upon change of Lord, 4. Jac. li. B. fo. 435.
Fox contra Huddle≈øton, 4. Jac. li. B. fo. 204. A years value.
Tenants Right.
Wat≈øon contra Maihne, Mich. 15. Jac. li. B. fo. 328. one years value.
Nevill contra Albany, 12. Jac. li. B. fo. 768.
Beare contra Seymor, Mich. 9. Jac. li. A. fo. 343. & Pa≈øch. li. A. fo. 797.
Dom. Gerrard contra Parker, 12. Jac. li. A. fo. 1404.
Certaine examined here. Elrington contra Whet≈øtone, in 39. & 40 Eliz.
To be paid before enlargement Eaton contra Gwyn, 11 & 12. Eliz. fo. 206. The Defendant not to be relea≈øed out of Pri≈øon, till he hath paid the Fine to the Queen.

Levied by fraud by a Tenant five years pa≈øt ≈øhall not bar. Farmor contra Smith, that a Fine levyed by the practi≈øe and fraud of a Tenant at will, Copyholder, or a Terminor for years upon Covin, to barr the Lord of his Inheritance (though the Proclamation and five years pa≈øt without claime) doth barre the Rever≈øion of his Inheritance or Free-hold, 43. Eliz. li. B. fo. 367.

Fined for putting in a long replication. Milward contra Welden, the Plaintiffe for putting in a long Replication, was fined Ten pounds, and impri≈øoned, and a hole to bee made through the Replication, and hanged about his neck, and he to go from Barre to Barre, in 8. Eliz. li. B. fo. 678.
Thorold contra Thorold, 17. Jac.

Wright contra Booth, the Plaintiffe (being
≈øimple) was drawn to levy a Fine of his lands,levyed by a ≈øimple man yet ordered to be re≈øtra ‚Ä¢
ned. yet ordered that the lands ≈øhould be rea≈ø≈øured, if the Defendant did not pay a valuable con≈øideration or if hee failed of payment thereof, then the ≈øaid lands ≈øhould be re-a≈ø≈øured, 3. Juc. li. B. fo. 508.
Lewis contra Vaughan, 4. Jac. li. A. fo. 835.
Voyd yet relieved. Scambler contra _____ , in May 13. Car. becau≈øe a Fine was not levyed according to Covenant, a power became voyd to make Lea≈øes, but decreed but the la≈øt Order, in 15. Car.
Longman contra Hopgood, a Fine impo≈øed for breach of a Decree, Trin. 6. Car. li. B.

Impo≈øed to take mony and goods, &c.
Ru≈ø≈øell contra Read, 11. Car. a Warrant to the Serjeant at Armes to goe into the Fleet, and to take the Defendants money and goods to ≈øatisfie a Fine.
Barker contra Shepheard, about Mich. 9. Car. a Fine impo≈øed, and parties Pillored and impri≈øoned, and layd in Irons for abu≈øing a man for ≈øerving a Subpena in the Kings Bench.
Moderated. Long contra Snagg this Court doth rate and moderate a Fine 12. Jac. fo. 157.
Hopton contra Higgins, a Fine is not to be decided by witne≈ø≈øes but by Court rolls, and ordered to goe to hearing upon them in 10. Jac. li. B. fo. 176.
Thynn contra Carey, how far a Fine at Common law after five years, ≈øhall bar a title in Equitie, 10. Car.

Regulated by the mo≈øt number of Court-Rolls. Barra≈øton contra Wal≈øh, whether Fines be certain or not to regulate the ≈øame the mo≈øt number of Court Rolls to determine the ≈øame, and the time 14 Car. & Mich. 15. Car.
Clarke≈øon contra V ‚Ä¢ gerons, halfe a years full value.
Sacheverell contra Brimington, the Defendant pleads a Fine levied by a Lunatique, over-ruled in Trin. 15. Car. and an Order too for a Commi≈ø≈øion to examine whether a Lunatique or not.

Sur Conce≈ø≈øit reheved, &c.
A≈øhfield contra Cri≈øpe, a Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øit after five years upon a Mortgage in Mich. 13. Car.

div.head: Forgerie.
div.p: Forgerie here puni≈øhed. Barker contra Ireland & Morris, a per≈øon Sentenced in this Court for Forgerie, in 8. Jac. li. A. fo. 1172.

div.head: Feoffees.
div.p:
Feoffees a ≈øurviving joynt Feoffee to make ≈øale of lands, &c.
Billing≈øley contra Mathew, the Court orders the ≈øurviving Joynt Feoffee, to make ≈øale of lands for payment of debts a≈øwell as if the other had bin living in Mich. 12.
‚Ä¢ ac. and before.

In tru≈øt to be examined as, &c.
Mildmay contra Com. Warwick, Feoffees in tru≈øt to be examined as Witne≈ø≈øe, in Hill. 1. Car.
For Wife compelled to joyn. Ayre contra lenningss, Feoffees tru≈øted for the good of a Wife, compelled to joyn in ≈øale of lands, in Hill. 2. & 3. Car.
Clotworthy contra Hunt, Feoffees for a a Town, nor Recorder, to be examined, but for matter of fact, Trin. 2. Car.

div.head: Feoffement.
div.p: Liddalls contra vanlore, about an Occupant to u≈øes, or a Feoffement in tru≈øt, 2. or 3. Car.
Dux Buckingham contra Paul, in Mich. or Hillar. 5. Car.
Lilley contra Gilbie, Mich. or Hill. 5. Car. to compell a man to execute a Feoffement.

div.head: Forfeiture.
div.p: Forfeiture of a Copyhold relieved. Poore contra Oxenbridge, although a Tenant hath forfeited her Coppihold, yet relieved here, in 9. No. 44. Eliz.
Whi≈øtler contra Cage, Pa≈øch. vel Trin 7. Car.

div.head: Goods.
div.p: Goods. POpham contra Hinton, to goe into the per≈øonall, and whether a ≈øtatute bee goods, and betwixt goods Inventoried and a peraporconalia. How far ≈øhall go into e≈øtate, after it was in Orphans Court.
Haynes contra Child, concerning the contingencie or Goods, 9. Car.

Leate contra Turkey, Company of Merchants, if a Con≈øull beyond Sea hath power, and doe levy Goods upon a private Merchant, the Company mu≈øt beare it, if the Factor could not prevent the Act of the Con≈øull, Hill'. 1630.

div.head: Heire.
div.p: Heire is not bound by the Fathers bargain. THe Heire is not in Equitie bound to a≈ø≈øure lands, which his Father bargained and tooke money for, We≈øton contra Danvers 1584.

Of a Mortgager not to be relieved. Michill contra Chamberlaine, in 7. Car. an Heire of Mortgagee not to be relieved after ≈øeverall di≈ømi≈ø≈øions and Decrees unle≈ø≈øe can prove an extraordinary value of the land.

Porter contra _____ in 11. Car. one Brett provides, that his Heires, Executors, or Admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall have power to redeem lands, the Plaintiffe is neither, but as an A≈ø≈øignee from Brett, yet ≈øhall have power.

Breach of condition holpen again≈øt the heire. Salmon contra Vaux, an Heire at Law ≈øeeks to take advantage upon breach of Condition, becau≈øe Legacies were not paid according to the Will, but becau≈øe there was an intention to pay it, and an Agreement between the Si≈øters, decreed again≈øt the Heire, in 11. Car.
Archer contra Partridge, 9. Car.
Cooke contra Tookey, Pa≈øch. 15. Car. by great advi≈øe.

Bound by his fathers Covenant though claims not by di≈øcent. Pooke contra Poole, the Defendant comming in by grant and not by di≈øcent from his Father, 'tis pretended he ought to bee bound by the Fathers Covenants and as Executor hath no A≈ø≈øers, yet ordered to be lyable, in Mich. 14. Car.

div.head: Husband.
div.p: Husband. The Ma≈øter of Kings Colledge in Cambridge contra Ragland, the Defendants Wife would not bring in Evidences according t√∂ an Order, the Husband was bound that ≈øhe ≈øhould doe it, 4. Eliz. li. A. fo. 73.

Ackland contra Dom' Perriam, the Plaintiffe marrying one Malletts Widow, who made a Conveyance to the Defendants Husband in tru≈øt and received the profits of the land accordingly, but dyed before any ≈øatisfaction made the wife being ≈øued demurres, becau≈øe the Plaintiffe doth not ≈øue as Admini≈øtrator, and that the profits were received before ≈øhe was married to the Defendant, nor hath made any title to him≈øelfe to the goods of the ≈øaid Mallett, which notwith≈øtanding was over-ruled in 9. Jac. li. A. fo. 78.
Dom. Griffin contra Tailor. 3. & 4. Car. the Court ordered a man to procure his wife to acknowledge a Fine of Mortgaged lands.

div.head: Induction.
div.p: Induction WEbb contra Smart. 5. Iac. li. A. fo. 302. the Plaintiffe being inducted to a Par≈øonage, the Defendant notwith≈øtanding keeps the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by force; whereupon the Plaintiffe was inforced to preferre his Bill in this Court but the Defendant Demurred, becau≈øe the Vicarage is as his Freehold and Inheritance, and ≈øo properly determinable at law, yet the Demurrer overruled.
Bird contra Smith, 3. Iac. li. A. fo. 819.

div.head: Infants.
div.p: Infants. Copihold ≈øurrendred to the u≈øe of an Infant, to the intent he ≈øhould pay an Annuity to another at full Age, which he refu≈øed to doe, and it was decreed he ≈øhould pay it, and the Arrerages. Sawyer contra Gillet, 9. Eliz.

Bound. In a cau≈øe between the Lady Ru≈ø≈øell and the Earle of Lincolne, the Plaintiffs Councell moved the Court, to give Order again≈øt the younger Earle of Bedford being an Infant, Vouched a ca≈øe, 11. Nov. 6. Eliz. li. B. fo. 426. Between Altham and the Lord Morley, where between the date and ≈øealing of a Conveyance, the Lord Morley conveyed the land to an Infant, wherefore Altham had order again≈øt the Lord Morley

Made Executor to prevent payment yet lyable. Dom. Leppington contra Barnes, the Plaintiffs Husband made an infant Executor to prevent payment of debts not fit to undertake it, but another Admini≈øtrator for him during his Nonage, yet lyable for payment of debts in Mich. 9. Iac. fo. 362. & 1092.

div.p: Injunctions. Cock ≈øhot & Parke, an Injunction was again≈øt the Plaintiffe, and all clayming under him, to ≈øuffer the Defendant to enjoy po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, one Wilkin≈øon bought the Lea≈øe which Cock≈øhat the Plaintiffe claimed by, and then to avoyd the Injunction, tooke a Lea≈øe till it ≈øhould be ≈øeen how the old Lea≈øe ≈øhould be avoyded.
Servington contra Webb, 12. Eliz. li. A. fo. 176. An Injunction for po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, becau≈øe the Defendant would not perfect a≈ø≈øurance to prevent a mi≈øchiefe.
Barkley contra Pier≈øon, an Injunction to ≈øtay proceedings at law upon treble damages, notwith≈øtanding the cau≈øe di≈ømi≈ø≈øed to the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Court, Trin. 17. Jac.

div.head: Judgements.
div.p: Indgement.Upon Affidavit, endeavour u≈øed to have ≈øerved Proces to heare Judgement and could not find the Defendant, the Court proceeded, Windham & Harwood.

A Judgement no lett to examine in Equitie, ≈øo the truth of the Judgement not examined, as where Judgement again≈øt the truth of an Acquittance without a ≈øeale, or where the money paid after the day. Heard contra Doddington.

div.head: Inventorie.
div.p: Inventorie. Howet contra Baker, in Pa≈øch. 15. Car. Where the Defendant did not exhibit an Inventorie, the Court chargeth the whole Legacie on him after twenty years, though pretended not ≈øufficient.

div.head: Land.
div.p: Land ≈øold away and tenure re≈øerved.WHere new annexed Land is ≈øold away in Fee, and a tenure in Capite re≈øerved, it is pleadable here, Crompton contra Clifford, in Pa≈øch 37. Eliz. li. A. fo. 128.

Skinner contra Skinner, in Trin. 42. Eliz. the Father of the Plaintiffe and Defendant, Devi≈øed certain Lands to the younge≈øt ≈øon, which he purcha≈øed, the elde≈øt ≈øon ≈øuing for the ≈øame, is decreed according to the Devi≈øe.

Thynn contra Kin≈ømell, Money devi≈øed by the Plaintiffs Father to the Plaintiffe, out of certain lands which were to be ≈øold by the Defendant, the lands were intailed, and provided, that if the heires went about to ≈øell the ≈øame, it ≈øhould be voyd, being again≈øt the ≈øtatute of 32. H. 8. It is ordered to be ≈øold in 38. Eliz. lib. B. fo. 97. and concerning a di≈øcontinuance.

Manwayring contra Dudley, the Plaintiffs Wives Father made a Feoffement to u≈øes for thirteen years, to rai≈øe Portions of foure hundred pounds for his Daughters, the Father being dead, the Feoffees ≈øuffer the ≈øonne and heire to enter into the ≈øaid land, and ≈øold the ≈øame, and yet after a di≈øcent, after the death of the fir≈øt Purcha≈øor, at the third hand, although the money be due, yet the Court would not charge the lands with
the ≈øaid money, the Example being dangerous, in Hill. 43. & 44. Eliz. li. B. fo. 306.

Hungate contra Hungate, the Plaintiffs Father being a Batchelour, purcha≈øed an E≈øtate in the Defendants name, but after having i≈ø≈øue, the Plaintiffe, the Court decreed that the lands ≈øhould go to the Plaintiffe, and be rea≈ø≈øured by the Defendant, in 4. or 5. Jac. fo. 1070.
Bowell contra Hancocks, a Purcha≈øor di≈øcharged from a ≈øtatute in 11. Jac. li. A. fo. 344.

7. H. 7.10. A. Had lands di≈øcended to him in antient Deme≈øne, extended by ≈øtatute Merchant, B. purcha≈øed the lands, and had a Recovery by ≈øufferance, in the Court of antient Deme≈øne upon a Voucher, and ou≈øted A. A. brought a Subpaena, and it was holden that A. could not ≈øatisfie the Recovery, and therefore ≈øhould be re≈øtored to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by the Chancerie, for he had no remedie by law, where, notwith≈øtanding a double Judgement, yet the Judges directed them to the Chancerie.

Buggs contra Sumpnor, 8. Junii 43. Eliz. Lands given for the di≈øcharge of poore Inhabitants of a Pari≈øh, for di≈øcharge of Fifteens and Taxes, with a provi≈øo, that the Rents ≈øhould not be to the di≈øcharge of Gentlemens lands of the Pari≈øh, but of
poore mens onely, the Defendant being but a Yeoman (though he have purcha≈øed ≈øome of the Gentlemens lands, and ≈øought to have benefit of the gift) yet not allowed in 8. Junii, 43. Eliz.
Town≈øend contra K ‚Ä¢ lmurrey, Fee≈øimple laud purcha≈øed by the Father, and de≈øcended to the Son, this land ≈øhall not be A≈ø≈øetts in law, nor equitie to pay debts, 13. Car.
The Counte≈ø≈øe of Exeters Ca≈øe.

Epi≈øcopus Heref. contra Awbery, where the quantitie of a yard-land is not known, a Commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øett out ≈øo much land as the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall thinke fit, upon common intendment, in Hill. 14. Car.
Eborall contra Hunt, Lands pa≈ø≈øed in a Feoffement more then was meant, was holpen in equitie, notwith≈øtanding a Verdict and Judgement at law, ≈øuppo≈øing ≈øome circumvention.

Hire contra Wordall, lands Devi≈øed to be ≈øold and the money thereof comming ≈øhould be devi≈øed to Children, but the lands could not be ≈øold becau≈øe there was none appointed by the Will to ≈øell the ≈øame, yet ordered to be ≈øold, and the Lea≈øe was for a thou≈øand yeares, which is mo≈øt commonly to prevent the Kings right, in 39. Eliz. li. B. fo. 134.

div.head: Lea≈øe.
div.p:
Lea≈øe defective not ≈øupplyed in equitie. A Lea≈øe conteyning a Mo≈ø≈øuage in the
demi≈øe but land al≈øo in the habend', which land had been many years enjoyed accordingly, yet the Lord Chancellours opinion was, no continuance would make a voyd Lea≈øe good, e≈øpecially again≈øt a Purcha≈øor, Meld contra Cooper in 25. Eliz.
Brad≈øhaw contra Brad≈øhaw, in 16. & 17. Eliz. li. A. fo. 309.
Collins contra Syms, look from Febr. 26. Eliz. li. fo. 358.
Ellis contra Be≈øwick, the contrary, 36. Eliz. li. A. fo. 654.

A Lea≈øe devi≈øed to one for life, with ≈øeverall Remainders over to others, the fir≈øt Devi≈øee was compelled to enter Bond, to let it go according to the Devi≈øe, but if it were for a perpetuall Chattle, the Court would not have done it. Price contra Jones, 26. Eliz. fo. 599.
Al≈øton contra Ea≈øter, Trin. 7. Car.
Iones contra Frederick, 12. Jac. li. B. fo. 303. the Court will not charge the Admini≈øtrator of an Executor.
Smith & Gawdy contra Compton, 14. Nov. 41. & 42. Eliz. Tudnam, the contrary Tudnam contra Glanvile, 36. Eliz. li. A. fo. 396.
Long lea≈øes di≈ømi≈ø≈øed. No reliefe in Equitie touching Lea≈øes of one thou≈øand years, becau≈øe they tend to defraud the Crown, in 39. & 40. Eliz. Ri≈øden. & Tuffin.

A ≈øtranger having a Lea≈øe before a Decree, which was not bound thereby, and the ≈øame Lea≈øe being over-wrought by a Statute which was bound by the Decree, bought the extent of the ≈øtatute, and therefore his Lea≈øe was thereby bound by the Decree, ≈øo long as the Extent ≈øhould have continued, if it had not been bought. Arden contra Hanbury, or e contra.
Lea≈øes made by Deans, Canons, or Colledges, &c. for one and twenty years, or three lives are here relieved. Simeon contra Decanus de Windfor, Trin. 15. Iac. li. A. fo. 1177.
Long ‚Ä¢ o tra Decanum Bri≈øtoll, 3. Car.
Epi≈øcopus 'Dun ‚Ä¢ lm ‚Ä¢ ' contra Martin, Trin. 5. Car.
Comes Oxon' contra Gooth, Pa≈øch. 14. Iac. Derham cont' Chri≈øt-church, Mach. 10. Jac. li. B. fo. 64. the contrary.

Mon≈øen contra A ‚Ä¢ ≈øcough, the Defendant upon an Award did Covenant, that the Defendant and his Wife ≈øhould make a Lea≈øe voyd of all Incumbrances, yet after denied, and pretended, that a former E≈øtate was made to his Children, ≈øo that it was not in his power, and brake off the Sale of the ≈øaid Agreement or Lea≈øe whereby it was voyd in Law; The Court ordered the award to be performed to all intents and purpo≈øes, 11. & 12. Eliz. li. A. fo. 510. And afterwards
for not performing the ≈øame, was committed, 12. & 13. Eliz. li. A. fo. 204. And afterwards he was to become bound by a Recognizance to yeeld him≈øelfe to the Pri≈øon, which he did not doe, therefore the Plaintiffe might, and was Licenced, to take Execution upon that Recognizance, eodem folio 328.
Golding contra Tuffin, a Lea≈øe for many yeares, although it be intailed to many in Remainder, decreed to be ≈øold for payment of debts, Mich. 10. Iac.
The like 17. Jac. Hubbard contra Hare, li. A. 944.
Harvy contra Withers, in Pa≈øch. 24. Iac. Intailed lands ≈øold for payment of debts.

Powell contra Moultor ‚Ä¢ , a Lea≈øe intailed not ≈øubject to debts‚ñ™ though the Lea≈øe or A≈ø≈øignement ≈øuppo≈øed to be voyd becau≈øe intended, and the Defendant to pay debts out of the per≈øonall e≈øtate, 5. June, 3. Car. li. B fo. 1441.

Chambers contra Gregorie, a Lea≈øe made for yeares, and a Statute for quiet enjoying, the Statute was delivered with the Lea≈øe, but not a≈ø≈øigned; Whereupon the A≈ø≈øignee of the Lea≈øe, procured Letters of Admini≈øtration of the goods and chattells unadmini≈øtred, of the cognizor of the Statute and extended the ≈øame, which Admini≈øtration being
repealed and granted to another, the Court and Judges ordered th' e≈øtate by that Statute to be determined, 22. No. 9. Car.
Birkenhead contra Birkett, a Lea≈øe made for forty years, by the Ma≈øter and Brethren of the Ho≈øpitall of Saint Katherines, allowed for good, Hill, 1632.
Bampton contra Freake, a Decree to re≈øtrain the Defendant from ≈øelling of a Lea≈øe contrary to the intent of the Ance≈øtors in Octob. 9. Jac.
Huddle≈øton and Lamplugh, concerning a Lea≈øe attending upon an Inheritance and concerning the di≈øpo≈øing of the ≈øame, and likewi≈øe of a Tru≈øt, in Pa≈øch. 6. Car. li. A. fo. 769.

Car. li. A. fo. 182.

Sill contra Mole, a re≈øtraint from plowing of land worth five ≈øhillings an Acre, being antient warren, though di≈øpuni≈øhable here, about 6. Car.

div.head: Parcell.
div.p: Parcell or not parcel determined here. Egerton contra Egerton, by the opinion of the Judges parcell or no parcell determinable here where the Bill is not ≈øimple parcell.
Tatter≈øall contra Dalton, upon turning of water lying in two Counties about 11. Car.

Hobby contra Bonby, though parcell or
not parcell fit for law, yet no new≈øe to ≈øettle things according to proofe, and a Commi≈ø≈øion awarded accordingly, Pa≈øch. 2. or 3. Car.
Hetley contra Com. Suff. parcell or not parcell over-ruled upon the Demurrer, and decreed in Pa≈øch. 12. Car. Mr. Pages report.

div.head: Pannage.
div.p: Pannage. Pannage was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, the Le≈ø≈øor felled the trees, that felling in Equitie is to be ≈øtaid ≈øo far, as the Pannage may not be taken away 1593. Lord Marque≈ø≈øe contra Corham 36. Eliz.

div.head: Plaintiff.
div.p: Plaintiffe may examine and have publication within 14 dayes after return of the Certiorarie. My Lords order and opinion, the Plaintiffe may examine, and have publication within fourteen dayes after the return of the Certiorari to pray the ≈øurmi≈øes, and give the Court Juri≈ødiction, but the Defendant is not to examine or publi≈øh any to di≈øprove it. And if upon the Plaintiffs proofes it be reteyned, then the Plaintiff and Defendant may examine orderly touching the body of the Cau≈øe, and have publication according to the rules, and though the Defendant examine as ≈øoon as the An≈øwer, yet ≈øhall not they be publi≈øhed, but in ordinary cour≈øe, Checkey & Allen.

Lambert contra Lambert, the Plaintiffe is to bee examined upon Interrogatories,
12. & 1.3. Eliz. fo. 380. Kent contra Benham, to examine the Plaintiffe at the hearing of the Cau≈øe, Pa≈øch. 6. Car.
Drury contra Drury, the Plaintiffe examined as a Witne≈ø≈øe in a Cau≈øe, and after becomes Plaintiff for the Intere≈øt in that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, allowed and not to be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, about 9. Car.
Smith contra Gabry, the Plaintiff relea≈øed out of Pri≈øon, though deteyned at other mens ≈øuits, becau≈øe he was arre≈øted when he was going about his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, or ≈øuit in Chancerie, 8. Car.
Major Bri≈øtoll contra Whit≈øon, the Plaintiff examined as a Witne≈ø≈øe, 8. Car.
Allen contra Allen, in Trin. 15. Car. the Plaintiff relieved for a debt again≈øt an heire in taile, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, to be e≈øtabli≈øhed with the Plaintiff till the heire in tayle recover at law.

div.head: Perpetuitie.
div.p: Perpetuitie. Poole contra Poole, the Court doth not allow of Perpetuities, nor of ≈øtatutes to warrant them, Pa≈øch. 5. Jac. li. B. fo. 619.
Bacon contra Smith, 12. Jac.
Hunt contra Bancroft, 14. Jac. Hill. & Mich. 15. Jac. fo. 455. & 883. li. B. & Pa≈øch. 16. Jac.
Hooe contra Arnold & al', about 17. Jac. the contrary.

div.head: Po≈ø≈øibilitie.
div.p: Po≈ø≈øibility relieved here. Romney contra Garnons & al', a Conveyance made to the Defendant to u≈øes, and to their heires, for want of i≈ø≈øue, then to ≈øuch child or children of Eliz. (one of them to whom the u≈øe was limitted) begotten of her former Husband, being the Plaintiffs Father, they to whom the u≈øe is lymitted dye without i≈ø≈øue, and before their death, did grant and devi≈øe the lands ≈øo in u≈øe to the Plaintiffe. It was thought good and decreed for the Plaintiff, it being but a po≈ø≈øibilitie in them, and contrary to the words of the fir≈øt intaile and grant, being lymitted to the Children, in 37. Eliz. li. A. fo. 286. & 949.

Though po≈ø≈øibility cannot by law bee di≈øpo≈øed of, yet by equitie. Povey contra Barker, a Demurrer, becau≈øe a Po≈ø≈øibilitie cannot be di≈øpo≈øed of, overruled notwith≈øtanding a Decree in the Marches, 9. Car.
Decreed here notwith≈øtanding a Decree in the Marches.

div.head: Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
div.p: Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Delahay & Pottenden, Mich. 39. & 40 Eliz. Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion as at time of Subpaena ≈øerved.
Row≈øwell contra Engli≈øh, Trin. 16. Iac.
Le Stationers London contra Simcox, the Court e≈øtabli≈øheth Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion untill Eviction at law again≈øt a Pattent, Mich. 7. Car.
Pleydall cont'‚ñ™ Prettiman. Mich. 12. Car. No advantage to be taken by unitie of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at law, being point of common; and after a tryall, a Commi≈ø≈øion to i≈ø≈øue out of Chancerie.
Wild contra Sliford, the Judges Certificate.
Berd contra Dormer, the Lord Keepers difference concerning unitie of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion when it continued in the Abbots hand, in Trin. 15. Car.

div.head: Plea.
div.p: Plea forraigne. Yelveyton contra Burtow, 1594. to bee ≈øworn to it, and to put in a Plea not forraigne.

over-ruled about 34, or 35. Eliz.

Cinque-Ports priviledged again≈øt Chancerie.

Harbie contra Salton≈øtall, in 5. Feb-1. & 3. Jac.
An Injunction out of the Exchequer di≈øallowed, and the partie which procured it ≈øent for it by a Pur≈øivant, becau≈øe her Maje≈øties Revenue not in que≈øtion here, Hartopp contra Hartop, in 1594.

Ellords widow, claymed her priviledge, becau≈øe her Husband was priviledged, and if it were for her Husbands act, it was holden cleere that ≈øhe ≈øhould be priviledged, but this was for her own act, and yet hac vice priviledged.
Lloyd contra Lloyd‚ñ™ Pa≈øch. 35. Eliz. but this is no order to priviledge others, in li. A.

Barkley contra Hu≈ø≈øey, the Defendant
not allowed his Priviledge, becau≈øe his wife joyned with him, 21. Nov. 32. Eliz.
Oxford priviledged again≈øt Chancery. Hopper contra Ea≈øtmond, 1587. in 33. Eliz. li. A. fo. 21.
Onewry contra Gla≈øier, Trin. 1588.
White contra Howger, in 17. & 18. Eliz. li. A.
Over-ruled between Horwood contra Smith, in Mich. 12. Iac. li. B. fo. 308.
Court of Reque≈øts not allowed Priviledge here, Garnons contra Maddox, 39. Eliz.
County Palatine of Che≈øter.
Any dwelling there, mu≈øt appeare upon the Proces, and plead their Priviledge, by the Ma≈øter of the Rolls opinion, in Herendens Ca≈øe in 36. & 37. Eliz.
Chancerie Priviledge. In what ca≈øes the Chancerie doth priviledge.
The Defendant comming to execute a Commi≈ø≈øion was arre≈øted, and had a Corpus cum Cau≈øa, and ≈øet him at libertie, Jack≈øon contra Vaughan, Trin. 23. Eliz.
Fowler contra Ayhur≈øt, removed from Roche≈øter, in 22. Eliz. li. B. fo. 557.

The Plaintiffe arre≈øted when he came up to examine Witne≈ø≈øes, and di≈øcharged by Super≈øedeas of Priviledge, Barnardi≈øton
contra Bawd, Trin. 1591. or 32. Eliz. fo. 738.

A Defendant comming up upon an Attachment would have had his Priviledge again≈øt a Citation in the Arches, and had not, becau≈øe a Citation is no ≈øtay of his per≈øon. Cooke contra D ‚Ä¢ x, Pa≈øch. 30. Eliz.
Mar≈øhall contra Moore, the Plaintiffe comming up to follow his ≈øuit halfe a yeare after his Bill exhibited was arre≈øted in London, and had his Priviledge 1588.
Hughes contra Middleton, in Hillary Terme, and paid co≈øts for the ≈øame 4. & 5. Car.
Diggs being committed by the Court of Reque≈øts for not an≈øwering a Bill there for the ≈øame matter for which hee had a Bill here, had a Corpus cum cau≈øa, in 36. Eliz. li. A. fo. 539.

Becau≈øe Ma≈øter Bridgeman ≈øerved a Clark in Ma≈øter Shugboroughs Office, a Commandement from _____ to ≈øtay here, he was committed to the Pri≈øon of the Fleet, at the ≈øuit of Carleton, Pa≈øch. 37. Eliz. li. A. fo. 135.
Inter Carleton & Bridgman, with the opinion of the Court, that no Court can hinder the point of Equitie of this Court.
Binion contra Thimble, in Pa≈øch. 1632. or 1633. concerning the Priviledge of the Univer≈øity of Oxon.

Morgan contra Richard≈øon, & al', the Plaintiffe having a Writ of Priviledge was taken in Execution, ordered to goe abroad by Habeas corpus, and the partie that arre≈øted him to be committed, about Hill. 17. or 18. Jac.
Iohn≈øon contra Obbin, the Plaintiffe delivered out of Execution, 12. & 13. Eliz. fo. 238. li. A.
Mathew contra Com' Arundell, a Demurrer, becau≈øe an Exchequer-man, overruled, 6. Car. li. B.
Welbore cont' Collins, concerning Kings Colledge in Cambridge over-ruled, 7. Car.
Bancks Attorney Dom' Regis by Information, where an Inqui≈øition was awarded to inquire of Rookes E≈øtate in the Cinque-Port of Sandwich, a Writ of ≈øeizure awarded about 11. Car.

Pepwell contra Gold≈ømiths London, an Attorney at Law joynes with another in Action, thereby to avoyd a priviledged man in this Court, the ≈øuit ≈øtayd, and the Priviledge allowed, in 28. Eliz. fo. 247.
Mo≈øtin contra Thomas, though the Defendant (a Clerke in the Court of Reque≈øts) becau≈øe the ≈øuit had prioritie there, Demurred in re≈øpect of that, and of Priviledge over-ruled, in Hill. 14. Car.

div.head: Partition.
div.p: Partition. Long contra Miller, Mich. 1594. An unequall Partition relieved here.

In Equity where none by law. Speke the Plaintiffe had one part, Walrond the Defendant another, and Morgan a Ward another, and Walrond overcharged Speke, and Morgan had his part ≈øet out by Commi≈ø≈øion, and no Partition could be had again≈øt Walrond, without making the Ward partie to the Writ, which he could not doe during the Wards Minoritie therefore thought meet the Plaintiffe ≈øhould bee holpen in Equitie during the Minoritie, Hill. 40. Eliz.
Nor≈øe contra Ludlow, a Decree that two Partners which have made an unequall divi≈øion, ≈øhould be divided into Equalitie, in 32. Eliz. li. A. fo. 404.
Broughton contra Broughton, Hill. 28. & 29. Eliz. li. B. fo. 264. whether a Partition made without writing, be good or not Quere.

Babb contra Dudeney, in Mich. 14. Car. the Court would not grant a Partition, the matter being but nine pounds per Annum. Norbury contra Yarbury, otherwi≈øe, this is upon a Joyntenancy, in Mich. or Hill. 14. Car.
Windham contra Weare, 15 Car.

div.head: Po≈ø≈øe Comitatus.
div.p:
Po≈ø≈øe Comit' awarded.
Sidenham contra Courtney, Po≈ø≈øe Comit' awarded to be taken, 41. Eliz. li. B. fo. 324.
Harrington contra Horton & Cox, about Mich. 16. Iac. li. A. fo. 9.

div.head: Proces.
div.p: Proces of Record.All Proces that goe in affirmance of the Recognizance mu≈øt go into the ≈øame Countrie where the fir≈øt Scire Facius goeth, it is not ≈øo in the≈øe which goe in di≈ø-affirmance, Ha≈øelwood & White, 30. Eliz.

No Clerkes of this Court ≈øhall make out Proces of Subpoena again≈øt any to te≈øtifie before any Officer, unle≈ø≈øe it be before a Judge, or Commi≈ø≈øioners warranted and Authori≈øed by this Court, to take examinations of Witne≈ø≈øes, 11. & 12. Eliz. li. A. fo. 28.

div.head: Perjurie.
div.p: Perjury puni≈øht.In the Judgement Roll 37. H. 8. between Baskervile and Guilliams, ≈øet on the Pillo ‚Ä¢ y for procuring Perjurie in the Spirituall Court.
And 16. Eliz. fo. 17. between Sider≈øon & E ‚Ä¢ ≈øtcourt.
Bullen contra Bullen, 44. & 45. Eliz. li. B. fo. 170.
Freeborne contra Lea≈øure, in Trin. 20. Jac. li. B. fo.

Perjurie to bee examined here, Hal≈øe
contra Browne, notwith≈øtanding the Cau≈øe was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, 16. Eliz. fo. 401.
Puni≈øhed upon hearing. Mound contra Culme, 40 pounds Co≈øts given for Perjurie, in Mich. 14. Car.

div.head: Proceedings.
div.p: The Court proceeds, becau≈øe the Defendant would not An≈øwer or appeare,Procedings. Michell contra Harry in Mati 39. Eliz. fo. 775.

div.head: Purcha≈øors.
div.p: Purcha≈øors favoured. Vava≈øor, or Wa≈øerer contra Row, in 33. & 34. Eliz. the ≈øaid Plaintiffe bought land of one who had no power to ≈øell and moved, that if the Defendant ≈øhould be compelled to bring in the Lea≈øes, which might incumber the Plaintiffs purcha≈øe, then the plaintiffe might bring in the antient Evidences which might di≈øcover, that he which ≈øold to the Plaintiffe, had no power to ≈øell, the Court An≈øwered, that no Ayd ≈øhould be given to overthrow Purcha≈øes made bona fide.

Not charged by any collaterall Agreement after the ≈øale. Smith contra Killigrew, & Ognell, in 34 & 35. Eliz. li. A. fo. 88. Ognell would have charged land purcha≈øed by the Plaintiffe of Killigrew, by a former _____ becau≈øe a Collaterall which grew after the Plaintiffs purcha≈øe was not performed; It was thought no rea≈øon to load the land with heavy Agreement, after Smith purcha≈øe. Hall contra Often, 3. Jac.

Favoured. The Court would not ≈øtay a Purcha≈øor from felling of woods, though the Vendor had an E≈øtate for life.
‚Ä¢ irringham contra Eyres. 37. Eliz. and the Court would not bar him remedie at law, upon any Evidence he could produce.

Buying land of Feoffees relieved though a Verdict at law again≈øt them. Bani≈øter contra Brooke, a man po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a Lea≈øe for Fifty years, he dying inte≈øtate, the Wife Admini≈øters, and makes a Feoffement to her own u≈øe, a little before her Marriage with a ≈øecond Husband, the Feoffees ≈øell the land for valuable con≈øideration, and was enjoyed many years accordingly: After the Wives death, the ≈øecond Husband would avoyd this purcha≈øe by rea≈øon of the u≈øe‚ñ™ the Court decreed that the Purcha≈øors ≈øhould enjoy it, notwith≈øtanding a Verdict at law, in Mich. 17. Iac. li A. fo. 413.
Relieved again≈øt breach of Condition. Swan contra Rogers, Mich. 9. Iac. li. A. fo. 305. the Court relieveth the Purcha≈øor again≈øt a breach of Condition.
Burlace contra Burrell‚ñ™ in Pa≈øch. 19. Iac. li. B. fo. 1244. being a Purcha≈øor.
Stonehou≈øe contra Dell, the contrary in 10. Iac. li. B fo. 274.
Buller contra Smith, in Trin. 15. Car.

Stile cont' Michell, in Pa≈øch. 19. Iac. li. A.
Dimmock contra Williams, in Mich. 16. Jac. li. A. fo.

Garfield contra Humble, in 16. Jac.

Eliz. li. A. fo. 713. & 42. Eliz. li. B. fo. 289.

Helam contra Colt, in 9 Car.
Relieved again≈øt ≈øtatute upon a ≈øecond Agreement. Boll contra Hancock, in Octob. 11. Jac. A Purcha≈øor relieved again≈øt a ≈øtatute.

Li≈øter contra Harri≈øon, a Purcha≈øor relieved again≈øt a ≈øtatute in 9 Jac. li. B. fo. 619. ≈øought to bee extended by a ≈øecond
Agreement after the Purcha≈øe.

Relieved again≈øt a voluntary conveyance. Relieved again≈øt a ≈øtat. for performance of Covenants. Chandler contra Dawtree, in 41. Eliz. li. B. fo. 480, The opinion of the Court, that a ≈øtatute for performance of Covenants, ought not to take away the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a Purcha≈øor.

Having no notice ≈øhall not be charged. Maynard contra Pauperes de Ea≈øt-Green≈øted, a Purcha≈øor that comes in without notice of a Rent-charge, ≈øhall not bee chargeable therewith, although given to a charitable u≈øe in 6. Car. l ‚Ä¢ . B.
Rutter contra Bartley, Purcha≈øors relieved of a ≈øleeping Mortgage, in Mich. 2. Car.

Comes B ≈øt ‚Ä¢ ll contra Hamond, the Defendant would avoyd a Lea≈øe again≈øt a Purcha≈øor upon proofe that the Lea≈øe was made by one of Non ≈øane memoriae. and that point of parcell is determinable at law, the Lea≈øe decreed, 9. Car.

The like between Nurton & Nurton, 9. Jac.

To prohibit a Purcha≈øor to bring Audita querela.
Thoruburgh contra Grobham, about 17. Jac. a Purcha≈øor for a valuable con≈øideration re≈øtrained from bringing an Audita querela upon pretence that a Purcha≈øor had levied moneys upon other ≈øecurities.

div.head: Procedendo.
div.p:
Procedendo awarded, becau≈øe the Certiorari had a long returne.Becau≈øe a Certiorari was made with a long return (skipping a Terme) a Procedendo
was awarded, A≈øhley contra God≈øer 36. H. 8. fo. 30.

div.head: Promi≈øe.
div.p: A remedy for a promi≈øe. Where the Law cannot give a Lea≈øe, or a thing promi≈øed but damage, there is ≈øome cau≈øe for the Court to compell the partie to performe the thing promi≈øed, Browne contra North. Waller contra Salter, in Trin. 8. Jac. li. A.
Ferne contra Bullock, Mich. 9. Jac. li. A. fo. 274. the Defendant promi≈øed to ≈øell the Plaintiffe land, whereof ten ≈øhillings was given him, yet the Defendant would not performe, yet he ≈øhould.
Clarke contra Hackwell, in 3. Jac. li. A. fo. 596. Five pounds paid, Decreed.
Long contra Long, in 40. Eliz. li. A. fo. 360. or 369. the Defendant promi≈øed and agreed to a≈ø≈øure Lea≈øes in Marriage with the Plaintiffs Daughters, who would not performe it, but Ordered.
To a≈ø≈øure lands marriage ordered.A man promi≈øeth to a≈ø≈øure lands in con≈øideration of Marriage, but after the Marriage refu≈øeth, yet ordered, Gerards Ca≈øe, in 2. Jac. li. A. fo. 202.
Fox contra Fox, in 8. Iac. li. B. fo. 248.

div.p:

hearing, he after her death, exhibited a Bi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of Revivor, and ≈øerved Proces to hea ‚Ä¢ Judgement, yet upon an objection, that th ‚Ä¢ Defendant ≈øhould fir≈øt have been calle ‚Ä¢ to An≈øwer, the hearing was put off 1591.
