div.head: THE PROCEEDINGS of the High-Court of CHANCERIE.
div.p: NOtwith≈øtanding the practi≈øe here before this time hath been, That no Subpoena ≈øhould be ≈øued forth of the court of Chancery without a bil of complaint fir≈øt exhibited: yet of late, for the ea≈øe of all ≈øuiters and ≈øubjects, it hath been thought good, that every man may have a Subpoena out of the ≈øame Court, without any Bill fir≈øt exhibited.
And this is called a Sub poena adre≈øpondendum.

This Sub paena is the leading Proce≈ø≈øe of this Court, by which the party defendant again≈øt whom the complaint is intended, is ≈øummoned and required to appeare and make an≈øwer to the complainant, under a certaine paine, and at a certaine day to come.

The dayes of Returne here are the u≈øuall Returnes, as in the ordinary Almanack; or el≈øe a Sub poena may be returneable at a certaine day, after any the ≈øaid u≈øuall Returnes, or the great Fea≈øt dayes, from whence the Returnes take their denomination: So that you mu≈øt adde (prox') in place where cau≈øe ≈øhall require.
As, if the Fea≈øt day be to come, then it mu≈øt bee Prox. futur. in unum men≈øem.
But if the Fea≈øt day be pa≈øt, then it mu≈øt be die Pa≈øchae in unum men≈øem prox futur.
And the like to other Returns, before or after other Fea≈øt dayes.

Where, note what time you have for exhibiting of your Bill after the day of Returne prefixed in your writ of Sub-p ‚Ä¢ na: If it be returneable upon a general Returne day, as Cra≈øtin', Octabis,
Tres, Men≈ø, &c. after ≈øuch a Fea≈øt, then you have time to put in your Bill uutill the ≈øecond day before noone next following, the fourth day following every of the ≈øaid Returnes: and you mu≈øt account the Returne day, and the fourth day after it, for two of the ≈øaid foure dayes.
But if the Sub-paena be returneable on ≈øuch a certaine day of the month, then your Bill mu≈øt be put in the ≈øecond day after it before dinner.

And how≈øoever the Sub-paena be returneable, if it bee but ≈øerved on the ≈øame day whereon it is returneable, before noone, and the ri≈øing of the Court of Chancery, it is a good ≈øerving, and binds the defendant ≈øo ≈øerved to an appearance with all convenient ≈øpeed.

If a Sub paena be returneable on a day certaine, as on any day of the moneth, the bill not being in, the de≈øendants Atturney may prefer co≈øts the next day after; and if the bill come not in the next day after co≈øts ≈øo preferred before noone or pre≈øently after dinner, the defendant is di≈øcharged with ≈øuch co≈øts as a Ma≈øter of the Court taxes him.

And ≈øo in the like ca≈øe for a Sub paena
that is returnable on a returne day, the next day after the fourth day is co≈øt day, and if the bill come not in the next day at noon or pre≈øently after dinner, the defendant, having preferred his co≈øts the day before, is di≈øcharged from attendance, with his co≈øts.

When the defendant hath ≈øo got co≈øts, he may have a Sub paena whereby to command the complainant pre≈øently, upon the ≈øight thereof, to pay the defendant or the bringer thereof, the ≈øaid co≈øts, (as afore≈øaid:) Which Sub-paena mu≈øt be ≈øerved on the Plaintiffe per≈øonally. And if the complainant doe refu≈øe to pay the ≈øaid co≈øts accordingly, then the defendant may, upon Affidavit made that the Sub-paena for co≈øt was ≈øerved, have an Attachment directed to the Sheriffe of the County, to attach the complainant therefore.
And upon returne made by the Sheriffe that the complainant cannot be found, an Attachment with Proclamation may be ≈øued forth again≈øt the complainant.

And that Proclamation being likewi≈øe returned by the Sheriffe (as afore≈øaid) then a Commi≈ø≈øion of Rebellion
may be ≈øued forth again≈øt the complainant.

But on the contrary, if the complainant doe put in his bill, and the defendant appeareth not the next day after co≈øts day (which co≈øts day is u≈øually the next day after the foure dayes upon a returne is out, or if the Sub-paena be returnable on a day certaine, then the next day after is co≈øts day) then the complainant upon oath made that the defendant was ≈øerved with a Sub-paena, may have an Attachment, and further Proce≈ø≈øe upon the Sheriffes returnes of non e≈øt inventus.
Where note, that the party which maketh oath that hee ≈øerved the Sub paena: Or that the Sub-paena was ≈øerved, mu≈øt ≈øweare as followeth:
That he delivered the Sub paena to the defendant.
Or he ≈øhewed the Sub paena to the defendant under the ≈øeale of the Court, and delivered to him a note of the day of his appearance, or a labell of the Sub paena.
Or he left the Sub paena at the defendants dwelling hou≈øe or lodging, where the defendant mo≈øt abideth.

Or he mu≈øt ≈øweare that he heard the
defendant confe≈ø≈øe that he was ≈øerved with a Sub-paena.
Or he mu≈øt ≈øweare that he ≈øaw another ≈øerve the defendant with a Sub-paena.

Note, that if the party ≈øerved with any ≈øuch Sub-paena doe wrong or abu≈øe the party who ≈øerved it for the ≈øerving thereof, or u≈øeth: any words of contempt or ≈øleighting of his Maje≈øties ≈øaid Writ; upon oath made thereof, and motion thereupon, he is puni≈øhable for the ≈øame, by impri≈øonment in the Fleet, or otherwi≈øe at the Lord Keepers di≈øcretion.

And if the defendant do appeare within the time limited, then the complaynants Atturney may give unto the defendants Atturney, on the ≈øaid day after the co≈øts day, a Rule, that the defendant doe make an≈øwer to the complainants Bill, by the ≈øame day ≈øeven-night then next to come. This Rule and day given, mu≈øt be entred into the Regi≈øter.

And if the defendant doe not an≈øwer by the prefixed day ≈øo entred; or if he doe not otherwi≈øe ≈øatisfie the Court by ≈øufficient cau≈øe, and occa≈øion of the delay, then the complainants Atturney may take forth an Attachment again≈øt the defendent.

div.head: The Cau≈øes whereby the defendant may ≈øatisfie the Court of the ≈øaid delay in an≈øwer, are the≈øe, for the mo≈øt part, of which the defendant mu≈øt make oath, (viz.)
div.p: HEe cannot make direct an≈øwer, without ≈øight of his Evidences or Writings which are in the Countrey.
Or he cannot an≈øwer without conference had fir≈øt with ≈øome Per≈øon named in the ≈øaid Bill.
Or with ≈øome Per≈øon whom the matter toucheth.

Or if the Bill be again≈øt the defendant, to expre≈ø≈øe what goods he hath of the plaintiffes, he may make oath he cannot make perfect an≈øwer to the plaintiffes bill without ≈øight and peru≈øall of the ≈øaid goods, which are in the countrey: And that place in the countrey, where tho≈øe goods or writings, or parties live, mu≈øt be above twenty miles from London, or el≈øe he mu≈øt an≈øwer within eight dayes after his appearance, unle≈ø≈øe he get further time by order: And, if he doe make ≈øuch oath, then his an≈øwer is ≈øpared till the fir≈øt day of the next Terme following.
This oath be made by the Solicitor, or ≈øome oother for the defendant.Or that the defendant is not able to Travell without danger of his life, &c.

And if upon ≈øuch oath made, the plaintiffe refu≈øe to allow the defendant a Dedimus pote≈øtatem for taking his an≈øwer in the Countrey, the Court upon motion or petition will order it; which order is to be entred in the Regi≈øter, and the Affidavit filed in the Affidavit Office.

In ca≈øe the defendant doe not appear, or having appeared doth not an≈øwer in his time limited, nor ≈øheweth any of the afore≈øaid rea≈øons in excu≈øe, then an Attachment is awarded again≈øt him, which mu≈øt be entred both in the hou≈øe-book in the ≈øix Clerks Office, and in the Regi≈øter, expre≈ø≈øing the cau≈øe of the i≈ø≈øuing of the ≈øaid Attachment.
But if no day be given to the defendant to an≈øwer, then the defendant hath liberty to an≈øwer at any time during the Terme.

And if he doe it not within that time, hen an attachment may be ≈øued forth gain≈øt him of cou ‚Ä¢ ≈øe: and the ≈øame, with the cau≈øe thereof, mu≈øt be entered into the Regi≈øter: (viz.) That the Defendant appeared, and departed without an≈øw ‚Ä¢ r.

If the Sub-paena be returnable ≈øo nere the end of the Terme, that there cannot be a day given to the defendant to an≈øwer, he mu≈øt at his perill an≈øwer by the ≈øame day ≈øevennight following the day of his appearance, although it be in the Vacation: For the Chancery is alwaies open. It is Officina ≈øemper aperta.
If the Sub paena be returnable on the la≈øt returne day of the Terme it ≈øelfe, then the defendant is at liberty to apapeare the fir≈øt Returne of the Terme following.
But if it be a day certain, although the ≈øame be the la≈øt day of the Terme, yet the Defendant mu≈øt appeare and an≈øwer by that day ≈øevenight next following the ≈øaid appearance.
Note, there are no ≈øuch Sub-paenas to an≈øwer returnable immediately in Terme time.

And if the defendant make Oath that he cannot an≈øwer without Writings &c. or conference with ≈øome other per≈øon: Or if he have a Dedimus Pote≈øtatem, & Commi≈ø≈øion to make his an≈øwer he mu≈øt at his perill procure his an≈øwer to be put in before the day after the fir≈øt Co≈øts day of the next Terme following, unle≈ø≈øe
it be Trinity Terme; and then, and in ≈øuch ca≈øe, it mu≈øt be put in the ≈øecond day after the ≈øecond returne, el≈øe the complainants Attorney may, upon ≈øuch default, make an attachment again≈øt the defendant, and enter the ≈øame into the Regi≈øter, For that he hath not an≈øwered by the day prefixed.
Or in other ca≈øe, that he appeared and departed without an≈øwer; Or otherwi≈øe that he did not returne the Dedimus potestatem at the day prefixed, &c. and as the cau≈øe ≈øhall require.

If a Defendant living in the Country, having a Dodimus Pote≈øtatem granted him for the taking of his an≈øwer to the Plaintiffes Bill, or his Councell finde there is cau≈øe of Plea or Demurrer, upon a motion or petition, he may have a ≈øpeciall Dedimus Pote≈øtatem by Order to an≈øwer, plead, or demur; But the Commi≈ø≈øioners upon an ordinary Dedimus have no power to take any thing but an an≈øwer; And if a Demurrer be put in without Commi≈ø≈øion, the party mu≈øt put the ≈øame in into the ≈øix Clerks Office in his owne per≈øon: And if the Demurrer or Plea be not put into the Paper of Pleas and Demurrers in the
Regi≈øter appointed for that purpo≈øe, within eight daies after the ≈øame is put in Court, to the end the ≈øame bee argued before the Lord Keeper, as it ≈øhall fall in cour≈øe after others; then the ≈øaid Plea and Demurrer is over-ruled of cour≈øe, and the Plaintiffe may take forth a Sub-paena again≈øt the Defendant to make a better an≈øwer, and an other for Co≈øts, according to the Lord Keepers late Orders.
This was wont to be the cour≈øe, but my Lord Keeper of late hath declared, that if a bill have cau≈øe of Demurrer he will not a bad bill good.

In ca≈øe a man be ≈øerved with a Subpaena wherein his wife is named he being in London and his wife in the country or el≈øewhere, if he appeare not for her, or ≈øhe an≈øwer not as well as hee, an Attachment is granted again≈øt them both though he appeare and an≈øwer for him≈øelfe.
If ≈øhee doe not appeare, then the Attachment is again≈øt him and her for her not appearance.
If ≈øhee doe not an≈øwer, then again≈øt him and her for her not an≈øwering.

If a Complainant die depending the
≈øuite, his Heire, Executor, or Admini≈øtrator, who hath the Intere≈øt in the thing complained for, may put in a Bill of Revivor again≈øt the Defendant: or if the Defendant die, the Plaintiffe may put in a Bill of Revivor again≈øt his Heire, Executor or Admini≈øtrator.

Al≈øo it is to be remembered, that if the Complainant exhibit his Bill again≈øt a man and his wife, for matter which wholly concerneth the wife, whereunto they make an≈øwer, & after an≈øwer made, the man dyeth; the Complainant cannot proceed in that ≈øuit again≈øt the woman without a Bill of Revivor, becau≈øe the woman ≈øhall not be con≈øtrained to ≈øtand to that an≈øwer, which ≈øhe together with her Husband or ≈øolely (as wife unto the man) made to the Complainant, for that ≈øhe was the under Coverture.

And after her husbands death (≈øhee being ≈øeized or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the thing in Controver≈øie as in her former e≈øtate) may (if ≈øhee plea≈øe) make a new an≈øwer, and ≈øhall never be bound or concluded by the an≈øwer which ≈øhee made in her Husbands life time, for that ≈øhee was then under Coverture. And yet (if ≈øhee ≈øo plea≈øe) ≈øhe may ≈øtand to that former an≈øwer of hers and proceed in that ≈øuite accordingly.

But if the Complainant exhibite a Bill again≈øt a Feme ≈øole, whereunto ≈øhe maketh an≈øwer, and afterwards marrieth, the Complainant may proceed again≈øt her husband and her without any Bill of Revivor: and her, husband ≈øhall be bound by that an≈øwer which ≈øhe made before marriage, becau≈øe ≈øhe ≈øhall not be admitted to take advantage of her owne act.

Where (on the contrary) if a Feme ≈øole exhibite her bill of Complaint, whereunto the Defendant an≈øwereth, and afterwards ≈øhe taketh an husband, her husband and ≈øhee ≈øhall not proceed again≈øt the Defendant, without a Bill of Revivor; becau≈øe her ≈øuite is abated by her owne act, whereof the Defendant may take advantage.

And if a Man and his Wife exhite a Bill of Complaint, whereunto the Defendant an≈øwereth and the Man dyeth, the woman ≈øhall be at her choice whether ≈øhe will exhibite a new Bill, or proceed upon the former.
Note that in Chancery you cannot ≈øerve the Wife without her husband, though the matter in que≈øtion doe only concerne her, and not him.

Al≈øo, if two ≈øeized of joynt e≈øtate; or two Executors of one Te≈øtament; or two Obligers or Obligees exhibite a Bill of Complaint, whereunto the Defendant an≈øwereth, and one of them dyeth. The Survivor of them may proceed again≈øt the Defendant, without any Bill of Revivor.

And in all ca≈øes where a Bill of Revivor is requi≈øite after the ≈øaid Bill exhibited, and a Sub-paena ≈øerved on the Defendant to that purpo≈øe: the Complainant ≈øhall be in the ≈øame ca≈øe, as hee for his Predece≈ø≈øor was, at the time when the cau≈øe of Revivor accrewed, unle≈ø≈øe the Defendant ≈øhall appear upon the ≈øaid Sub-paena, and by way of an≈øwer ≈øhew good cau≈øe to the contrary: which Cau≈øe mu≈øt be, that the Complainant in the Bill of Revivor, is not Heire, or Executor, nor ≈øtandeth in the like ca≈øe, nor have the like intere≈øt, or the like cau≈øe of Complaint, as before in the former ≈øuite.

And no other cau≈øe is to be allowed. If the Complaynant exhibite his Bill of Complaint, for Title of any Lands, not of the yearely value of forty ≈øhillings: And the ≈øame be proved by Affidavit,
or depo≈øed, the Defendant ≈øhall be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.
Al≈øo, if the Defendant demurte to any Bill exhibited again≈øt him, or di≈øclaime: the Complaynant cannot reply:
For if the Defendant be called up by Sub-paena ad Rejungendum, having before made no other an≈øwer but a Demurer or a Di≈øclaimer, he ≈øhal have co≈øts for unju≈øt vexation.

But after the Defendant hath an≈øwered, the Complaynant hath liberty all that Terme, and all the next Terme following that; and untill the beginning of the ≈øecond Terme after an≈øwer, to put in his Replication.

The next Terme after an≈øwer put in, the Defendants Atturney may give the Plaintiffe a Rule to Reply, and if hee doth not Reply, then co≈øts are awarded, and if he give no Rule and the Plaintiffe reply not the ≈øecond Terme after the Terme the An≈øwer was put in, the Bill may be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with co≈øts by morgage or of cour≈øe.
But if the Complaynants Replication be put into the Court, the Defendant can have no co≈øts allowed unto him.
But then the Defendant may, if he ‚Ä¢ will, Rejoyne gratis to the Replication, and enforce the Complainant to goe to Commi≈ø≈øion.
Which if the Complainant refu≈øe, then the Defendant may have Commi≈ø≈øion to examine Witne≈ø≈øes on his owne part again≈øt the Complainant, and ≈øhall have the carriage thereof.
The Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øhall be directed to foure ≈øuch per≈øons as the Defendant ≈øhal name; or to any three or two of them, without any warning to be given to the Complainant.
But if in this ca≈øe the Complainant will, he may joyne in Commi≈ø≈øion, and have the carriage of it him≈øelfe.

And then he mu≈øt name foure Commi≈ø≈øioners indifferent men; and the Defendant foure more, and two being ≈øtrook out on each ≈øide the Commi≈ø≈øion is made up to the foure that remaine: and the Complainant having the carriage of the Commi≈ø≈øion mu≈øt give the Defendant fourteen dayes warning of the day and place when and where the Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øhall be executed.

This warning mu≈øt be given, either by him≈øelfe in per≈øon, or el≈øe left in
Writing, at the Hou≈øe or place where the Defendant doth mo≈øt re≈øide.

The Complainant in all ca≈øes of Commi≈ø≈øion to examine witne≈ø≈øes, ≈øhall have the fir≈øt choice of Commi≈ø≈øioners, and carriage of the Commi≈ø≈øion, and if hee faile by not executing it, then the Defendant may renew it and have the carriage thereof, and give the Complaynant the like notice.

If a Defendant be ≈øerved with a Sub-paena ad Rejungendum, and Oath be thereof made; Commi≈ø≈øioners names being called for in the Terme time to the Defendants Atturney, and the Defendant refu≈øe to joyne in Commi≈ø≈øion the ≈øecond Seale after the Terme, the Complainants Atturney may make a Commi≈ø≈øion ex parte to the Complaynants owne Commi≈ø≈øioners and Intere≈ø≈øers mu≈øt be included in the Commi≈ø≈øion
He ≈øhall examine Witne≈ø≈øes, in all the≈øe ca≈øes following: (Viz.)

FIr≈øt, upon a Bill by him preferred to examine Witne≈ø≈øes in perpetuall memory of the matter to command the Defendant either by him≈øelfe, or by his Atturney to appeare immediatly; and within fourteen dayes to ≈øhew cau≈øe why the Complaynant ≈øhould not examine
Witne≈ø≈øes ‚Ä¢ in perpetuall memory.

And if the Defeudant doe thereupon appeare by him≈øelf, or his Attourney, and ≈øhew good cau≈øe to the contrary, ≈øuch as the court ≈øhal allow, then the Complaynant ≈øhall not examine any witne≈ø≈øes in perpetuam rei memoriam, or perpetual memory.

But if he doe ≈øhew no ≈øufficient cau≈øe, nor joyne in Commi≈ø≈øion with the complainant, then the Complainants Atturney mu≈øt preferre ≈øix Commi≈ø≈øioners names to the Lord Keeper, or the court, &c. Foure of the which, or foure ≈øuch other, as the Lord Keeper or the court ≈øhall appoint, ≈øhall be ≈øet downe for Commi≈ø≈øioners; and a Commi≈ø≈øion for the Complaynant ≈øhall be made forth, and directed to the ≈øaid foure Commi≈ø≈øioners, or any three, or two of them, to examine witne≈ø≈øes, according to certaine Articles heretofore ≈øet downe in Chancery, which Witne≈ø≈øes are never to be publi≈øhed, during their lives, unle≈ø≈øe Oath be made.
That the Complainant hath ≈øome tryall wherin he ≈øhould give them in evidence
That the witne≈ø≈øes are notable to travel to the place where the tryal ≈øhould be.
Or the Party Defendant will con≈øent thereunto.

Neither can they be given in Evidence again≈øt another, but again≈øt the party which was called, to ≈øhew cau≈øe why the ≈øaid witne≈ø≈øes ≈øhould not be examined, or ≈øome other, claiming under him by ≈øome intere≈øt which accrewed unto them, after the Bill preferred by the Complainant for the examination of witne≈ø≈øes.
It is al≈øo u≈øed, that either party, after the Bill is exhibited, add An≈øwer made thereunto, may examine witne≈ø≈øes in court here before one of the Examiners.

But the Complainant can have no Commi≈ø≈øion to examine his witne≈ø≈øes, unle≈ø≈øe, and before the Defendant be ≈øerved with a Sub-paena ad Rejungendum: Which Sub-paena mu≈øt be ≈øerved in ≈øuch manner as is before mentioned:

And then upon Affidavit made of the ≈øerving thereof, the Complaynant (if the Defendant appeare not that Term) ≈øhall have a Commi≈ø≈øion directed to foure ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øioners as him≈øelfe ≈øhall name, or to any three, or two of them, for the examination of witne≈ø≈øes on his part, again≈øt the Defendant, without any warrant to be given to the Defendant.
Vpon the returne of the ≈øaid Sub ‚Ä¢ pae. na ad Rejungendum, The Complainant may give to the Defendant a day to Rejoyne (viz.) The ≈øame day ≈øeven-night.
By which time, if the Defendant doe not rejoyne, hee ≈øhall lo≈øe the benefit thereof.
And when that day ≈øo given to rejoyn; is pa≈øt, the Complainant may give two ordinary dayes, (viz.) two Returnes, for the Defendant to produce his witne≈ø≈øes; and then a Peremptory day:

Before which day pa≈øt, if the Defendant doe come in, he may have a Commi≈ø≈øion to examine witne≈ø≈øes of cour≈øe, without any motion; but he ≈øhall lo≈øe the benefit of Rejoynder: And the Complainant, if he plea≈øe to joyne in the Commi≈ø≈øion, ≈øhall have the carriage of it, giving to the Defendant fourteen dayes warning of the day and place, when and where the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øhall be executed.
In the joyning of this Commi≈ø≈øion, the Complainant mu≈øt fir≈øt name one Commi≈ø≈øioner, unto whom the Defendant may give generall exception:
The Defendant mu≈øt name the ≈øecond; The Complainant the third; And the Defendant the fourth.

div.head: The common exceptions which be given to Commi≈ø≈øioners are the≈øe, (viz.)
div.p: THat the Commi≈ø≈øioner named, is of Kinred or Allyed to the party, for whom he is named:
That he is a Ma≈øter to the partie:
That he is a Land-lord unto him:
Or a Partner unto him:
Or have ≈øuite in Law with the adver≈øe partie to him, by and for whom he is named:
Or is it of Coun≈øell, an Atturney, or a follower of the cau≈øe of the one party:
Or to whom the party is indebted:
Or any other apparent cau≈øe of partiality, or ≈øiding with either party.
And it is commonly u≈øed, that either party may give exception to one, and they ≈øeldom give exception to any more then one, on either party.
And yet neverthele≈ø≈øe, the Complaynants Atturney may if the Complainant will, renew the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øion al≈øo and give the like warning al≈øo unto the Defendant, if the Defendant renue it not.

Vpon the execution of either of
which Commi≈ø≈øions and return whereof either of them may give to the other a Rule for publication, thus, viz. dies dat defend publicat. ≈øuper Commi≈ø. junct. If the Defendant give the Rule, then thus: dies dat quer pro public. ≈øuper Commi≈ø. junct.

The day ≈øo given, is one week; which being expired, and no cau≈øe ≈øhewed to the contrary, then Publication is granted; and neither party can examine any witne≈ø≈øes afterwards, unle≈ø≈øe it be by ≈øpeciall order of the Court; which is never granted without an Oath made, that the party which requireth the ≈øame, nor any of them hath ≈øeen, or been made privy to any examination of any of the Witne≈ø≈øes formerly examined in this Court by either of the parties: And ≈øome good cau≈øe be ≈øhown, either by oath, or certificate of Commi≈ø≈øioners, why the party could not get his ≈øaid witne≈ø≈øes examined within the time limited for their examination.
In which ca≈øe, ≈øometimes the Court giveth order to examine witne≈ø≈øes by a time prefixed, with this Provi≈øo; That the party ≈øhall not in the meane time ≈øee the ≈øaid former examination.

And ≈øometimes the Court giveth Order
that the ≈øaid party ≈øhall examine his witne≈ø≈øes, to informe the con≈øcience of the Judge only and not otherwi≈øe.

The≈øe Depo≈øitions are never publi≈øht, but by e≈øpeciall order or con≈øent of the parties; but delivered to the Judge, ≈øealed up by the Officer, under who≈øe cu≈øtody they doe remaine, to the end he may peru≈øe them.

If any one be called by a Sub paena, to appeare in this Court: And upon his appearance, the Complainant or any other doth arre≈øt him in any other court; he ≈øhall have a Super≈øedeas to di≈øcharge the Action, becau≈øe he mu≈øt have free going and free comming.

But it is not ≈øo, if the Complainant be arre≈øted, except it be after i≈ø≈øue is joyned, and a day is given for the matter to be heard. And the Complaynant comming to the Court, with evidence to maintaine his cau≈øe, is arre≈øted: The Court in this ca≈øe ≈øhall defend him, and ≈øet him free to follow his ≈øuite.
But this is ≈øeldome ≈øeen: And hee that is Plaintiffe in the other Court, may declare, again≈øt him here Prae≈øentem in curia, if he plea≈øe. See 37. Eliz.

If any one who hath Priviledge in
Chaucery, arre≈øted into another Court, in a joynt-action with his Wife, for matter concerning her: Notwith≈øtanding the Coverture, ≈øhe ≈øhall not have any benefit of Priviledge here. See Powles ca≈øe.
The Clerkes of Chaucery are to be ≈øued in this Court, either by Latine or Engli≈øh Plea.

div.head: The Order made and ordained by Sir Nicholas Bacon, Knight, Lora Keeper of the Great Seale, touching the Examination of witne≈ø≈øes (in perpetuam rei memoriam:) Dated the tenth of December, in the third year of the late Q. Eliz. follow. eth.
div.p: FIr≈øt the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall examine no Witne≈ø≈øes, but ≈øuch as be aged and impotent.

Item, the Complaynant, or party, who ≈øueth forth the Commi≈ø≈øion, ≈øhall give warning by precept from the Commi≈ø≈øioners, unto the party that ≈øhould take prejudice by this examination, by the ≈øpace of fourteen dayes at the lea≈øt, of the time, and place; when, and where the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners wil ≈øit upon this Commi≈ø≈øion.

And the ≈øame warning being ≈øo given, the Commi≈ø≈øioners are to be ≈øatisfied by the Oath of the party complainant, or of ≈øome other credible per≈øon that warning is given accordingly, before they ≈øhall proceed to the execution of their Commi≈ø≈øion.

Item, If the party Adver≈øant, or Defendant can ≈øhew before the Commi≈ø≈øioners good cau≈øe of exception, either again≈øt the witne≈ø≈øes produced by the complainant, or any of them, or again≈øt the Commi≈øsioners them≈øelves; or otherwi≈øe, then they ≈øhall cea≈øe and forbeare any farther execution of the commi≈ø≈øion.
And the Commi≈øsioners ≈øhall certifie and returne the ≈øaid cau≈øes and exceptions up with the commi≈øsion.

Item, If the party adver≈øant cannot ≈øhew ≈øufficient cau≈øe (as afore≈øaid) then the commi≈øsioners ≈øhall proceed to the examination of witne≈ø≈øes; and the party adver≈øant or defendants ≈øhall have liberty to joyne in the examination of the ≈øame witne≈ø≈øes, or o ‚Ä¢ any other likewi≈øe upon Interrogatories on his behalfe (if he thinke good.)

Item, The commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall certifie
in their returne of the commi≈øsion, ≈øuch acceptations as the defendant ≈øhall take again≈øt the proceeeding in the ≈øame Commi≈øsion, and whether the De endant did appear or no?
And if the Defendant did not appeare, they are likewi≈øe to certifie and return, whether Affidavit were made of the giving of warning by precept (as afore. ≈øaid) or no?

div.head: Orders to be ob≈øerved before the granting of Publication of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øion.
div.p: THe party who prayeth Publication, ≈øhall fir≈øt by him≈øelfe, or ≈øome other, make Oath that the Depo≈øitions of the ≈øame witne≈ø≈øes, are nece≈ø≈øarily to be given in evidence on his behalfe.
Item, Oath al≈øo mu≈øt be made, that the ≈øame Witne≈ø≈øes be either dead, or ≈øo aged, or impotent as they cannot travell to te≈øtifie (viva voce) without danger of life.

Item This Oath being ≈øo taken, a Ma≈øter of the Chancery mu≈øt fir≈øt open the Commi≈ø≈øion, and con≈øider whether this Order before mentioned hath been ob≈øerved
in all points: wherein hee being ≈øatisfied, Publication is thereupon to be granted.
Provided alwayes, that no Depo≈øitions ≈øhall be given in evidence, but again≈øt tho≈øe per≈øons that were warned by precept (as afore≈øaid) or again≈øt their Heirs or A≈øsignes.

And provided al≈øo, That after examination had, and taken (as a ore≈øaid,) and after Publication had, and granted of the ≈øame examinations: The party Adver≈øant, or Defendant, ≈øhall not be admitted to have any new examination on his behalfe, concerning the ≈øame matter.

Item, This Order is to be ob≈øerved in ca≈øe where the commi≈øsion is ex parie querentis only, and it is to be engro≈ø≈øed in Parchment, and ≈øub≈øcribed with the hand of the Regi≈øter, and to be annexed to every of the ≈øaid commi≈øsions, but not otherwi≈øe.
Fur if the Defendant joyne, then the≈øe articles ≈øhall not need.

div.head: The difference u≈øed between a Joynt. Commi≈ø≈øion in the afore≈øaid nature, and Commi≈øsion ex parte followeth.
div.p: THe Joynt-Commi≈øsion is made in forme, as all other generall commi≈øsions to examine witne≈ø≈øes, Super Interrogator, mini≈øtrand, be, Adding to the end of the ≈øame the≈øe word (viz.) In perpetuam rei memoriam perman≈øur.

This Commi≈øsion ex parte, is to have the≈øe rules in≈øerted under the Regi≈øters hand, and the Commi≈øsioners names are ≈øpecially to be a≈øsigned by the Lord Keeper, or, Lord Chancellour for the time being.

div.head: Termino Michaelis, Anno Regni Elizab. Reg. Sext.
div.p:
MEmorandum, That all Injunctions granted for pre≈øervation of po≈ø≈øe≈øsion, during the ≈øuit in the Court of Chancery, ≈øhall have this clau≈øe and condition contained in them (viz.) That the partie who prayeth po≈ø≈øe≈øsion, was in po≈ø≈øe≈øsion at the time of the Bill exhibited, and certaine yeares before;
And that his intere≈øt is not determined by forfeiture, ≈øurrender, or other lawfull means,
And Bond mu≈øt be put in by the party who prayeth the po≈ø≈øe≈øsion, of the penalty of ten pound, with condition that this Information afore≈øaid is true.

Item, That all Injunctions granted for the ≈øtay of ≈øuits at the common Law, ≈øhall have this clau≈øe and condition contained in them: (viz.) That the ≈øame ≈øuit de≈øired to be ≈øtayed, is for and concerning the ≈øame matter depending in this Court, and as were begun at the Common Law, after the Bill exhibited into this Court; and that Bond be put in (as afore≈øaid.)

Item, That no ≈øpeciall Certiorare doe pa≈ø≈øe without Bond fir≈øt given, on the behalfe of the party who de≈øireth the ≈øame; with condition that the Bill exhibited containeth matter ≈øufficient to beare a Certiorare, and that hee ≈øhall prove the contents of this Bill to be true, within fifteen dayes after the returne of the Writ, according to the order and cour≈øe of this Court.
And that upon the granting of every Procedendo the Bond afore≈øaid be remembred to the Lord Keeper.

div.head: Termino Trinitatis, Anno Regni Elizab. Reginae Septimo.
div.p: The Proce≈ø≈øe now is made returnable but three dayes before the hoaring.It is ordered, that all Suits for no more then ≈øix acres of Land, or le≈ø≈øe, except the ≈øame be worth forty ≈øhillings by the year.

And all Suites for matter under the value of ten pounds, ≈øhall be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed this Court, for ≈øuch cau≈øe only proved. And this Court ≈øhall not retaine any ≈øuch: But the party who bringeth the ≈øame hither, ≈øhall pay co≈øts to the Defeudant, as this Court ≈øhall award.

div.head: Termino Michaelis, Anno Regni Eliz. Reg. Septimo.
div.p: IT is ordered, that all Proce≈ø≈øe to beare Iudgement, be returnable ≈øix or ≈øeven dayes before the day of Hearing, and not above, ≈øaving in the beginning of the Terme, when the time will not permit ≈øo long warning.
And the ≈øaid Writs mu≈øt he endor≈øet on the back-≈øide, with the very day appointed for the hearing of Iudgement. And ≈øo much for that Terme.

By the generall cu≈øtome, and ancient u≈øage of this Court, all Bils ≈øhall be retainable here, in ca≈øe where the Equity of the cau≈øe requireth and beareth it, and wherein the common Law doth afford no reliefe, but rather pre≈ø≈øure and rigour.

After Publication once had the Complainant may procure a day of Hearing of cour≈øe, by ≈øuch as one of the ≈øix Clerks as dealeth for him. And he may at the end of the Term, when the Lord Keeper ≈øetteth down the dayes of Hearings, procure his hearing to be ≈øet downe among≈øt tho≈øe a≈ø≈øigned for the next ≈øucceeding Term.

This was wont to be ancient cour≈øe of procuring of Hearings, how≈øoever it was lately di≈ø-u≈øed and (as I take it) the ≈øame is now re≈øtored againe to the good contentment of al Suitors in this Court.

div.head: The Order of Proceeding again≈øt ≈øuch as refu≈øe to obey His Maje≈øties Injunctions, proceeding and i≈ø≈øuing out of the Court of Chancery.
div.p: FOr the breach of an Injunction, this is the cour≈øe commonly.

If the Contemptor doe not upon ≈øight of the Injunction obey the ≈øame, but doth commit ≈øome Act in contempt or neglect thereof, then upon an Affidavit made of the ≈øerving of the ≈øaid Injunction, and of the breach thereof, then an Attachment is awarded again≈øt the ≈øaid Contemptor, &c. as in the ca≈øe of Proces, before mentioned and declared, and ≈øo further Proces to common Rebellion and Serjeant at armes, &c.

div.head: The Moderne Orders and Ordinances of Chancery follow.

div.p: NO Affidavit ≈øhall be admitted or taken which ≈øhal tend to the proof or di≈ø-proof of the Title or matter in que≈øtion, or touching the merits of the cau≈øe.
Neither ≈øhall any ≈øuch matter be colourably in≈øerted, in any Affidavit to be made touching the Serving of Proces.
No Affidavit ≈øhall be taken again≈øt Affidavit ≈øo far as the Ma≈øter of Chancery can di≈øcerne, or take knowledge, &c.
If any ≈øuch be taken, the latter ≈øhall not be u≈øed or read in Court.

div.head: Contempts.
div.p: IN ca≈øe of Contempts, granted upon force, or ill words, u≈øed upon ≈øerving of Proces, or other words of Scandall, proved by Affidavit, the party forthwith upon motion will be committed, if the words ≈øpoken de≈øerve it.
But for other Contempts, again≈øt the Orders or Decrees of the Court.
Fir≈øt, an Attachment goes forth upon Affidavit made.
Then the party being taken is to be examined upon Interrogatories.
His examination is to be referred, upon motion, to one of the Ma≈øters of the Chancery.
And if upon examination, he confe≈ø≈øe matter of contempt, he is to be committed upon the like motion.
If he confe≈ø≈øe it not, the Adver≈øe party may upon like motion and order examine witne≈ø≈øes to prove the contempt.
And if the contempt appeare upon proof, the contemptor is to be committed therefore, upon motion and order likewi≈øe.

But if the adver≈øe party fail to prove the ≈øaid contempt, or fail to put in his Interrogatories or other pro≈øecution, then the party charged with the contempt, is to be di≈øcharged upon motion with good co≈øts.
Impri≈øonment upon Contempts for matters pa≈øt, may be di≈øcharged of grace, after ≈øufficient puni≈øhment: Or it may be otherwi≈øe di≈øpen≈øed withall in ≈øuch ca≈øe.

But if the impri≈øonment be for performance of any Order of the Court in force: Then the Contemplator ought not to be di≈øcharged, except he fir≈øt obey: Only, the contempt may bee ≈øu≈øpended for a time.

div.head: Petitions.
div.p: NO Injunctions, Seque≈øtration, Di≈ømi≈ø≈øions Retainer upon Di≈ømi≈ø≈øions, or Finall Orders, ≈øhall be granted upon Petitions.

No former Order made in court, is to be altered, cro≈ø≈øed or explained upon any Petition: But ≈øuch Orders may be only ≈øtayed upon Petition for a ≈ømall
time, till the matter may be moved in court.

No Commi≈ø≈øions for examination of Witne≈ø≈øes ≈øhall be di≈øcharged; Nor any examinations, or depo≈øitions of witne≈ø≈øes ≈øhall be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed upon Petition, unle≈ø≈øe it be fir≈øt referred, and Certificate be made thereupon.

div.head: Injunctions.
div.p: INjunctions for po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or for ≈øtay of Suits after verdict, are to be pre≈øented to the Lord Keeper, or Lord Chancellor, being together, with the Orders whereupon they goe forth; that his Lord≈øhip may take con≈øideration of the Orders before he ≈øigne them.
No Injunction of any nature ≈øhall be granted, revived, di≈ø≈øolved, or ≈øtaid upon private Petition.
No Injunction to ≈øtay Suits at the common Law, ≈øhall be granted upon Prioritie of Suite only:
Or upon the Surmi≈øe of the complainants Bill only.
But upon matter confe≈ø≈øed in the An≈øwer of the Defendant.
Or matter of Record.
Or writing plainly appearing.
Or when the Defendant is in contempt for not an≈øwering.
Or when the debt de≈øired to be ≈øtaid, appeareth to be old, and hath ≈ølept long.
The creditor and the debter have been dead ≈øome good time, before the Suite brought.

Where the Defendant appears not, but ≈øits an Attachment: Or when hee doth appeare and departs without an≈øwer, and is under attachment for an an≈øwering: Orwhere he takes Oath, that he cannot an≈øwer without ≈øight of Evidences in the Countrey: Or ab≈øenting him≈øelfe in one private place, or beyond Sea, and cannot be found to be ≈øerved with a Sub-paena, upon Oath made, an Injunction is u≈øually granted.
In all the≈øe ca≈øes, an Injunction may be granted, for ≈øtay of ≈øuites at the Common Law, untill the party an≈øwer, or appeare in per≈øon in Court, and the Court give further order.
An Injunction never is di≈ø≈øolved without motion on the adver≈øe part.

In the ca≈øe afore≈øaid, where an Injunction is to be granted, for ≈øtay of ≈øuits at
the common Law; if the like Suits be in the Chancery, either by Scire facias or by Priviledge or Engli≈øh Bill; then the Suit is to be ≈øtaid by order of the Court, as it is in other Courts by Injunction.
An Injunction is u≈øually granted, if the party Defendant be in Contempt, or matter confe≈øt, though after an arre≈øt or further proceedings at Law without bringing money in Court.

Injunctions for Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion are not to be granted before a Decree, but where the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion hath continued by the ≈øpace of three yeares pa≈øt before the Bill exhibited, and upon the ≈øame Title, and not upon any Title by leave or determined.

In ca≈øe where the Defendant ≈øits all the proce≈ø≈øe of Contempt, and cannot be found by the Sergeant at Armes, or re≈øi≈øts the Sergeant, or make re≈øcues, a Seque≈øtration ≈øhall be granted of the Land in que≈øtion, and if the Defendant doe not render him≈øelfe within the yeare, then an Injunction ≈øhall be granted for the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

Injunctions again≈øt the felling of Timber, or plowing up of ancient Pa≈øtures, or for the maintaining of Inclo≈øures, or the like, ≈øhall be granted according to
the circum≈øtances of the ca≈øe, but not in ca≈øe, where the Defendant upon his an≈øwer, claimeth a ≈øtate of inheritance, except it be where he claimeth the Land in tru≈øt, or upon ≈øome other ≈øpeciall ground.
Injunctions ≈øhall be enrolled, or the Tran≈øcripts thereof be filed.

div.head: Order.
div.p: WHere any Order ≈øhall be made again≈øt the generall Rules of the Court, there the Regi≈øter ≈øhal plainly and expre≈øly ≈øet downe the particular rea≈øons and grounds, moving the Court to vary from the generall rule.

No order of the publick Court is al
‚Ä¢ erable upon Petition: vid. in the Title Petition.

div.head: Regi≈øter: Order.
div.p: THe Regi≈øters are to be ≈øworne.

If any Order ≈øhall be made, and the Court not informed of the la≈øt martiall Order formerly made, no benefit ≈øhall be taken by ≈øuch Order, as being granted by abu≈øe, and ≈øurreption: And
to that end, the Regi≈øter ought duly to mention the la≈øt former Order in the pre≈øent Order.

No Order ≈øhall be explained upon any Petition, but only in Court as they are made, and the Regi≈øter is to ≈øet downe the Orders, as they are pronounced by the Court, truly, at his perill, without troubling the Lord Keeper, or Lord Chancellour, by any private attending of him, to explaine his meaning; and if any explanation be de≈øired, it is to be done by publick motion, where the other party may be heard.

No draught of any Order ≈øhall be delivered by the Regi≈øter to either party, without keeping of a Copy by him: to the end that if the Order be not entred; neverthele≈ø≈øe, the Court may be enformed what was formerly done, and not be put to a new trouble, and to the end al≈øo, that knowledge of Orders be not kept backe too long from either party, but may pre≈øently appear at the Office.

Where a cau≈øe hath been debated upon the hearing of both parties: and opinion hath been delivered by the court; and neverthele≈ø≈øe, the cau≈øe referred to Treaty: the Regi≈øters are not to omit
the opinion of the Court in drawing of the Order of Reference, except the Court doe ≈øpecially declare, that it is to be entred without any opinion either way.

In which ca≈øe, neverthele≈ø≈øe, the Regi≈øters are out of their ≈øhort Notes to draw up ≈øome more full remembrance of that which pa≈ø≈øed in Court to inform the Court if the cau≈øe come backe, and cannot be agreed.

The Regi≈øters upon delivery of the draught of any Order, unto the coun≈øell of either party, are not to re≈øpect the Interlineations, or alterations of the ≈øaid Coun≈øell (be the ≈øaid Coun≈øell never ≈øo great) further then as to put them in remembrance of that which was truly delivered in Court; and ≈øo to conceive the Order upon their Oath and duty, without any other or farther re≈øpect.

The Regi≈øters are to be carefull in the penning and drawing up of Decrees; and e≈øpecially in matters of difficulty and weight; and therefore when they pre≈øent the ≈øame to the Lord Keeper, or Lord Chancellor, they ought to give him under≈øtanding which are ≈øuch Decrees of weight, that they may be read and reviewed,
before his Lord≈øhip ≈øign them.

div.head: Decrees.
div.p: THe Decrees or di≈ømi≈ø≈øions made or granted in the Rolles, and tho≈øe that are made in Court at We≈øtmin≈øter on Wedne≈ødayes or Fridays, when the Lord Keeper is not pre≈øent (being drawn up) are fir≈øt to bee ≈øigned by the Ma≈øter of the Rols, or the Judge that ≈øat at the hearing of the cau≈øe, and then pre≈øented to the Lord Keeper to be likewi≈øe ≈øigned; which being done, then the ≈øame are to he enrolled.

NO Decrees ≈øhall be rever≈øed altered or explained, being once enrolled, but upon Bill of Review; and no Bill of Review ≈øhall be admitted, except it be upon errour in Law, appearing in the body of the Decree, without farther examination of matters in fact or he ≈øhall ≈øhew ≈øome new matter which hath ri≈øen in time after the Decree, and not any new proof, which might have been u≈øed when the Decree was made.

Neverthele≈ø≈øe, upon new proof which is come to light ≈øince, and after the Decree made, and could not po≈ø≈øibly have
been u≈øed at the time when the Decree pa≈ø≈øed, a Bill of Review may be granted by the ≈øpeciall Licen≈øe of the Court, and not otherwi≈øe.

Al≈øo upon a Bill of Review the party Complaynant is to put in ≈øecurity before one of the Ma≈øters of the Court, to ≈øtand to and performe the order of the Court, upon the hearing upon ≈øuch Bill of Review,
In ca≈øe of mi≈ø-ca≈øting, being a matter Demon≈øtrative, a Decree may be explained, and reconciled by an Order without Bill of Review.
Where note, that by the word Mi≈øca≈øting, is not intended any pretended Mi≈ø-ca≈øting, or mi≈ø-valuing, but only errour in the Auditing, or numbring.

No Bill of Review ≈øhall be admitted, or any other new Bill to change matter decreed, except the Decree fir≈øt obtained, be performed: And if it be for Land, that the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion be yeelded: If it be for money, that the money be paid: If it be for evidence, that the evidence be brought in; and ≈øo in other ca≈øes which ≈øtand upon the ≈øtrength of the Decree alone.

But if any Act be de≈øired to be done,
which extingui≈øheth the parties righ at the Common Law (as making of A≈ø≈øurance and Relea≈øe, Acknowledging of Satisfaction, Cancelling of Records or Evidence, and the like) Tho≈øe parts of the Decree are to be ≈øpared, untill the Bill of Review be determined: But ≈øuch ≈øparing is to be warranted by publicke Order made in Court.
No Decree ≈øhall be made upon pretence of equity, again≈øt the expre≈ø≈øe provi≈øion of an Act of Parliament.

Neverthele≈ø≈øe, if the con≈øtruction of ≈øuch Act of Parliament, hath for a time gone one way in generall opinion and reputation; and after by a latter judgement hath bin controlled: Then Reliefe may be given upon matter of equity for ca≈øes ari≈øing before the ≈øaid Judgement: becau≈øe the Subject was in no default.

Impri≈øonment for breach of a Decree is in nature of an Execution, and therefore the cu≈øtody ought to be ≈øtraight, and the party not to have any liberty to goe abroad, but by ≈øpeciall licen≈øe of the Lord Keeper or Lord Chancellour being: But no clo≈øe impri≈øonment is to be but by expre≈ø≈øe order for wilfull and extraordinary Contempts and di≈øobedience (as hath been u≈øed.)

In ca≈øe of ob≈øtinate di≈øobedience, in the breach of a Decree an Injunction is to be granted Sub-poena of a ≈øumme: and upon Affidavit, or other ≈øufficient proofe of per≈øi≈øting in contempt, Fines are to be pronounced by the Lord Keeper, or Lord Chancellor in open Court, and the ≈øame are to be e≈øtrated downe into the Hannaper by ≈øpeciall order.

In ca≈øe of a Decree made for the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Land, a Writ of Execution goeth forth, and if that be di≈ø≈øobeyed, then Proce≈ø≈øe of Contempt, according to the cour≈øe of the Court, is to goe forth again≈øt the per≈øon unto the Commi≈ø≈øion of Rebellion; and then a Sergeant at Armes by ≈øpeciall Warrant: and in ca≈øe the Sergeant at Armes cannot find him, Or he be re≈øi≈øted, Or if he upon his commitment doe per≈øi≈øt in his di≈øobedience, an Injunction is to be granted for the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and in ca≈øe that it al≈øo be di≈øobeyed, then a Commi≈ø≈øion is to be made to the Sheriffe, to put his adver≈øary into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

Where the party is committed for breach of a Decree, he is not to be enlarged, untill the Decree be fully performed
in all things which are to be done pre≈øently.

But if there be other parts of the Decree to be performed at dayes or times to come: Then he may be enlarged by order of the Court, entring into Recognizance with Sureties for the performance de futuro but not otherwi≈øe.
Where cau≈øes come to hearing in Court, no Decree bindeth any Per≈øon, who was not ≈øerved with Proce≈ø≈øe ad audiendum judicium, according to the cour≈øe of the Court.
No Decree bindeth any one that commeth in bona fide, by Conveyance from the Defendant before the Bill exhibited; and is made no party either by Bill or by Order.
But where her comes in Pendente lite, and while the Suit is in full pro≈øecution, and without any colour of allowance, or privity of the Court: there regularly the Decree bindeth.
But if there were any intermi≈ø≈øion of ≈øuite, or the Court were made acquainted with the Conveyance, the Court is to give order upon the ≈øpeciall matter according to Ju≈øtice.

Where a Decree made for a Rent to
be paid out of Land, or a ≈øumme of money to be levied upon the profits of Land; there a Seque≈øtration of the ≈øame Land being in the Defendants hand, may be granted upon the Decree.

Where the Decree of the Provinciall coun≈øells, or the Court of Reque≈øts or the like, are by contumacy or other meanes interrupted: there the Court of Chancery, upon a Bill preferred for corroboration of the Decrees of that juri≈ødiction ≈øhall give remedy.

Where any cau≈øe come to hearing here which hath been formerly decreed in any other of the Kings Courts of Iu≈øtice at We≈øtmin≈øter; ≈øuch Decree ≈øhall be fir≈øt read and then this Court ≈øhal proceed to heare the re≈øt of the evidences on both ≈øides.

Decrees upon Suits brought after Iudgement, ≈øhall containe no words to make void or weaken the. Judgement: But ≈øhall only correct the corrupt con≈øcience of the party, and rule him to make Re≈øtitution, or to performe other acts, according to the equity of the cau≈øe.

div.head: Bill of Review.
div.p: Decrees are not to be rever≈øed, altered, or explained, being once enrolled, but upon Bill of Review.
Bill of Review ≈øhall not be admitted, except the Decree be fir≈øt obeyed and performed.
No Bill of Review ≈øhall be put in, except the party that prefers it, enter into Recognizance, with ≈øureties for the ≈øatisfying of co≈øts and damages for the Delay, if it be found again≈øt him.

div.head: Reference, Report.
div.p: NO Reference upon a Demurrer, or que≈øtion touching the Juri≈ødiction of this Court, ≈øhall be made to the Ma≈øters of the Chancery, but ≈øuch Demurrer ≈øhall be heard and ruled in the Court, or by the Lord Keeper, or Lord Chancellor him≈øelfe.
For the confirming or ratifying of any Report, No Order ≈øhall be made, without day to be given by the ≈øpace of a Seven-night (at lea≈øt) to ≈øpeake unto it in Court.

No Reference ≈øhall be made to any Ma≈øter of the Court, or any other Commi≈ø≈øioner or Commi≈ø≈øioners, to he are and determine where the cau≈øe is gone ≈øo farre as to Examination of witne≈ø≈øes: Except it be in ≈øpeciall ca≈øes of parties neer in blood, or of extreme poverty, or by con≈øent.
And generally, References of the ≈øtate of the cau≈øe, are to be ≈øparingly granted; except it be by con≈øent of the parties.
No Report ≈øhall be re≈øpect in Court, which exceedeth the warrant o ‚Ä¢ the Order of reference which leadeth it.

The Ma≈øters of the Court are required, that by Report they doe not certifie the e≈øtate of the cau≈øe; as if they would make Breviates of the Evidence on both ≈øides, which doth little ea≈øe the Court; but that they doe it with ≈øome opinion: Or otherwi≈øe, in ca≈øe they thinke it too doubtfull, to give opinion there; And thereupon they are to make ≈øuch ≈øpeciall Certificate, and the cau≈øe is to goe on to a judiciall hearing, without re≈øpect had to the ≈øame.

If both parties con≈øent to a Reference for the examination of Accompts
to make the Cau≈øe more ready for hearing, it may be granted. But generally matters of Accompt, excepting in very weighty Cau≈øes, are not fit for the Court, but are to be prepared by Reference, with this provi≈øion neverthele≈ø≈øe: That the Cau≈øes come fir≈øt to hearing, and upon the entrance into a hearing, they may receive ≈øome direction, and be turned over to be con≈øidered and prepared.
The like cour≈øe of Reference is to be taken for the examination of Court Rolles upon any Cu≈øtomes; and the Copies ≈øhall not be referred to any one Ma≈øter, but to two Ma≈øters at the lea≈øt.
No Reference ≈øhall be made of the In≈øufficiency of any An≈øwer, without ≈øhewing of ≈øome particular points of the defects thereof, and not upon ≈øurmize of the In≈øufficiency generally.

If a Complainant take exception to a Defendants An≈øwer, he mu≈øt deliver his exceptions to the Defendants cou ‚Ä¢
≈øell or Attourney; and if the Defendant within eight dayes amend his an≈øwer, he is to pay no co≈øts; but if he doe not, then a Reference is to be had to a Ma≈øter of the Court, and if he
report the An≈øwer in≈øufficient, then the Complainant may take out two Subpaena's again≈øt the Defendant, one for twenty ≈øhillings co≈øts, and the other to make a better an≈øwer.

Where a Tru≈øt is confe≈ø≈øed by the Defendants an≈øwer, there needeth no farther hearing of the cau≈øe, but a Reference pre≈øently to be made of the Accompts, and ≈øo they are to goe on to the hearing of the Accompts.

div.head: Di≈ømi≈ø≈øion.
div.p: WHere Cau≈øes are di≈ømi≈øt upon ful hearing, and the Di≈ømi≈ø≈øion ≈øignified by the Lord Keeper or Lord Chancellor, and inrolled, ≈øuch Cau≈øes ≈øhall not be retained againe, neither ≈øhall any new Bill be admitted, except it be upon new matter, like unto the ca≈øe of the Bill of Review.

In ca≈øe of all other Di≈ømi≈ø≈øions, which are not upon hearing of the Cau≈øe, if any new Bill be brought the Di≈ømi≈ø≈øion is to be pleaded; and after Reference and Report of the Contents of both Suits, and con≈øideration taken of the Cau≈øe or cau≈øes of the former Di≈ømi≈ø≈øion:
the Court ≈øhall rule and order the Retaining or Di≈ømi≈ø≈øion of the new Bill, according to ju≈øtice, and the nature of the Ca≈øe.

All ≈øuits grounded upon wils Nuncupative, Lea≈øes paroll, or upon long Lea≈øes, that tend to the defeating of the Kings Tenures, or for the e≈øtabli≈øhing of the Perpetuities; or granted upon Remainder over unto the Crowne, to defeat purcha≈øers; Or for Brocage, or Rewards to make marriages; Or for bargain at play; or Wagers for bargains for Offices, contrary to the Statute of the ≈øecond of Edward 6. Or upon contracts for u≈øury or Simony, are regularly to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed upon motion, if they be the whole matter of the Bil; and there be no ≈øpeciall circum≈øtances to move the court to allow them a Proceeding.
And all ≈øuits under the value of ten pounds, are Regularly to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.
Di≈ømi≈ø≈øions are properly to be prayed and had, either upon hearing, or upon Plea unto the Bill, when the cau≈øe comes fir≈øt into the Court.

But Di≈ømi≈ø≈øions are not to be prayed
after the parties have been at charge of examination of witne≈ø≈øes, except it be upon ≈øpeciall cau≈øe.
If the Complainant di≈øcontinue pro≈øecution, after all the Defendants have an≈øwered, above the ≈øpace of one whole Terme, the cau≈øe is to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed of cour≈øe without motion.

But after Replication is put in, the cau≈øe is not to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed without motion and order of the Court: and that motion is not to be made till four Termes after the Replication put in, and that in ca≈øe there have been no proceeding after the Replication, either by Motions, References, examination of witne≈ø≈øes, or the like.
For double vexation, the cau≈øe may be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.

Where cau≈øes are Removed by ≈øpeciall Certiorare, upon a Bill containing matter of equity; the Complainant is upon Receipt of his Writ, to put in Bond to prove his ≈øugge≈øtions within fourteen dayes after the Receipt, which if he doe not prove, then upon certificate from either of the Examiners, pre≈øented to the Lord Keeper or Lord Chancellor, the cau≈øe ≈øhall be di≈ømi≈øt
with co≈øts, and a Procedendo ≈øhall be granted.

div.head: Demurrer.
div.p: DEmurrers and Pleas which tend to the di≈øcharging of any ≈øuite, ≈øhall be neard fir≈øt upon every day of Orders, that the Subject may know, whether he ≈øhall need to give further attendance or no.
A Demurrer is properly upon matter defective contained in the Bill it ≈øelfe: or foraigne matter.
But a Plea is of foraigne matter, to charge or ≈øtay the ≈øuit. (as)
That the cau≈øe hath been formerly di≈ømi≈øt,
That the Complainant is out-lawed.
That the Complainant is excommunicate.
That there is another Bill depending for the ≈øame cau≈øe.
Or the like.
And ≈øuch Plea may be put in without Oath, in ca≈øe where the matter of Plea appears upon Record, but if it be any thing which doth not appear upon Record, then the Plea mu≈øt be put in upon Oath.
No Outlary ≈øhall be allowed, without pleading Record Sub pede Sigilli: Nor plea of Excommunication without the Seale of the Ordinary.

Where any ≈øuite appeareth upon the Bill to be of the nature of any of tho≈øe which are regularly to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, according to the Order before mentioned the ≈øaid Order is to be ≈øet forth by way of Demurrer.

div.head: An≈øwer.
div.p: WHere an An≈øwer ≈øhall be certified to be ≈øufficient, the Defendant is to pay co≈øts.
And if a ≈øecond An≈øwer be returned in≈øufficient in the points before certified for in≈øufficient, then hee ≈øhall pay double co≈øts.
And upon the third like ca≈øe, treble co≈øts.

And upon the fourth, quadrupile co≈øts, and then to be committed al≈øo till he ≈øhall have made a perfect and ≈øufficient An≈øwer and he ≈øhall be examined upon Interrogatories, touching the points defective in his An≈øwer.

But if any An≈øwer be certified to be
≈øufficient, then the Complainant is to pay co≈øts.
No In≈øufficiency of An≈øwer can be taken hold of, after Replication put in, becau≈øe it is admitted for ≈øufficient by the Replication.

An An≈øwer to a matter charged as the Defendants own fact, mu≈øt be direct, without ≈øaying that It is to his remembrance, or as he beleeveth, if it be bid downe to be done within ≈øeven years before.
And if the Defendant doe deny the Fact then he mu≈øt traver≈øe it directly, and not by way Negative pregnant.
As if a Fact be laid to be done with divers circum≈øtances; the Defendant may not traver≈øe it literally as it is laid in the Bill: But he mu≈øt traver≈øe the point of ≈øub≈øtance.

So as if he be charged with the receipt of an 100. pounds he mu≈øt traver≈øe that he hath not received an 100. l or any part therof. And i ‚Ä¢ he have received any part of it, he mu≈øt ≈øet downe what part he hath received.
If a Hearing be prayed upon Bill and An≈øwer: the An≈øwer mu≈øt be admitted to be true in all points.
And a Decree ought not to be made, but upon hearing of the An≈øwer read in Court.
Where no Coun≈øell appears for the Defendant at the hearing, and the Proce≈ø≈øe appears to have been ≈øerved, the An≈øwer of ≈øuch Defendant is to be read in Court.
No new matter is to be contained in any Replication except it be to avoid matter ≈øet forth in the Defendants An≈øwer.
